 Dow Jones

Fitch Revises Boeing's Outlook to Stable; Affirms IDR at 'BBB-'
3281 words
30 June 2025
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2025 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-30 June 2025: Fitch Ratings has revised the Rating Outlook on The Boeing Company's Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) to Stable from Negative and has affirmed the IDR at 'BBB-'. Fitch has also affirmed Boeing's Short-Term IDR and CP rating at 'F3' and its senior unsecured notes and revolvers at 'BBB-'.

The Outlook revision to Stable reflects Fitch's view that the post-strike production ramp and enhanced financial flexibility, including the announced Jeppesen sale, have reduced downgrade risks and support the 'BBB-' rating. The Stable Outlook also incorporates Fitch's expectation of gross debt reduction, including repayment of all 2026 notes at maturity ($7.95 billion).

Sustained operational improvements, particularly continued 737MAX production progress, should drive FCF generation and EBITDA leverage metrics consistent with 'BBB-' thresholds. Fitch will monitor Boeing's ability to maintain operational momentum and provide greater clarity on long-term capital allocation, which could support further rating improvement within 6-12 months.

Key Rating Drivers

BCA Stabilization Drives Credit Enhancement: The Stable Outlook reflects the significant post-strike operational progress at Boeing Commercial Airplanes (BCA), supporting the investment-grade credit profile. BCA has increased 737MAX production to the mid-30s per month, targeting 38 per month during 3Q25. Fitch expects 787 production to average eight per month in 2026, up from an average of six in 2025. Production sustained at these levels supports FCF generation, subject to 777X production pace and certification status, with higher output incrementally de-risking the operational and FCF profiles.

Boeing has also reduced legacy inventory, delivering 10-15 parked aircraft each month. Fitch expects the reduction of legacy 737MAX inventory to facilitate the progressive return to a more normalized production-to-delivery cadence, driving substantial improvements in working capital and enabling annual FCF generation in the mid-to-high single-digit billions by 2026. The closure of shadow factories is expected to unlock resources to further support safety and quality targets and enable sustained higher production levels, allowing the company to achieve more predictable delivery schedules.

Debt Reduction and Capital Structure Improvement: Boeing's debt reduction efforts, coupled with anticipated EBITDA recovery as production rates normalize, are expected to drive leverage metrics toward 'BBB' thresholds in the 2027 period. Fitch forecasts EBITDA leverage to improve to below 4.0x and 3.0x in 2026 and 2027, respectively. The company's robust liquidity position, with approximately $34 billion in proforma cash and short-term investments, including the announced Jeppesen sale, as of March 31, 2025, provides additional financial flexibility during this transition period.

The $24 billion equity issuance in late 2024 materially strengthened Boeing's balance sheet, enabling the company to de-risk its financial profile while supporting operational execution. Fitch expects Boeing to retire all 2026 notes ($7.95 billion) upon their respective maturities. This would drive gross debt below $50 billion in 2026, a key consideration in the Stable Outlook revision.

$545+ Billion Backlog Provides Visibility: Boeing's multi-year backlog provides strong visibility into future production and underscores sustained demand for its commercial aircraft portfolio. As of March 31, 2025, Boeing's total backlog exceeded $545 billion, with approximately $460 billion tied to commercial customers. This includes orders for over 5,600 aircraft, of which more than 4,300 are 737s. This robust order book extends into the next decade and reinforces Fitch's confidence in the company's long-term revenue generation capability.

Portfolio Optimization Supports Liquidity, Strategy: Boeing's plan to divest portions of its Digital Aviation Solutions business (Jeppesen) to Thoma Bravo for $10.55 billion represents a significant milestone in the company's portfolio optimization strategy. This transaction, which is not subject to capital market risk and is expected to close in 4Q25, will provide substantial incremental liquidity. Fitch views positively management's commitment to further streamline operations through additional pruning of peripheral business segments, which should enhance focus on core aerospace capabilities while generating proceeds to support the balance sheet and fund strategic initiatives.

Certifications Would Accelerate Recovery: Fitch anticipates that achieving 777X certification will further catalyze Boeing's financial improvement. Expected in early 2026, the certification would unlock significant working capital currently tied up in inventory, potentially avoiding a production versus FCF decision in case of extended delays. The resulting boost to FCF would enhance financial flexibility, supporting debt reduction efforts and enhancing capital allocation flexibility. Certifications for the 737MAX-7 and -10 variants would also be favorable, but backlog depth and the substitutability of other MAX variants helps mitigate the near-term impact on the credit profile.

Legacy Defense Contracts Remain Overhang: Boeing's Defense, Space & Security (BDS) segment remains weighed down by loss-making legacy contracts, particularly in its fixed-price development, fighter, and satellite programs, which together represent about 40% of the portfolio. Losses are likely to continue until these programs conclude, despite ongoing efforts to mitigate operational and financial impacts. Fitch expects management to continue reviewing the portfolio and divesting non-core BDS assets over the next few years, potentially sharpening focus on core areas such as fixed-wing aircraft, as demonstrated by the recent sixth-generation fighter contract win.

Future Capital Deployment Awaits Clarification: Greater clarity around Boeing's capital spending and allocation priorities, particularly regarding the new U.S. Air Force F-47 program and 2027 debt maturities, would further strengthen its credit profile. A defined long-term strategy balancing growth, debt reduction, and potential shareholder returns would improve visibility into Boeing's priorities and reinforce confidence in its financial trajectory.

Peer Analysis

Boeing is rated four notches below its most immediate peer, Airbus SE (A/Stable). This is largely due to Boeing's operational challenges over the past several years, which have combined to weaken its quantitative rating factors compared with Airbus. Cash flow generation is one of the key differentiators between Airbus and Boeing. In the past, Boeing consistently achieved significantly better FCF and funds from operations due to program execution and lower investment needs despite higher dividend payments. However, the 737MAX grounding and subsequent disruptions severely affected Boeing's cash flow and caused debt to rise significantly versus Airbus's.

Boeing's business profile has also been modestly stronger than Airbus's because of a more diverse revenue mix between commercial and defense, in addition to services. Airbus currently has meaningfully stronger leverage metrics. Airbus generally operates with a net cash position, though both companies have significant financial flexibility. Foreign exchange exposure is also a key differentiator between Boeing and Airbus, with the former having less exposure and the latter with more significant exposure, although Airbus has taken steps to address this.

Key Assumptions

--Overall revenue up mid-30% in 2025 followed by low double-digit growth in 2026 and 2027; FCF positive in 2026 and thereafter;

--737MAX production rate reaches 38 per month run-rate in 3Q25; 787 production rate average six per month in 2025 and around eight per month in 2026;

--Deliveries of 737MAX in high-400s during 2025 and mid-500s in 2026; 787 deliveries around 100 in 2025 and above 100 in 2026;

--More than half of 737MAX inventory is liquidated during 2025, with the remainder liquidated in 2026;

--BDS/BGS revenue relatively flat-to-positive over the next few years;

--BCA operating margins negative in 2025, turning positive in 2026 and steadily increasing through 2027;

--BDS operating margins negative in 2025, turning positive in 2026;

--Pension contributions remain around $800 million to $1 billion per year throughout the forecasted period;

--Capital expenditures remain around $2.5 billion per year or approximately 2%-2.5% of total sales.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Negative Rating Action/Downgrade

--Material negative developments with any of the company's major programs leading to delivery delays, order cancellations, large additional costs or inventory write-downs, resulting in FCF margins sustained below 2%;

--Operational missteps and/or debt-funded acquisitions or share repurchases lead to EBITDA leverage sustained above 4.0x;

--Indications of materially higher business risk from regulatory challenges, fines, litigation, or reputation and brand damage.

Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Positive Rating Action/Upgrade

--Sustained progress towards operational normalization via reduced inventory and increased production;

--Continued commitment to gross debt reduction leading to EBITDA leverage at or below 3.0x;

--Sustained FCF margins at or above 3%.

Liquidity and Debt Structure

Fitch views Boeing's liquidity as sufficient with proforma cash and investments around $34 billion, including the announced Jeppesen sale, as of March 31, 2025. Fitch forecasts Boeing will maintain full revolver availability and aim to sustain greater than $10 billion of cash over the next few years. We currently expect this will be adequate to cover negative FCF in 2025 and repayment of 2026 maturities, and project that FCF will exhibit improving trends with positive mid-single-digit billion-dollar FCF in 2026. Boeing's debt structure is predominantly comprised of senior unsecured notes, revolvers and commercial paper availability.

Issuer Profile

The Boeing Company is the world's largest aerospace & defense firm, and one of two major large commercial aircraft manufacturers, globally. The company operates in three principal segments: BDS; Boeing Commercial Aircraft; and BGSs.

Summary of Financial Adjustments

Fitch made standard analytical adjustments regarding non-recurring, one-time or forward charges.

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

MACROECONOMIC ASSUMPTIONS AND SECTOR FORECASTS

Click here: https://app.fitchconnect.com/search/research?keyword=Corporates%20Macro%20%26%20Sector%20Forecasts[https://app.fitchconnect.com/search/research?keyword=Corporates%20Macro%20%26%20Sector%20Forecasts]

to access Fitch's latest quarterly Global Corporates Macro and Sector Forecasts data file which aggregates key data points used in our credit analysis. Fitch's macroeconomic forecasts, commodity price assumptions, default rate forecasts, sector key performance indicators and sector-level forecasts are among the data items included.

ESG Considerations

The Boeing Company has an ESG Relevance Score of '4' for Management Strategy due to 737MAX production challenges, which has a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the ratings in conjunction with other factors. Below average execution on the 737MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs, lower cash flows, and elevated leverage.

The highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3', unless otherwise disclosed in this section. A score of '3' means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores are not inputs in the rating process; they are an observation on the relevance and materiality of ESG factors in the rating decision. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores[https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores].

Document FITRA00020250630el6u003xp


Fitch Ratings: Boeing Recovery Supports Suppliers, Airlines, & EETC Issuances
2031 words
26 June 2025
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2025 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-Toronto-26 June 2025: Boeings (BBB-/Negative) steady production improvement enhances stability across the aerospace supply chain and could support a recovery in Enhanced Equipment Trust Certificate (EETC) issuances beginning in 2H25 or 2026, Fitch Ratings says. Rising aircraft deliveries bolsters confidence among suppliers and airlines, provides greater certainty for fleet planning and aircraft financing, and contributes to a more predictable operating environment for the sector.

Boeings operational progress is gaining traction following the resolution of the 2024 machinist strike, management changes, and increased production oversight. 737MAX production rates have climbed into the mid-30s per month, and Fitch expects run rates to reach 38 per month in 3Q25. The clearance of legacy inventory, with 10-15 previously built aircraft delivered each month, has provided a near-term boost to cash generation and working capital efficiency, while freeing up resources to support further production improvements. These operational milestones, along with the $24 billion equity raise and the pending $10.55 billion sale of Jeppesen, provide Boeing with greater financial flexibility to manage its backlog and future investments.

Consistent and predictable production at Boeing benefits suppliers and airline customers. More reliable delivery schedules support long-term fleet planning and enable a more orderly retirement of older aircraft, which is expected to normalize over the next year. The stabilization of Boeings supply chain, despite lingering risks from tariffs and geopolitical tensions, adds further confidence for tier-one and tier-two suppliers such as Howmet Aerospace (BBB+/Stable) and Hexcel Corporation (BBB-/Stable), many of whom rely on steady volumes to manage costs and investment. Boeing has indicated that its current supply chain is sufficient to support a 737MAX production rate of 38 aircraft per month, but additional improvements will likely be needed to accommodate higher output in the future.

Normalized aircraft production will also support aircraft financing markets. EETC issuance has been muted in recent years, reflecting airlines reluctance to lock in fixed-rate debt at elevated levels and ongoing uncertainty around aircraft delivery timing. Persistent delivery delays have complicated EETC structures, which often pre-fund future aircraft deliveries and include a specified delivery window from the time of funding. If manufacturers fail to deliver within this window, airlines must return unutilized funds to investors and secure alternative financing for the delayed aircraft. Disruptions highlighted by the 2024 Alaska Airlines door-plug incident resulted in heightened regulatory scrutiny and production delays.

Fitch expects EETC issuance to increase as Boeing demonstrates greater consistency in meeting scheduled deliveries. Improved certainty, together with substantial orderbooks that require financing, is likely to support a recovery in EETC issuance beginning in the second half of 2025 or into 2026. EETCs remain attractive to airlines with large orderbooks, as they offer an efficient means to finance batches of aircraft with investment-grade rated debt. With Boeings backlog approaching 6,000 commercial aircraft and delivery schedules now more reliable, upcoming certifications for the 737MAX-7, -10, and 777X could further support a rise in EETC volumes.

Aircraft Orders by Major North American Airlines[https://e.infogram.com/fcc286ea-3338-4587-8b09-69f07178125f?src=embed]

Fitch expects air travel demand to

soften: https://pro.fitchratings.com/research/article/PR_10306355[https://pro.fitchratings.com/research/article/PR_10306355]

but does not anticipate significant order deferrals or cancellations, particularly among typical EETC issuers. Aircraft purchase decisions have a lengthy planning cycle, and airlines remain motivated to modernize fleets for fuel efficiency and cost savings, and to increase average seat counts. Instead of pulling back on aircraft deliveries, airlines will likely manage seat capacity through retirement of older planes or reduced daily utilization. Backlogs for Boeing and Airbus aircraft are greater than 5,900 and 8,000 planes, respectively, with wait times for new deliveries extending multiple years.

Ratings are not a recommendation to buy, sell, or hold any security. Fitch receives fees from issuers, insurers, guarantors, other obligors, and underwriters for rating securities. Such fees generally vary from US$1,000 to US$750,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent) per issue. In certain cases, Fitch will rate all or a number of issues issued by a particular issuer, or insured or guaranteed by a particular insurer or guarantor, for a single annual fee. Such fees are expected to vary from US$10,000 to US$1,500,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent). The assignment, publication, or dissemination of a rating by Fitch shall not constitute a consent by Fitch to use its name as an expert in connection with any registration statement filed under the United States securities laws, the Financial Services and Markets Act of 2000 of the United Kingdom, or the securities laws of any particular jurisdiction. Due to the relative efficiency of electronic publishing and distribution, Fitch research may be available to electronic subscribers up to three days earlier than to print subscribers.

For Australia, New Zealand, Taiwan and South Korea only: Fitch Australia Pty Ltd holds an Australian financial services license (AFS license no. 337123) which authorizes it to provide credit ratings to wholesale clients only. Credit ratings information published by Fitch is not intended to be used by persons who are retail clients within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001.

Fitch Ratings, Inc. is registered with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission as a Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organization (the 'NRSRO'). While certain of the NRSRO's credit rating subsidiaries are listed on Item 3 of Form NRSRO and as such are authorized to issue credit ratings on behalf of the NRSRO (see https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory]), other credit rating subsidiaries are not listed on Form NRSRO (the 'non-NRSROs') and therefore credit ratings issued by those subsidiaries are not issued on behalf of the NRSRO. However, non-NRSRO personnel may participate in determining credit ratings issued by or on behalf of the NRSRO.

Document FITRA00020250626el6q002xl


Fitch Ratings: Boeing Continues to Stabilize Operations Amid Trade, Geopolitical Tensions
1928 words
11 March 2025
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2025 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York/Chicago/Toronto-11 March 2025: The Boeing Company (BBB-/Negative Outlook) has made early progress in resuming production post-strike, reducing legacy inventory, and managing supply chains, says Fitch Ratings. While escalating trade and geopolitical tensions are a risk, Fitch views Boeings operational execution, profitability improvement, and balance sheet management as the main drivers for its rating over the next two years.

Boeing has exhibited early progress resuming production, reducing legacy inventory, and managing supply chains after ending the strike and raising $24 billion in late 2024. The monthly production run rate for 737MAX has reached the low-to-mid 20s, with legacy inventory deliveries at about 10 per month. Fitch believes the initial post-strike operational progress paves the way to produce 38 units per month in 3Q25. While this represents a slight delay from Fitchs

previous: https://pro.fitchratings.com/research/article/PR_10286885[https://pro.fitchratings.com/research/article/PR_10286885]

expectations, other operational milestones remain broadly on track.

Boeing Operational Milestones March 2025[https://e.infogram.com/39ad64be-437a-4fc0-96aa-34f10d8f5311?src=embed]

Boeings commercial revenues and profitability are currently constrained by production rather than end-market demand, and Fitch does not view the risk of retaliatory tariffs on U.S.-made aircraft as a significant rating driver. Market values for commercial

aircraft: https://pro.fitchratings.com/research/article/PR_10287103[https://pro.fitchratings.com/research/article/PR_10287103]

have risen, supported by strong demand, supply constraints, and ongoing fleet replacement needs. Long-term demand strength is evident in the order backlogs of both Boeing and Airbus (A-/Positive), which extend to the end of the decade. As of Dec. 31, 2024, Boeing Commercial Airplane reported a backlog of $435 billion, comprising 5,554 aircraft, including 4,296 737 aircraft.

The Trump administrations recent threats to scale back military support for Europe have raised concerns that some EU countries may divert military spending to European defense companies, at the expense of U.S. companies. Such a shift would encounter numerous obstacles, require significant investment, and likely take many years to achieve at scale.

The more imminent challenge faced by Boeings Defense, Space & Security (BDS) segment is its loss-making legacy contracts. These include fixed-price development programs, and the fighter and satellite programs, which together comprise roughly 40% of the portfolio. Losses are likely to persist until these programs conclude in the coming years, despite Boeings efforts to engage with customers to manage operational and financial impacts. Fitch believes management will likely manage and, in some cases, divest non-core components of the BDS portfolio over the next few years. This will be followed by a more comprehensive, strategic portfolio realignment to enhance operational focus on core competencies, such as fixed-wing aircraft.

The equity raising in late 2024 enabled Boeing to prepay most of its 2025 debt maturities and reduce gross debt to about $53.9 billion at YE 2024. With cash and investments around $26.3 billion as of Dec. 31, 2024, Boeing has considerable financial flexibility to meet anticipated liquidity needs in 2025 as operations stabilize. Fitch continues to forecast FCF in the mid-single-digit billions, gross debt below $50 billion, and EBITDA leverage under 4x in 2026, in-line with investment-grade rating tolerances. Securing additional non-debt capital would further de-risk Boeings financial profile and support positive rating momentum.

Contacts:

Dino Kritikos

Managing Director, Corporates

+1 312 368 3150

dino.kritikos@fitchratings.com

+1 646 582 4777

ryan.s.oloughlin@fitchratings.com

+1 646 582 4577

ashley.rogers@fitchratings.com

+1 647 800 9142

yeeman.chin@fitchratings.com

In issuing and maintaining its ratings and in making other reports (including forecast information), Fitch relies on factual information it receives from issuers and underwriters and from other sources Fitch believes to be credible. Fitch conducts a reasonable investigation of the factual information relied upon by it in accordance with its ratings methodology, and obtains reasonable verification of that information from independent sources, to the extent such sources are available for a given security or in a given jurisdiction. The manner of Fitch's factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitch's ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed. Fitch Ratings makes routine, commonly-accepted adjustments to reported financial data in accordance with the relevant criteria and/or industry standards to provide financial metric consistency for entities in the same sector or asset class.

Document FITRA00020250311el3b0025t


Fitch Ratings: Boeing Equity Raise Supports Liquidity, Alleviates Downgrade Risk
1697 words
28 October 2024
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-Toronto/New York/Chicago-28 October 2024:

The Boeing Companys (Boeing; BBB-/Negative) announced equity offering supports debt repayment and increases financial flexibility amidst continued operational challenges, alleviating downgrade risk, says Fitch Ratings. Fitch continues to evaluate the companys ability to resolve its labor negotiations, regain operational momentum, and adhere to our negative rating sensitivity of decreasing gross debt below $50 billion and EBITDA leverage below 4x by YE 2026.

The $17.5 billion equity offering demonstrates managements willingness to access non-debt capital sources to preserve its $10 billion cash target, repay 2025-2026 maturities of around $12 billion, and fund expected cash needs into 2026. Pro forma cash and equivalents will be approximately $28 billion as of Sept. 30, 2024. Boeing launched its offering with a combination of $12.5 billion in common equity and $5 billion in mandatory convertibles. The mandatory convertibles offering will have conversion date and rate, subordination, dividend deferral, and settlement features to receive 100% equity treatment as defined in Fitchs Corporate Hybrids Treatment and Notching Criteria.

The IAM union strike continues prolonging the re-establishment of operational momentum. A labor resolution is a necessary first step to restart production of the companys flagship 737MAX aircraft. The equity offering enhances financial flexibility and moderates the credit impact of strike-related delays. The improvement in the most recent voting outcome, albeit short of ratification, suggests contract terms are approaching acceptability for at least the majority of union members.

Fitchs post-strike focus remains on Boeings ability to achieve key commercial aircraft operational milestones to facilitate cash flow generation and enhance deleveraging capacity. These

milestones: https://pro.fitchratings.com/research/article/PR_10286885[https://pro.fitchratings.com/research/article/PR_10286885]

include re-establishing 737MAX production momentum, receiving 737MAX-7/-10 and 777X certification approvals, liquidating legacy aircraft inventory, and integrating Spirit AeroSystems. Boeing Commercial Airplanes reported backlog was 5,410 aircraft, including 4,151 737 aircraft, as of Sept. 30, 2024.

Contacts:

Document FITRA00020241028ekas001rx


Fitch Ratings: Boeings Actions Support Liquidity Amidst Continued Operational Challenges
1734 words
15 October 2024
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-Chicago/New York/Toronto-15 October 2024: The Boeing Company (BBB-/Negative Outlook) announcements today increase financial flexibility and moderate near-term liquidity concerns amidst an extended strike and continued operational challenges, says Fitch Ratings. Fitch continues to evaluate the companys ability to adhere to our negative rating sensitivity of decreasing gross debt below $50 billion and EBITDA leverage below 4x by year-end 2026.

Managements willingness and ability to access non-debt capital sources over the coming months will help alleviate downgrade risks by supporting repayment of 2025-26 maturities and increasing financial flexibility. The $25 billion S-3 shelf registration filing today accommodates broader market access, including the issuance of equity. The establishment of the up to $10 billion 364-day facility provides a short-term liquidity buffer and we expect any draws to be temporary. Boeing reported cash and equivalents of approximately $10.5 billion as of Sept. 30, 2024.

An enhanced liquidity position helps offset operational execution risks as management navigates the labor strike and works toward re-establishing post-strike momentum, receiving certification approvals, normalizing operations, and integrating Spirit AeroSystems into 2026. Fitch believes managements announcement to winddown the 767 program helps heighten operational focus. The announced organizational actions should improve operational efficiency and provide considerable cost savings.

Boeing Operational Milestones Table[https://e.infogram.com/b0c99872-340d-41ab-b69b-5759388cbd7b?src=embed]

Boeings September delivery of 33 commercial aircraft, including 27 737MAXs, incrementally supports liquidity and decreases legacy inventory. Continued production progress of the 787 aircraft, which is not affected by the strike, also provides some cash flows and operational continuity. The company received 65 gross orders, including 54 737MAXs and 11 777s, in September suggesting continued commercial interest and backlog strength.

Fitchs forecast currently assumes the shadow factory is closed and 737MAX production of 38 per month is achieved in late 1Q25/early 2Q25. This would allow management to focus on the completion and integration of the Spirit AeroSystems acquisition. Positive working capital reduction and cost savings are projected to contribute to low/mid-single digit billions of FCF in 2025. Fitch forecasts FCF of mid/high-single digit billions, gross debt below $50 billion, and EBITDA leverage under 4x in 2026.

Contacts:

Dino Kritikos

Managing Director, Corporates

+1 312 368 3150

dino.kritikos@fitchratings.com

Hearst Tower

300 W. 57th Street

New York, NY 10019

The individuals are named for contact purposes only. Ratings may be changed or withdrawn at any time for any reason in the sole discretion of Fitch. Fitch does not provide investment advice of any sort. Ratings are not a recommendation to buy, sell, or hold any security. Ratings do not comment on the adequacy of market price, the suitability of any security for a particular investor, or the tax-exempt nature or taxability of payments made in respect to any security. Fitch receives fees from issuers, insurers, guarantors, other obligors, and underwriters for rating securities. Such fees generally vary from US$1,000 to US$750,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent) per issue. In certain cases, Fitch will rate all or a number of issues issued by a particular issuer, or insured or guaranteed by a particular insurer or guarantor, for a single annual fee. Such fees are expected to vary from US$10,000 to US$1,500,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent). Due to the relative efficiency of electronic publishing and distribution, Fitch research may be available to electronic subscribers up to three days earlier than to print subscribers.

Credit ratings information published by Fitch is not intended to be used by persons who are retail clients within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001.

While certain of the NRSRO's credit rating subsidiaries are listed on Item 3 of Form NRSRO and as such are authorized to issue credit ratings on behalf of the NRSRO (see https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory]), other credit rating subsidiaries are not listed on Form NRSRO (the 'non-NRSROs') and therefore credit ratings issued by those subsidiaries are not issued on behalf of the NRSRO. However, non-NRSRO personnel may participate in determining credit ratings issued by or on behalf of the NRSRO.

Document FITRA00020241015ekaf003ml


Fitch Ratings: Prolonged Boeing Strike Could Pose Downgrade Risk
1828 words
13 September 2024
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-Chicago/New York-13 September 2024: The Boeing Companys investment-grade credit rating has limited headroom for a strike, according to Fitch Ratings. If the current strike lasts a week or two, it is unlikely to pressure the rating. However, an extended strike could have a meaningful operational and financial impact, increasing the risk of a downgrade.

Management would likely need to access new liquidity sources in an extended strike scenario to adhere to its cash targets and remain within Fitchs negative rating sensitivity, including decreasing gross debt below $50 billion and EBITDA leverage below 4x by year-end 2026.

Although the current labor negotiations create near-term uncertainty, we believe management understands the importance of reaching a timely agreement that supports the maintenance of its current investment-grade ratings. Our ratings case forecasts do not assume an operationally disruptive labor action but do account for union-linked labor cost increases under new contracts. These incremental costs suggest the potential for a mutually beneficial agreement. Labor costs per 737MAX are about 15% of each aircraft, with union labor costs accounting for around one-third, or roughly 5% of total aircraft costs.

If the strike is prolonged, we will assess managements willingness and ability to preserve and enhance its liquidity position. Boeings Negative Rating Outlook also reflects the operational and certification risks to achieving run-rate production during 2026-2027. This includes elimination of legacy inventory, certification of the 737MAX-7, 737MAX-10 and 777X aircraft, stabilization of and increases in aircraft production rates, and navigation of seasonal cash flow volatility. These steps should enhance longer-term operations and help fulfill Boeings commitment to repay debt and return to investment-grade metrics.

Boeings BBB- rating incorporates 737MAX production increasing towards mid-30 per month by year-end and liquidation of approximately half of the companys pre-2023 built 737MAX inventory during 2024. The company has been taking steps to achieve a 737MAX production rate of 38 aircraft per month in 4Q24. Deliveries from inventory were also on track to allow closure of its shadow factories around year-end. The achievement of these milestones will be important in establishing the operational efficiency and momentum to support production growth, as well as margin expansion and positive free cash flow realization.

Boeings last strike in 2008 lasted 57 days with a 52-day production shutdown that necessitated 4-6 weeks to return production to pre-strike levels. A strike of similar length and operational impact would materially hinder operational momentum and pressure liquidity. This could result in a negative rating action without the addition of new liquidity in a credit-conscious manner.

Contacts:

Dino Kritikos

Managing Director, Corporates

+1 312 368 3150

dino.kritikos@fitchratings.com: https://mailto:dino.kritikos@fitchratings.com[https://mailto:dino.kritikos@fitchratings.com]

Fitch Ratings, Inc.

Hearst Tower

300 W. 57th Street

New York, NY 10019

+1 646 582 4577

ashley.rogers@fitchratings.com: https://mailto:ashley.rogers@fitchratings.com[https://mailto:ashley.rogers@fitchratings.com]

Senior Director, Fitch Wire

Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed. Document FITRA00020240913ek9d0035x


Fitch Ratings: Boeing's Ratings Unaffected by Spirit Aerosystems Acquisition
1637 words
1 July 2024
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-01 July 2024: The Boeing Company's (BBB-/Negative Outlook) announcement of an all-stock offer to purchase Spirit Aerosystems has no near-term rating impact, according to Fitch Ratings. Fitch believes the transaction will be operationally beneficial to Boeing, as it will allow the company to better plan and control the pacing of future 737 MAX production.

The all-stock funding decision is favorable compared to Fitch's prior expectation and limits the need for additional debt, while retaining financial flexibility during a period of heighted operational execution risk. Fitch expects most known quality control issues with the 737MAX to be evaluated and resolved before the acquisition closes.

The transaction announcement does not materially affect Fitch's 2024 or 2025 production or delivery expectations. However, a lower debt burden should free up incremental FCF for debt repayment. Fitch forecasts between 350-370 737MAX deliveries and about 65-70 787 deliveries in 2024. The agency also forecasts Boeing's 737MAX production rate in the low-30s by the end of 2024 and mid-30s by early 2025, as well as around three 787s per month during 2024, before returning to five per month in 2025. Fitch projects Boeings FCF will be modestly negative in 2024, but will return to low-single digit positive billions in 2025 and mid-single digit billions in 2026.

The Negative Outlook reflects Boeing's heightened execution risks over the next 12 to 24 months as it eliminates legacy inventory, stabilizes and increases aircraft production rates, navigates seasonal cash flow volatility, pursues additional corporate actions that should enhance longer-term operations and fulfills its commitment to repay debt and return to IG metrics.

Fitch could revise the Outlook if Boeing liquidates over 100 of its pre-2023 built 737 MAX and half of its 787 inventories by early 2025 and 737 MAX production increases toward 38 per month. Fitch believes these actions would alleviate operational strain and enable management to focus on the Spirit Aerosystems integration. These improvements will also provide a path towards operational normalization and production optimization, facilitating FCF acceleration, debt repayment and return to an IG financial profile.

Contact:

Nicholas Varone

Senior Director

+1 212 908 0349

Nicholas.Varone@fitchratings.com: https://mailto:Nicholas.Varone@fitchratings.com[https://mailto:Nicholas.Varone@fitchratings.com]

33 Whitehall St.

Document FITRA00020240701ek71001b9


Fitch Ratings Lowers Boeing Aircraft Delivery Forecasts
1739 words
31 May 2024
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-31 May 2024: Fitch Ratings has lowered its 2024 forecasts for The Boeing Companys aircraft deliveries and FCF due to recent developments. Fitch does not currently expect these adjustments to result in rating changes. However, we will continue to assess the companys operational progress toward material aircraft inventory liquidation and 737MAX production above 30 per month. Failure to achieve a clear path to these milestones by mid-2025 remains our key downgrade trigger.

Fitch forecasts between 350-370 737MAX deliveries and about 65-70 787 deliveries in 2024, below previous expectations of about 400 and 75, respectively. Fitch also expects modestly negative FCF during 2024, compared to previous breakeven-to-positive. These changes are incorporated in Boeings BBB- Long-term Issuer Default Rating and Negative Rating Outlook.

The delivery forecasts were affected by the Civil Aviation Administration of Chinas (CAAC) decision to restrict certain aircraft model deliveries to Chinese customers while it requests additional documentation regarding voice recorder and battery information. Fitch believes the CAACs restriction of deliveries could be resolved by mid-Q3 but would still result in at least 20-30 fewer 737MAX deliveries out of inventory and five fewer 787 deliveries out of inventory during 2024.

Fitchs forecast adjustments also reflect the Federal Aviation Administrations decision to maintain oversight within Boeings factories while individually certifying newly produced aircraft. The FAA maintaining oversight was generally an expected outcome, though comments from the head of the FAA, Mike Whitaker, indicated that oversight will continue for at least the next few months. While this scrutiny by the FAA is a near-term negative, Fitch believes it should support operational quality and normalization once the oversight starts tapering off. Fitch currently believes this will gradually begin during the end of 3Q24.

These changes do not alter Fitchs view that Boeing could reach a 737MAX production rate in the low-30s by the end of 2024 and mid-30s by early 2025, but could affect the rate of increase during the upcoming summer months. Fitch projects Boeings path to produce 38 737MAXs per month and liquidate inventoried aircraft will be uneven over the next nine to 12 months. Fitch is unlikely to revise Boeings Outlook back to Stable until the company makes progress toward completing these objectives. We have therefore reduced our production expectations for the remainder of 2024 and delayed the pace of increase above 38 per month until late-2025.

Fitch also considered the ongoing 787 investigation in our analysis. We primarily focused on the impact on production rather than the potential future fines due to the uncertainty around hypothetical amounts and payment timing. We currently expect the company to produce closer to three 787s per month during 2024, before returning to five per month in 2025.

Contact:

Nicholas Varone

Senior Director

+1 212-908-0349

Nicholas.Varone@fitchratings.com

33 Whitehall St.

New York, NY 10004

For Australia, New Zealand, Taiwan and South Korea only: Fitch Australia Pty Ltd holds an Australian financial services license (AFS license no. 337123) which authorizes it to provide credit ratings to wholesale clients only. Credit ratings information published by Fitch is not intended to be used by persons who are retail clients within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001.

Fitch Ratings, Inc. is registered with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission as a Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organization (the 'NRSRO'). While certain of the NRSRO's credit rating subsidiaries are listed on Item 3 of Form NRSRO and as such are authorized to issue credit ratings on behalf of the NRSRO (see https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory]), other credit rating subsidiaries are not listed on Form NRSRO (the 'non-NRSROs') and therefore credit ratings issued by those subsidiaries are not issued on behalf of the NRSRO. However, non-NRSRO personnel may participate in determining credit ratings issued by or on behalf of the NRSRO.

Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings, Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries. 33 Whitehall Street, NY, NY 10004. Telephone: 1-800-753-4824, (212) 908-0500. Reproduction or retransmission in whole or in part is prohibited except by permission. All rights reserved.

Fitch Solutions Group Limited

Document FITRA00020240605ek5v00ew6


Fitch Assigns Boeing's New Notes 'BBB-'
3539 words
29 April 2024
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-29 April 2024: Fitch Ratings has assigned 'BBB-' ratings to The Boeing Company's (Boeing) new senior unsecured notes, which will be used to fund general corporate purposes. Fitch has also revised Boeing's Rating Outlook to Negative on April 26, 2024, while also affirming its 'BBB-' long-term ratings and 'F3' short-term ratings.

The Negative Outlook reflects Boeing's heightened execution risks over the next 12 months to 24 months as it eliminates legacy inventory, stabilizes and increases aircraft production rates, navigates seasonal cash flow volatility, pursues additional corporate actions that should enhance longer-term operations and fulfills its commitment to repay debt and return to IG metrics.

Fitch could stabilize the Outlook if Boeing liquidates over 100 of its pre-2023 built 737MAX and half of its 787 inventories by early 2025 and 737MAX production increases toward 38 per month. Fitch believes these actions would alleviate operational strain and enable management to focus on the potential Spirit Aerosystems integration in 1H25. These improvements will also provide a path towards operational normalization and production optimization, facilitating FCF acceleration, debt repayment and return to an IG financial profile.

Boeing's 'BBB-' rating is supported by a $529 billion backlog (up about 30% during 2023), which provides several years of revenue visibility. The company is one of two major global aircraft manufacturers with substantial diversification to differentiate it from its largest competitor, particularly given its large defense and services businesses. Fitch projects the company will continue to generate positive annual FCF throughout its rating case with potential to approach double digit billions by the end of 2027 as operations normalize and operating margins improve.

Key Rating Drivers

Debt Issuance Extends Elevated Leverage: Fitch expects Boeing's new debt will help de-risk 2025 liquidity needs and restore cash balances around $10 billion, while staying ahead of liquidity needs over the next 12 months. The use of proceeds will provide a cushion against expected annual Q1 FCF seasonality ahead of upcoming maturities.

Fitch expects near-term leverage will remain well outside of its 4.0x negative sensitivity in 2024 and 2025 but will return inside by approximately YE 2026 before further declining below 3.0x by YE 2027 as a result of a combination of gross debt repayment over the three-year period and production- and efficiency-linked operating margin improvements. Fitch believes a potential all-debt-funded acquisition of Spirit is captured within the Negative Outlook and that the debt issuance provides incremental financial flexibility during a period of heightened operational execution risk.

Fitch believes the near-term financial pressures from incremental debt and expected capital investment will be mostly offset by the near-term focus on inventory reduction and production optimization and longer-term synergies if Boeing takes control of Spirit. The fuselages that Spirit produces effectively set the pace of Boeing's production line, and having greater control and visibility into timing and quality of the input will better allow Boeing to stabilize and normalize production rates, and plan for future increases. Since the transaction is not likely to close sooner than six to nine months after a potential announcement, Fitch expects the majority of the known quality control concerns related to the 737MAX will be in the process of being evaluated and alleviated.

Operational Challenges Temper FCF: Investment and working capital fluctuations, coupled with heightened execution risks around 2024-25 operational objectives, will likely result in weaker 2024 and 2025 FCF than Fitch previously expected. However, forecasted positive margin trends in the Boeing Commercial Airplanes (BCA) segment will accelerate FCF and deleveraging capacity heading into 2026, little changed from Fitch's March 2024 review. Boeing's FCF should then approach the double-digit billion-dollar level after the company liquidates its remaining aircraft inventory and shuts down its shadow factories, which Fitch currently projects to be largely completed by YE 2025, subject to MAX-7 and MAX-10 certification.

FAA Investigation Disruptive but Manageable: The FAA recently completed a quality control audit of Boeing's production processes following the January 2024 incident involving an Alaska Airlines flight. The investigation resulted in greater operational disruption and slower 737MAX production than Fitch previously anticipated during the first few months of 2024. Boeing has until late-May 2024 to develop a plan to address the various concerns and failures highlighted by the FAA, during which time Fitch believes Boeing will continue to operate at a slower production pace in line with early 2024 levels.

Aircraft Deliveries Update: Fitch forecasts around low-400s 737MAX deliveries in 2024 and expects the production rate to remain constrained below 20 per month for 1H, steadily rising towards the mid-30s by the end of the year. We further forecast the company will liquidate slightly more than half of its approximately 200 737MAX aircraft in inventory by YE 2024. We also forecast around 75 787 aircraft deliveries during the year, with low- to mid-single-digit production per month and liquidation of around 30 out of 60 787 aircraft in inventory.

$520+ Billion Backlog Provides Visibility: Fitch considers Boeing's multi-year and growing backlog to be one of the key positive considerations when evaluating the company's business profile. As of December 2023, Boeing had a total backlog of over $520 billion, approximately $120 billion higher than the previous year. Fitch estimates the commercial airplanes backlog of $440 billion represents greater than seven years of revenue at Fitch-projected 2025-2026 production levels.

Defense and Services Bolsters Diversification: Fitch views the Boeing Defense, Space & Security (BDS) and Boeing Global Services (BGS) segments as net positives for the company due to the high degree of diversification provided by contract, program and capability. Independently, BDS would represent a top-five global defense contractor, by revenue. The segment also operates in a variety of high priority areas such as space, drones and aircraft, which should remain key focus areas for the U.S. government over the next several years. Meanwhile, BGS provides steady margins and cash flows in addition to stability from aftermarket sales.

Derivation Summary

Boeing is rated three notches below its most immediate peer, Airbus SE (A-/F1/Stable). This is largely the result of Boeing's execution challenges in the past several years, which have combined to weaken its quantitative rating factors compared with Airbus. Cash flow generation is one of the key differentiators between Airbus and Boeing. In the past, Boeing consistently achieved significantly better FCF and funds from operations due to program execution and lower investment needs despite higher dividend payments. However, the 737MAX grounding and subsequent disruptions severely affected Boeing's cash flow and caused debt to rise significantly versus Airbus's.

Boeing's business profile has also been modestly stronger than Airbus's because of a more diverse revenue mix between commercial and defense, in addition to services. Airbus currently has a stronger balance sheet, though Boeing plans to use nearly all excess cash to repay debt. Airbus generally operates with a net cash position, though both companies have significant financial flexibility. Foreign exchange exposure is also a key differentiator between Boeing and Airbus, with the former having little exposure and the latter has significant exposure, although Airbus has taken modest actions to address this.

Key Assumptions

--Debt: Boeing issues new debt to, bolster financial flexibility and de-risk liquidity and refinance needs ahead of expected seasonal cash outflows in early-2025;

--Revenue/FCF: Overall revenue up low-single-digits in 2024, double-digits in 2025, 2026 and 2027; FCF breakeven-to-positive in 2024, low-single digit billions in 2025 and high single-digits in 2026 and 2027;

--Production rates: 737MAX production rate remains constrained during at least the first half of 2024, steadily increasing towards mid-30 per month by YE; 787 production rate in the low-to-mid single-digits throughout 2024, mid-single digits in 2025;

--Deliveries: low-400s 737MAX during 2024, increasing to mid-500s in 2025; 787 deliveries around 75 in 2024, 100 in 2025, and above 100 in 2026;

--Aircraft Inventory: approximately half of 737MAX inventory and 787 inventory is liquidated during 2024, with nearly all of the remaining liquidated in 2025; some inventory deliveries could be pushed to 2026 related to MAX-7 and MAX-10 certification timing and uncertainty;

--BDS/BGS Revenues: BDS segment revenue up by low single-digits annually over the next few years; BGS segment revenue increases in the mid-to-high single-digit range annually through 2026-2027;

--BCA operating margins: Negative in 2024, moving to breakeven or slightly positive in 2025 and steadily increasing through 2027;

--BDS operating margins: Around breakeven in 2024, moving slightly positive in 2025;

--Pension contributions: Remain around $800 million to $1 billion per year throughout the forecasted period;

--Working capital: Annual source of cash throughout the forecast; between 2024 and 2026, this is a result of 737MAX and 787 liquidations; in 2027 and 2028, Fitch assumes a liquidation of LRIP-built 777X as production increases;

--R&D expense: Fluctuates around 4% of total sales throughout the forecasted period; capex remains around 2% of total sales.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to a Stable Outlook

--Demonstrated progress towards liquidating 737MAX inventory to facilitate the closure of its shadow factories;

--Achievement of 38/month run-rate 737MAX production and alleviation of FAA concerns and failures;

--Progress towards operational improvement and integration of potential corporate actions that could enhance longer-term operations;

--Forecasted gross debt below $50B and EBITDA leverage below 4x by YE 2026.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade

--Continued progress towards operational normalization via reduced inventory and increased production;

--Demonstrated commitment to gross debt reduction leading to total debt to EBITDA leverage at 3.0x or lower;

--Sustained FCF margins at 3% or above.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade

--Material negative developments with any of the company's major programs leading to delivery delays, order cancellations, large additional costs or inventory write-downs, which contribute to sustained FCF margins below 2%;

--Operational missteps and/or debt-funded acquisitions or share repurchases lead to sustained total debt to EBITDA leverage above 4x;

--Indications of materially higher business risk from regulatory challenges, fines, litigation, or reputation and brand damage.

Liquidity and Debt Structure

Fitch views Boeing's liquidity as sufficient compared to other capital intensive 'BBB' category companies, to-be-bolstered by the expected debt-issuance related to the Spirit transaction. Fitch forecasts Boeing will maintain full revolver availability and aim to sustain greater than $10 billion of cash over the next few years. We do not expect the company to draw on its revolver, though it could reduce total capacity as operations improve heading into 2026-2027.

We currently expect this will be adequate to cover significant capital requirements and project that FCF will improve toward the high single-digit billion-dollar range in 2026-2027. Boeing's debt structure is predominantly comprised of senior unsecured notes, revolvers and CP availability. The company has several maturities due over the next 27 months, totaling more than $12 billion.

Issuer Profile

The Boeing Company is the world's largest aerospace & defense firm, and one of two major large commercial aircraft manufacturers, globally. The company operates in three principal segments: BDS; Boeing Commercial Aircraft; and BGSs.

Summary of Financial Adjustments

Fitch made standard analytical adjustments regarding non-recurring, one-time or forward charges.

Date of Relevant Committee

26 April 2024

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

ESG Considerations

The Boeing Company has an ESG relevance score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737MAX production challenges, which has a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. Below average execution on the 737MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs, lower cash flows, and elevated leverage.

The highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3', unless otherwise disclosed in this section. A score of '3' means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores are not inputs in the rating process; they are an observation on the relevance and materiality of ESG factors in the rating decision. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores[https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores].

The Boeing Company

----senior unsecured; Long Term Rating; New Rating; BBB-

Fitch conducts a reasonable investigation of the factual information relied upon by it in accordance with its ratings methodology, and obtains reasonable verification of that information from independent sources, to the extent such sources are available for a given security or in a given jurisdiction. The manner of Fitchs factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitchs ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed.

A Fitch rating is an opinion as to the creditworthiness of a security. This opinion and reports made by Fitch are based on established criteria and methodologies that Fitch is continuously evaluating and updating. Therefore, ratings and reports are the collective work product of Fitch and no individual, or group of individuals, is solely responsible for a rating or a report. All Fitch reports have shared authorship. Individuals identified in a Fitch report were involved in, but are not solely responsible for, the opinions stated therein. The individuals are named for contact purposes only. A report providing a Fitch rating is neither a prospectus nor a substitute for the information assembled, verified and presented to investors by the issuer and its agents in connection with the sale of the securities. Ratings may be changed or withdrawn at any time for any reason in the sole discretion of Fitch. Fitch does not provide investment advice of any sort. Ratings are not a recommendation to buy, sell, or hold any security. Ratings do not comment on the adequacy of market price, the suitability of any security for a particular investor, or the tax-exempt nature or taxability of payments made in respect to any security. Fitch receives fees from issuers, insurers, guarantors, other obligors, and underwriters for rating securities. Such fees generally vary from US$1,000 to US$750,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent) per issue. In certain cases, Fitch will rate all or a number of issues issued by a particular issuer, or insured or guaranteed by a particular insurer or guarantor, for a single annual fee. Such fees are expected to vary from US$10,000 to US$1,500,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent). Fitch Solutions Group Limited

Document FITRA00020240429ek4t002p9


Fitch Revises Boeing's Outlook to Negative
3654 words
26 April 2024
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-26 April 2024: Fitch Ratings has revised The Boeing Company's Rating Outlook to Negative from Stable. This action follows Boeing's comments around restoring its cash balance to $10 billion and staying ahead of maturities and liquidity needs over the next 12 months. The Outlook incorporates Fitch's expectation that Boeing could issue new debt to de-risk early-2025 cash flow risks and bolster financial flexibility as the company works through operational milestones.

Fitch has affirmed Boeing's 'BBB-' Long-term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) and 'F3' Short-term IDR. Fitch has also affirmed the company's long-term unsecured notes and revolvers at 'BBB-' and CP program at 'F3'.

The Negative Outlook reflects Boeing's heightened execution risks over the next 12 to 24 months as it eliminates legacy inventory, stabilizes and increases aircraft production rates, navigates seasonal cash flow volatility, pursues additional corporate actions that should enhance longer-term operations and fulfills its commitment to repay debt and return to IG metrics.

Fitch could stabilize the Outlook if Boeing liquidates over 100 of its pre-2023 built 737 MAX and half of its 787 inventories by early 2025 and 737 MAX production increases toward 38 per month. Fitch believes these actions would alleviate operational strain and enable management to focus on the potential Spirit Aerosystems integration in 1H25. These improvements will also provide a path towards operational normalization and production optimization, facilitating FCF acceleration, debt repayment and return to an IG financial profile.

Boeing's 'BBB-' rating is supported by a $529 billion backlog (up about 30% during 2023), which provides several years of revenue visibility. The company is one of two major global aircraft manufacturers with substantial diversification to differentiate it from its largest competitor, particularly given its large defense and services businesses. Fitch projects the company will continue to generate positive annual FCF throughout its rating case with potential to approach double digit billions by the end of 2027 as operations normalize and operating margins improve.

Key Rating Drivers

Debt Issuance Extends Elevated Leverage: Fitch expects Boeing could issue new debt to de-risk 2025 liquidity needs based on the company's comments around restoring cash balances around $10 billion and staying ahead of liquidity needs over the next 12 months. The use of proceeds would be to provide a cushion against expected annual Q1 FCF seasonality ahead of upcoming maturities. Fitch expects near-term leverage will remain well outside of its 4.0x negative sensitivity in 2024 and 2025 but will return inside by approximately YE 2026 before further declining below 3.0x by YE 2027 as a result of a combination of gross debt repayment over the two-year period and production- and efficiency-linked operating margin improvements. Fitch believes a potential all-debt-funded acquisition of Spirit is captured within the Negative Outlook and that the debt issuance provides incremental financial flexibility during a period of heightened operational execution risk.

Fitch believes the near-term financial pressures from incremental debt and expected capital investment will be mostly offset by the near-term focus on inventory reduction and production optimization and longer-term synergies if Boeing takes control of Spirit. The fuselages that Spirit produces effectively set the pace of Boeing's production line, and having greater control and visibility into timing and quality of the input will better allow Boeing to stabilize and normalize production rates, and plan for future increases. Since the transaction is not likely to close sooner than six to nine months after a potential announcement, Fitch expects the majority of the known quality control concerns related to the 737MAX will be in the process of being evaluated and alleviated.

Operational Challenges Temper FCF: Investment and working capital fluctuations, coupled with heightened execution risks around 2024-25 operational objectives, will likely result in weaker 2024 and 2025 FCF than Fitch previously expected. However, forecasted positive margin trends in the Boeing Commercial Airplanes (BCA) segment will accelerate FCF and deleveraging capacity heading into 2026, little changed from Fitch's March 2024 review. Boeing's FCF should then approach the double digit billion-dollar level after the company liquidates its remaining aircraft inventory and shuts down its shadow factories, which Fitch currently projects to be largely completed by YE 2025, subject to MAX-7 and -10 certification.

FAA Investigation Disruptive but Manageable: The FAA recently completed a quality control audit of Boeing's production processes following the January 2024 incident involving an Alaska Airlines flight. The investigation resulted in greater operational disruption and slower 737MAX production than Fitch previously anticipated during the first few months of 2024. Boeing has until late-May 2024 to develop a plan to address the various concerns and failures highlighted by the FAA, during which time Fitch believes Boeing will continue to operate at a slower production pace in line with early 2024 levels.

Aircraft Deliveries Update: Fitch forecasts around low-400s 737MAX deliveries in 2024 and expects the production rate to remain constrained below 20 per month for 1H, steadily rising towards the mid-30s by the end of the year. We further forecast the company will liquidate slightly more than half of its approximately 200 737 MAX aircraft in inventory by YE 2024. We also forecast around 75 787 aircraft deliveries during the year, with low-to-mid single digit production per month and liquidation of around 30 out of 60 787 aircraft in inventory.

$520+ Billion Backlog Provides Visibility: Fitch considers Boeing's multi-year and growing backlog to be one of the key positive considerations when evaluating the company's business profile. As of December 2023, Boeing had a total backlog of over $520 billion, approximately $120 billion higher than the previous year. Fitch estimates the commercial airplanes backlog of $440 billion represents greater than seven years of revenue at Fitch-projected 2025-2026 production levels.

Defense and Services Bolsters Diversification: Fitch views the Boeing Defense, Space & Security (BDS) and Boeing Global Services (BGS) segments as net positives for the company due to the high degree of diversification provided by contract, program and capability. Independently, BDS would represent a top-five global defense contractor, by revenue. The segment also operates in a variety of high priority areas such as space, drones and aircraft, which should remain key focus areas for the U.S. government over the next several years. Meanwhile, BGS provides steady margins and cash flows in addition to stability from aftermarket sales.

Derivation Summary

Boeing is rated three notches below its most immediate peer, Airbus SE (A-/F1/Stable). This is largely the result of Boeing's execution challenges in the past several years, which have combined to weaken its quantitative rating factors compared with Airbus. Cash flow generation is one of the key differentiators between Airbus and Boeing. In the past, Boeing consistently achieved significantly better FCF and funds from operations due to program execution and lower investment needs despite higher dividend payments. However, the 737MAX grounding and subsequent disruptions severely affected Boeing's cash flow and caused debt to rise significantly versus Airbus's.

Boeing's business profile has also been modestly stronger than Airbus's because of a more diverse revenue mix between commercial and defense, in addition to services. Airbus currently has a stronger balance sheet, though Boeing plans to use nearly all excess cash to repay debt. Airbus generally operates with a net cash position, though both companies have significant financial flexibility. Foreign exchange exposure is also a key differentiator between Boeing and Airbus, with the former having little exposure and the latter has significant exposure, although Airbus has taken modest actions to address this.

Key Assumptions

--Debt: Boeing issues new debt to, bolster financial flexibility and de-risk liquidity and refinance needs ahead of expected seasonal cash outflows in early-2025;

--Revenue/FCF: Overall revenue up low-single-digits in 2024, double-digits in 2025, 2026 and 2027; FCF breakeven-to-positive in 2024, low-single digit billions in 2025 and high single-digits in 2026 and 2027;

--Production rates: 737MAX production rate remains constrained during at least the first half of 2024, steadily increasing towards mid-30 per month by year-end; 787 production rate in the low-to-mid single-digits throughout 2024, mid-single digits in 2025;

--Deliveries: low-400s 737MAX during 2024, increasing to mid-500s in 2025; 787 deliveries around 75 in 2024, 100 in 2025, and above 100 in 2026;

--Aircraft Inventory: approximately half of 737MAX inventory and 787 inventory is liquidated during 2024, with nearly all of the remaining liquidated in 2025; some inventory deliveries could be pushed to 2026 related to MAX-7 and -10 certification timing and uncertainty;

--BDS/BGS Revenues: BDS segment revenue up by low single-digits annually over the next few years; BGS segment revenue increases in the mid-to-high single-digit range annually through 2026-2027;

--BCA operating margins: Negative in 2024, moving to breakeven or slightly positive in 2025 and steadily increasing through 2027;

--BDS operating margins: Around breakeven in 2024, moving slightly positive in 2025;

--Pension contributions: Remain around $800 million to $1 billion per year throughout the forecasted period;

--Working capital: Annual source of cash throughout the forecast; between 2024 and 2026, this is a result of 737 MAX and 787 liquidations; in 2027 and 2028, Fitch assumes a liquidation of LRIP-built 777X as production increases;

--R&D expense: Fluctuates around 4% of total sales throughout the forecasted period; capex remains around 2% of total sales.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to a Stable Outlook

--Demonstrated progress towards liquidating 737MAX inventory to facilitate the closure of its shadow factories;

--Achievement of 38/month run-rate 737MAX production and alleviation of FAA concerns and failures;

--Progress towards operational improvement and integration of potential corporate actions that could enhance longer-term operations;

--Forecasted gross debt below $50B and EBITDA leverage below 4x by YE 2026.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade

--Continued progress towards operational normalization via reduced inventory and increased production;

--Demonstrated commitment to gross debt reduction leading to total debt to EBITDA leverage at 3.0x or lower;

--Sustained FCF margins at 3% or above.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade

--Material negative developments with any of the company's major programs leading to delivery delays, order cancellations, large additional costs or inventory write-downs, which contribute to sustained FCF margins below 2%;

--Operational missteps and/or debt-funded acquisitions or share repurchases lead to sustained total debt to EBITDA leverage above 4x;

--Indications of materially higher business risk from regulatory challenges, fines, litigation, or reputation and brand damage.

Liquidity and Debt Structure

Fitch views Boeing's liquidity as sufficient compared to other capital intensive 'BBB' category companies, to-be-bolstered by the expected debt-issuance related to the Spirit transaction. Fitch forecasts Boeing will maintain full revolver availability and aim to sustain greater than $10 billion of cash over the next few years. We do not expect the company to draw on its revolver, though it could reduce total capacity as operations improve heading into 2026-2027.

We currently expect this will be adequate to cover significant capital requirements and project that FCF will improve toward the high single-digit billion-dollar range in 2026-2027. Boeing's debt structure is predominantly comprised of senior unsecured notes, revolvers and CP availability. The company has several maturities due over the next 27 months, totaling more than $12 billion.

Issuer Profile

The Boeing Company is the world's largest aerospace & defense firm, and one of two major large commercial aircraft manufacturers, globally. The company operates in three principal segments: Boeing Defense, Space & Security; Boeing Commercial Aircraft; and Boeing Global Services.

Summary of Financial Adjustments

Fitch made certain analytical adjustments to add-back one-time charges related to various defense programs, the 787 aircraft and 737 MAX aircraft.

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

ESG Considerations

The Boeing Company has an ESG relevance score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737 MAX production challenges, which has a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. Below average execution on the 737 MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs, lower cash flows, and elevated leverage.

The highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3', unless otherwise disclosed in this section. A score of '3' means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores are not inputs in the rating process; they are an observation on the relevance and materiality of ESG factors in the rating decision. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores[https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores].

The Boeing Company; Long Term Issuer Default Rating; Affirmed; BBB-; Rating Outlook Negative

; Short Term Issuer Default Rating; Affirmed; F3

----senior unsecured; Short Term Rating; Affirmed; F3
