In issuing and maintaining its ratings and in making other reports (including forecast information), Fitch relies on factual information it receives from issuers and underwriters and from other sources Fitch believes to be credible. Fitch conducts a reasonable investigation of the factual information relied upon by it in accordance with its ratings methodology, and obtains reasonable verification of that information from independent sources, to the extent such sources are available for a given security or in a given jurisdiction. The manner of Fitchs factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitchs ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed.

The information in this report is provided as is without any representation or warranty of any kind, and Fitch does not represent or warrant that the report or any of its contents will meet any of the requirements of a recipient of the report. A Fitch rating is an opinion as to the creditworthiness of a security. This opinion and reports made by Fitch are based on established criteria and methodologies that Fitch is continuously evaluating and updating. Therefore, ratings and reports are the collective work product of Fitch and no individual, or group of individuals, is solely responsible for a rating or a report. The rating does not address the risk of loss due to risks other than credit risk, unless such risk is specifically mentioned. Fitch is not engaged in the offer or sale of any security. All Fitch reports have shared authorship. Individuals identified in a Fitch report were involved in, but are not solely responsible for, the opinions stated therein. The individuals are named for contact purposes only. A report providing a Fitch rating is neither a prospectus nor a substitute for the information assembled, verified and presented to investors by the issuer and its agents in connection with the sale of the securities. Ratings may be changed or withdrawn at any time for any reason in the sole discretion of Fitch. Fitch does not provide investment advice of any sort. Ratings are not a recommendation to buy, sell, or hold any security. Ratings do not comment on the adequacy of market price, the suitability of any security for a particular investor, or the tax-exempt nature or taxability of payments made in respect to any security. Fitch receives fees from issuers, insurers, guarantors, other obligors, and underwriters for rating securities. Such fees generally vary from US$1,000 to US$750,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent) per issue. In certain cases, Fitch will rate all or a number of issues issued by a particular issuer, or insured or guaranteed by a particular insurer or guarantor, for a single annual fee. Such fees are expected to vary from US$10,000 to US$1,500,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent). The assignment, publication, or dissemination of a rating by Fitch shall not constitute a consent by Fitch to use its name as an expert in connection with any registration statement filed under the United States securities laws, the Financial Services and Markets Act of 2000 of the United Kingdom, or the securities laws of any particular jurisdiction. Due to the relative efficiency of electronic publishing and distribution, Fitch research may be available to electronic subscribers up to three days earlier than to print subscribers.

For Australia, New Zealand, Taiwan and South Korea only: Fitch Australia Pty Ltd holds an Australian financial services license (AFS license no. 337123) which authorizes it to provide credit ratings to wholesale clients only. Credit ratings information published by Fitch is not intended to be used by persons who are retail clients within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001

Fitch Ratings, Inc. is registered with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission as a Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organization (the NRSRO). While certain of the NRSROs credit rating subsidiaries are listed on Item 3 of Form NRSRO and as such are authorized to issue credit ratings on behalf of the NRSRO (see

https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory]: https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory]

), other credit rating subsidiaries are not listed on Form NRSRO (the non-NRSROs) and therefore credit ratings issued by those subsidiaries are not issued on behalf of the NRSRO. However, non-NRSRO personnel may participate in determining credit ratings issued by or on behalf of the NRSRO.

Document FITRA00020240426ek4q004h5


Fitch Revises Boeing's Outlook to Stable
3235 words
15 March 2024
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-15 March 2024: Fitch Ratings has affirmed The Boeing Company's (Boeing, NYSE: BA) 'BBB-' Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) and 'F3' Short-Term IDR. Fitch has also affirmed the company's senior unsecured ratings at 'BBB-' and short-term CP ratings at 'F3'. The Rating Outlook was revised to Stable from Positive.

The Outlook revision reflects Fitch's view that Boeing's path to reach its positive triggers (including sub-3.0x leverage, high single digit billion FCF and greater than $15 billion of debt repayment) will likely be delayed by around 12 months from Fitch's prior expectations, to 2026 from 2025. This delay would mainly be due to unexpected operational disruptions and the potential for additional corporate actions that should enhance longer-term operations.

Fitch forecasts between 420-450 737MAX deliveries in 2024, approximately 100 lower than prior forecasts. We expect the production rate to remain constrained below 38 per month for the majority of 2024 and the company will liquidate approximately half of its inventory by year-end. Fitch forecasts Boeing's 2024 FCF will be in the low single-digit billion range, likely limiting near-term deleveraging capacity and leading to leverage above 3.0x until 2026.

Boeing's 'BBB-' rating and Stable Outlook continue to be supported by the company's over $520 billion backlog (up about 30% during 2023), which provides several years of revenue visibility. The company is one of two major global aircraft manufacturers with substantial diversification to differentiate it from its largest competitor, particularly given its large defense and services businesses. Additionally, Fitch projects the company will continue to generate positive FCF with potential to increase substantially approaching double digit billions as operations normalize and operating margins improve over the next few years.

Key Rating Drivers

FAA Investigation Disruptive, but Manageable: The FAA recently completed a quality control audit of Boeing's production processes following the January 2024 incident involving an Alaska Airlines flight. The investigation resulted in greater operational disruption and slower 737MAX production than Fitch previously anticipated during the first few months of 2024. Boeing has until late-May 2024 to develop a plan to address the various concerns and failures highlighted by the FAA, during which time Fitch believes Boeing will continue to operate at a slower production pace in line with early 2024 levels.

Low-Single Digit 2024 FCF Delays Deleveraging Plans: Fitch forecasts Boeing's FCF in the low single-digit billion-dollar range during 2024 and in the mid-to-high single digits in 2025 and 2026. Fitch believes the company will continue to be negatively impacted by slower aircraft inventory reduction in the near-term coupled with a near-term build-up of parts and components as the company aims to support the supply chain. Fitch projects negative operating margins for the commercial airplanes segment in 2024 due to an expected negative drag in 1Q24.

However, Fitch believes positive margin in the Boeing Commercial Airplanes (BCA) segment will accelerate FCF and deleveraging capacity heading into 2026. We anticipate near-term debt paydown will likely be limited to maturities as they become due in 2024 and 2025, until production rates stabilize and the company liquidates its aircraft inventory. Fitch's current rating case forecasts 2025 and 2026 EBITDA leverage of low-to-mid 4x and mid-to-high-2x, respectively.

$520+ Billion Backlog Provides Visibility: Fitch considers Boeing's multi-year and growing backlog to be one of the key positive considerations when evaluating the company's business profile. As of December 2023, Boeing had a total backlog of over $520 billion, approximately $120 billion higher than the previous year. Fitch estimates the commercial airplanes backlog of $440 billion represents greater than seven years of revenue at Fitch-projected 2025-2026 production levels.

Defense and Services Bolsters Diversification: Fitch views the Boeing Defense, Space & Security (BDS) and Boeing Global Services (BGS) segments as net positives for the company due to the high degree of diversification provided by contract, program and capability. Independently, BDS would represent a top-five global defense contractor, by revenue. The segment also operates in a variety of high priority areas such as space, drones and aircraft, which should remain key focus areas for the U.S. government over the next several years. Meanwhile, BGS provides steady margins and cash flows in addition to stability from aftermarket sales.

Derivation Summary

Boeing is rated three notches below its most immediate peer, Airbus SE (A-/F1/Stable). This is largely the result of Boeing's execution challenges in the past several years, which have combined to weaken its quantitative rating factors compared with Airbus. Cash flow generation is one of the key differentiators between Airbus and Boeing. In the past, Boeing consistently achieved significantly better FCF and funds from operations due to program execution and lower investment needs despite higher dividend payments. However, the 737MAX grounding and subsequent disruptions severely affected Boeing's cash flow and caused debt to rise significantly versus Airbus's.

Boeing's business profile has also been modestly stronger than Airbus's because of a more diverse revenue mix between commercial and defense, in addition to services. Airbus currently has a stronger balance sheet, though Boeing plans to use nearly all excess cash to repay debt. Airbus generally operates with a net cash position, though both companies have significant financial flexibility. Foreign exchange exposure is also a key differentiator between Boeing and Airbus, with the former having little exposure and the latter has significant exposure, although Airbus has taken modest actions to address this.

Key Assumptions

Fitch's Key Assumptions for the issuer include:

--Overall revenue up high-single-digits in 2024, double-digits in 2025 and 2026; FCF in the low-single digit billions in 2024, mid-single digit billions in 2025 and high single digits in 2026 and 2027;

--Production rates: 737MAX production rate remains constrained during at least the first half of 2024, steadily increasing towards 38 per month by year-end; 787 production rate in the mid-single digits throughout 2024;

--Deliveries: between 420-450 737MAX during 2024, increasing to mid-500s in 2025; 787 deliveries around 85-95 in 2024 and 2025, and above 100 in 2026;

--Aircraft Inventory: approximately half of 737MAX inventory and greater than half of 787 inventory is liquidated during 2024, with nearly all of the remaining liquidated in 2025, excluding approximately 35 737MAX pushed to 2026 related to MAX-7 and -10 certifications;

--Boeing Defense, Space & Security (BDS) segment revenue up by low-to-mid single-digits annually over the next few years; Boeing Global Services segment revenue increases in the mid-to-high single-digit range annually through 2026-2027;

--BCA operating margins negative mid-single digits in 2024, moving slightly positive in 2025 and steadily increasing through 2027;

--BDS operating margins around breakeven in 2024, moving slightly positive in 2025;

--All debt paydown in 2024-2025 coming from paying maturities as they come due; some flexibility to make voluntary debt reduction in 2026;

--Pension contributions remain around $1 billion per year throughout the forecasted period;

--Working capital is an annual source of cash through 2026;

--R&D expense fluctuates around 4% of total sales throughout the forecasted period; capex remains around 2% of total sales.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade:

--Continued progress towards operational normalization via reduced inventory and increased production;

--Demonstrated commitment to gross debt reduction leading to total debt to EBITDA leverage at 3.0x or lower;

--Sustained FCF margins at 3% or above.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade:

--Material negative developments with any of the company's major programs leading to delivery delays, order cancellations, large additional costs or inventory write-downs, which contribute to sustained FCF margins below 2% beyond 2023;

--Operational missteps and/or debt-funded acquisitions or share repurchases lead to sustained total debt to EBITDA leverage above 4.0x beyond 2024;

--Indications of materially higher business risk from regulatory challenges, fines, litigation, or reputation and brand damage.

Liquidity and Debt Structure

Fitch views Boeing's liquidity as sufficient compared to other capital intensive 'BBB' category companies. As of YE 2023 the company maintained total liquidity of greater than $26 billion, comprised of cash and equivalents around $16 billion and full availability of its $10 billion unsecured revolver. Fitch believes Boeing will continue to hold greater than $10 billion of cash and equivalents over the forecasted horizon, and we do not expect the company to draw on its revolver.

We currently expect this will be adequate to cover significant capital requirements, particularly since Fitch-projected FCF will improve towards the high-single digit billion-dollar range in 2026. Boeing's debt structure is predominantly comprised of senior unsecured notes, revolvers and CP availability. The company has several maturities due over the next 27 months, totaling more than $12 billion, which Fitch currently expects will be repaid using internally generated cash and cash on hand.

Issuer Profile

The Boeing Company is the world's largest aerospace & defense firm, and one of two major large commercial aircraft manufacturers, globally. The company operates in three principal segments: Boeing Defense, Space & Security; Boeing Commercial Aircraft; and Boeing Global Services.

Summary of Financial Adjustments

Fitch made certain analytical adjustments to add-back one-time charges related to various defense programs, the 787 aircraft and 737 MAX aircraft.

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

ESG Considerations

The Boeing Company has an ESG relevance score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737 MAX challenges, which has had a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. Below average execution on the 737 MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs, lower cash flows, and elevated leverage.

The highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3', unless otherwise disclosed in this section. A score of '3' means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores are not inputs in the rating process; they are an observation on the relevance and materiality of ESG factors in the rating decision. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores[https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores].

The Boeing Company; Long Term Issuer Default Rating; Affirmed; BBB-; Rating Outlook Stable

; Short Term Issuer Default Rating; Affirmed; F3

In issuing and maintaining its ratings and in making other reports (including forecast information), Fitch relies on factual information it receives from issuers and underwriters and from other sources Fitch believes to be credible. Fitch conducts a reasonable investigation of the factual information relied upon by it in accordance with its ratings methodology, and obtains reasonable verification of that information from independent sources, to the extent such sources are available for a given security or in a given jurisdiction. The manner of Fitchs factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitchs ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed.

The information in this report is provided as is without any representation or warranty of any kind, and Fitch does not represent or warrant that the report or any of its contents will meet any of the requirements of a recipient of the report. A Fitch rating is an opinion as to the creditworthiness of a security. This opinion and reports made by Fitch are based on established criteria and methodologies that Fitch is continuously evaluating and updating. Therefore, ratings and reports are the collective work product of Fitch and no individual, or group of individuals, is solely responsible for a rating or a report. The rating does not address the risk of loss due to risks other than credit risk, unless such risk is specifically mentioned. Fitch is not engaged in the offer or sale of any security. All Fitch reports have shared authorship. Individuals identified in a Fitch report were involved in, but are not solely responsible for, the opinions stated therein. The individuals are named for contact purposes only. A report providing a Fitch rating is neither a prospectus nor a substitute for the information assembled, verified and presented to investors by the issuer and its agents in connection with the sale of the securities. Ratings may be changed or withdrawn at any time for any reason in the sole discretion of Fitch. Fitch does not provide investment advice of any sort. Ratings are not a recommendation to buy, sell, or hold any security. Ratings do not comment on the adequacy of market price, the suitability of any security for a particular investor, or the tax-exempt nature or taxability of payments made in respect to any security. Fitch receives fees from issuers, insurers, guarantors, other obligors, and underwriters for rating securities. Such fees generally vary from US$1,000 to US$750,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent) per issue. In certain cases, Fitch will rate all or a number of issues issued by a particular issuer, or insured or guaranteed by a particular insurer or guarantor, for a single annual fee. Such fees are expected to vary from US$10,000 to US$1,500,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent). The assignment, publication, or dissemination of a rating by Fitch shall not constitute a consent by Fitch to use its name as an expert in connection with any registration statement filed under the United States securities laws, the Financial Services and Markets Act of 2000 of the United Kingdom, or the securities laws of any particular jurisdiction. Due to the relative efficiency of electronic publishing and distribution, Fitch research may be available to electronic subscribers up to three days earlier than to print subscribers.

For Australia, New Zealand, Taiwan and South Korea only: Fitch Australia Pty Ltd holds an Australian financial services license (AFS license no. 337123) which authorizes it to provide credit ratings to wholesale clients only. Credit ratings information published by Fitch is not intended to be used by persons who are retail clients within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001

Fitch Ratings, Inc. is registered with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission as a Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organization (the NRSRO). While certain of the NRSROs credit rating subsidiaries are listed on Item 3 of Form NRSRO and as such are authorized to issue credit ratings on behalf of the NRSRO (see

https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory]: https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory]

), other credit rating subsidiaries are not listed on Form NRSRO (the non-NRSROs) and therefore credit ratings issued by those subsidiaries are not issued on behalf of the NRSRO. However, non-NRSRO personnel may participate in determining credit ratings issued by or on behalf of the NRSRO.

Document FITRA00020240315ek3f001gt


Fitch Ratings: Boeing 737 MAX 9 Grounding Neutral for Rated Aircraft Lessors, Airlines, ABS
2160 words
9 January 2024
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York/Chicago-09 January 2024:

The grounding of the Boeing 737 MAX 9 is expected to be neutral to ratings and have limited near-term effects on Fitch-rated aircraft lessors, airlines and ABS, given relatively low exposure to the aircraft model and a fairly clear pathway for corrective action, Fitch Ratings says.

Following the in-air door detachment on Alaska Airlines Flight 1282, the Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) issued an airworthiness directive requiring safety inspections of certain Boeing 737 MAX 9 aircraft equipped with the mid-cabin door plug before returning to flight. Subsequently, the FAA outlined an approved method for operators to comply with the directive, which should expedite the requisite inspections and any corrective actions needed for affected aircraft to resume service.

The airworthiness directive applies only to the Boeing 737 MAX 9 aircraft with the mid-cabin door plug for configurations with fewer than 180 seats. No other Boeing 737 MAX type or current generation B737-900 aircraft is subject to the grounding. The groundings will contribute to the overall scarcity of aircraft supply, further supporting residual values on current technology aircraft already buoyed by delivery delays from Boeing.

Collectively, Fitch-rated lessors? exposure to the Boeing 737 MAX 9 aircraft totaled 1.2% (or 57 aircraft) by count and 1.5% (or $2.7 billion by market value) as of Jan. 8, 2024. Of this exposure, the FAA?s airworthiness directive applied to only 47 of these aircraft, or $2.2 billion by market value.

Aircraft Lessors Exposure[https://e.infogram.com/92672ebf-a565-489d-9e9f-63baf7020cbd?src=embed]

Rated lessors have $17.2 billion of senior unsecured debt coming due in 2024 and $19.7 billion of purchase commitments, with currently-strong liquidity coverage ratios expected to normalize gradually as debt maturities come due and order book commitments are filled. While aircraft lessors actively issued secured debt in 2023, they are expected to seek to increase unsecured issuance in 2024 to maintain funding flexibility and strong unencumbered asset coverage.

Boeing?s (BBB-/F3/Positive)

credit profile trajectory remains positive: https://app.fitchconnect.com/search/research/article/PR_10258122[https://app.fitchconnect.com/search/research/article/PR_10258122]

despite the near-term execution risks as the company completes mandatory inspections to affected aircraft while navigating existing objectives. We do not expect material production cancellations, particularly due to the low percentage of the overall orderbook that the 737 MAX 9 represents. We forecast Boeing?s financial results to be slightly weaker in 2024 than we contemplated during our October 2023 review. However, we still expect the company to progress toward operational normalization over the next 18 to 24 months by gradually increasing 737 MAX and 787 production levels and liquidating aircraft in inventory.

Within Fitch-rated airlines, exposure to the Boeing 737 MAX 9 is limited to Alaska Air (BB+/Stable) and United Airlines (B+/Stable). Grounded aircraft account for roughly 18% of Alaska?s mainline fleet and nearly 9% of United?s. Although the aircraft model makes up a sizable portion of both airlines? fleets and the grounding will create operational headaches, we do not anticipate the financial impact will drive rating actions at this time.

Early information indicates that the grounding may be relatively short-lived, and both United and Alaska have sufficient financial flexibility to weather the disruption. The grounding also comes at a low point in the year for travel. A longer-term grounding would complicate operations, but also likely entail greater compensation from Boeing.

Fitch rates two enhance equipment trust certificate (EETC) transactions with exposure to the Boeing 737 MAX 9, namely United?s 2019-1 and 2018-1 series. We do not anticipate a material impact to collateral coverage for the transactions, as long-term value retention for the aircraft is unlikely to be affected by the incident, barring the discovery of a larger, systemic design flaw, which we view as unlikely. The aircraft type accounts for roughly 20% of the total collateral value for each transaction. Fitch-rated aircraft operating lease ABS transactions have no exposure to the aircraft.

Fitch Ratings: Boeing Credit Profile Remains on Positive Trajectory Despite Disruption
1810 words
8 January 2024
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2024 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York/Chicago-08 January 2024: Fitch Ratings believes The Boeing Company?s (BA) credit profile remains on a positive trajectory despite the recent grounding of more than 170 737 MAX-9 aircraft following an incident on an Alaska Airlines flight on Jan. 5, 2024. The FAA has since approved a method to inspect affected aircraft, which provides a glidepath toward resolving the grounding, though the overall timing and inspection cost ahead of full return-to-service is uncertain and subject to no further expansion of the airworthiness directive.

Fitch continues to view BA?s path to reach its 2025 targets -- including sub-3.0x leverage, high single-digit billion FCF and greater than $15 billion of debt repayment -- as achievable, but likely non-linear.

Fitch currently rates Boeing?s Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) and issue ratings on its unsecured debt ?BBB-?, and its short-term IDR and CP ratings at ?F3?. The Rating Outlook is Positive.

Near-term execution risks could be temporarily heightened as the company completes mandatory inspections to affected aircraft while navigating existing objectives. We forecast 2024 financial results will be slightly weaker than we contemplated during our October 2023 review. However, we still expect the company to remain on the same positive track and progress toward operational normalization over the next 18 to 24 months by gradually increasing 737MAX and 787 production levels and liquidating aircraft in inventory.

We have updated our base case forecast to reflect 2024 MAX deliveries of around approximately 575 (versus previous near-600). This adjustment accounts for the possibility that the planned production rate increases to above 38 aircraft per month for the MAX could be marginally delayed due to a shift in operational priority, but with less of a disruption to production rates than those related to 2023 supply chain issues. Fitch also projects BA could deliver between 10-15 fewer 737MAX aircraft as a result of the grounding, due in part to less inventory reduction than previously anticipated as affected airlines complete inspections.

Fitch forecasts 2024 FCF around the mid-to-high $4 billion range (versus previous the expectation of mid-$5 billion), which incorporates FAA-mandated inspection costs, potential customer compensation, lower deliveries and the working capital impact from less inventory reduction. Our assumption regarding inventory liquidation reflects that the majority of aircraft are (or were previously) earmarked to be delivered to China and are likely 737MAX-8 variants, which are unaffected by the grounding. An expansion of the airworthiness directive would further weigh on FCF and deleveraging capacity.

Fitch does not expect material cancellations as a result of the issue, particularly due to the low percentage of the overall orderbook that the MAX-9 represents. We believe the high switching costs for airlines to change fleet plans, coupled with the time-to-delivery for new aircraft orders also insulates BA from material cancellations. Fitch estimates the MAX-9 represents less than 5% of BA?s total backlog and a low-single-digit percentage of aircraft inventory to be liquidated (approximately 200 total 737 MAX aircraft in inventory).

Contact:

Nicholas Varone

Senior Director

Primary Rating Analyst

+1 212 908 0349

nicholas.varone@fitchratings.com

Document FITRA00020240108ek18002mh


Fitch Revises Boeing's Outlook to Positive; Affirms IDR at 'BBB-'
3629 words
3 October 2023
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2023 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-03 October 2023: Fitch Ratings has affirmed The Boeing Company's (BA or Boeing) 'BBB-' Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) and 'F3' Short-Term IDR. Fitch has also affirmed BA's senior unsecured ratings at 'BBB-' and short-term CP ratings at 'F3'. The Rating Outlook was revised to Positive from Stable.

The Positive Outlook reflects Boeing's declining inventory levels, improving production and delivery profile, growing backlog, and forecasted positive FCF that will facilitate debt repayment. Fitch recognizes that recent supplier missteps will modestly delay previously expected operational and financial improvements, but expects ongoing progress to lead to operational normalization and greater than $15 billion of gross debt repayment by YE 2025.

Fitch's base case forecasts positive FCF of around $2 billion in 2023 steadily increasing towards $10 billion in 2025, which supports EBITDA leverage declining below 3.0x by 2025. The Outlook is anticipated to be resolved in the next 12 months-18 months as the company de-risks its return to operational normalization and progresses towards its debt reduction targets.

Key Rating Drivers

FCF Approaching $10 billion by 2025: Fitch projects BA's FCF will improve to nearly $10 billion in 2025, up from around $2 billion forecasted in 2023, as the company gradually liquidates aircraft in inventory and normalizes operations by scaling 737MAX and 787 production rates. The company should also benefit from EBITDA margin improvement to above 10% in the next 12 months to 18 months as facility utilization improves alongside inventory reduction. The Boeing Defense, Space & Security (BDS) segment should also transition to breakeven-to-positive margins as challenged programs mature, which Fitch forecasts will begin during 2025.

EBITDA Leverage Declining Below 3.0x: Fitch forecasts BA's EBITDA leverage will decline below 3.0x by YE 2025 as a result of greater than $15 billion of estimated debt repayment in conjunction with utilization-driven EBITDA margin improvement. More than $9 billion of debt repayment would come from retiring debt at maturity and the agency calculates the company could have up to an additional $8 billion of capacity to make voluntary prepayments while maintaining cash above $10 billion. The timing and pace of voluntary repayments depends on BA's ability to reduce inventoried aircraft and ramp aircraft production rates on-schedule, while also considering seasonal liquidity needs. Fitch considers these concerns to be addressable.

Inventory Liquidation Facilitates Operational Normalization: Fitch projects BA will monetize all 737MAX and 787 aircraft currently in inventory by the end of 2025 despite supplier challenges in the first nine months of 2023. The agency forecasts approximately 200 MAXs and 60 787s in inventory at the end of 2023, declining to 80 and 20, respectively, in 2024 before being liquidated in 2025. These projections are slower than Fitch previously expected, but the agency recognized operational risks remained. Fitch views inventory liquidation as instrumental to operational normalization and long-term FCF generation.

Production Increasing, Non-Linear Path Expected: Fitch forecasts BA will steadily increase production rates for 737MAX and 787 aircraft over the next 24 months towards run-rate levels of 50 MAXs and 10 787s per month by early 2026. The agency believes Boeing should be able to manage the operational and financial impacts of future supplier challenges, if any, as MAX inventory levels and production rates normalize and supply chains are optimized.

Risks to production rate increases and inventory reduction include supply chain constraints which are expected to persist throughout 2024 and operational missteps by one of the company's key suppliers, Spirit Aerosystems. Disruptions have resulted in periodic but temporary delivery delays, particularly for the 737MAX. The bulk of issues have challenged inventory liquidation rather than new aircraft production due to increased inspections and rework requirements during maintenance cycles. These challenges will likely limit 2023 FCF and profitability growth compared to previous forecasts, due largely to slower inventory reduction coupled with increased maintenance work scope. However, Fitch believes BA's trajectory remains positive, with a clear line of sight to operational normalization.

Orders, Backlog Provide Demand, Revenue Visibility: Global demand for new aircraft is substantial, indicated by greater than $360 billion of backlog in BA's Boeing Commercial Airplanes (BCA) segment. Fitch estimates current aircraft backlog provides visibility into sales through early-2029. We expect the company will continue to generate substantial new orders over the next several years as airlines aim to modernize aging fleets and alleviate capacity constraints that currently exist in the industry.

China will also be a significant industry growth driver over the next few decades as it builds up its air infrastructure. Recent headwinds for the 737MAX in the APAC region have mostly dissipated and BA estimates 97% of the MAX fleet is now back in service in China. Fitch believes the company will be able to restart deliveries to the area over the next several months.

Defense Bolsters Diversification: Fitch views BA's BDS segment as a net positive factor for the credit due to the high degree of diversification provided by contract, program and capability. Independently, BDS would represent a top-5 global defense contractor, by revenue. The segment also operates in a variety of high priority areas such as space, drones and aircraft, which should remain key focus areas for the U.S. government over the next several years.

Fitch believes the company will remain competitive for new programs, such as (one of the two) Next Generation Air Dominance programs, which includes a drone component where BA specializes. BDS is also supported by strong international demand and heightened global tensions, with greater than 30% of defense revenue coming from non-U.S. customers.

Defense Program Challenges Expected to Moderate: Despite being a net positive for BA's overall credit profile, BDS has experienced operational challenges on four large contracts which Fitch projects will collectively contribute to a drag on free cash flow through at least the end of 2024. These four significant programs, which represent around 25% of BDS sales, have driven segment margins to be negative over the past 18 months and Fitch believes they will remain a margin headwind and cash drag until YE 2024 after two of the programs pass major milestones. We conservatively expect the segment will remain around breakeven through the end of 2025 as a result of persistent risk from the remaining two programs being offset by operational improvements.

Derivation Summary

Boeing is rated three notches below its most immediate peer, Airbus SE (A-/F1/Stable). This is largely the result of Boeing's execution challenges in the past several years, which have combined to weaken Boeing's quantitative rating factors compared with Airbus'. Cash flow generation is one of the key differentiators between Airbus and Boeing. In the past, Boeing consistently achieved significantly better FCF and funds from operations due to program execution and lower investment needs despite higher dividend payments. However, the 737MAX grounding and 787 disruption severely affected Boeing's cash flow, and caused debt to rise significantly versus Airbus's.

Boeing's business profile has also been modestly stronger than Airbus's because of a more diverse revenue mix between commercial and defense, in addition to services. Airbus currently has a stronger balance sheet, though BA plans to use all excess cash to repay debt. Airbus generally operates with a net cash position, though both companies have significant financial flexibility. Foreign exchange exposure is also a key differentiator between Boeing and Airbus, with the former having little exposure and the latter has significant exposure, although Airbus has taken modest actions to address this.

Key Assumptions

Fitch's Key Assumptions for the issuer include:

--Double-digit overall revenue growth in 2023 supported by significant growth at the Boeing Commercial Airplanes segment; 737MAX deliveries increase to around 405 in 2023 and 787 deliveries around 70; overall 2024 revenue grows by greater than 25% as a result of higher production levels and inventory reduction;

--Boeing Defense, Space & Security (BDS) segment revenue flattish in 2023, increases by single digits in 2024 and 2025; Boeing Global Services segment revenue increases in the mid-to-high single-digit range annually through 2026;

--737MAX production rates: increases to 38 per month by the end of 2023, low-40s in mid-2024, high-40s in early 2025 and run-rate around 50-52 by YE 2025;

--737MAX inventory: around 200 remain in inventory at YE 2023, between 60% and 70% of those aircraft are delivered during 2024, remaining delivered in 2025;

--787 production rates: Three per month until Q4 2023 when they increase to four per month; increase to 5 per month in 1H24, seven per month in 1H25 and 10 per month by YE 2025;

--787 inventory: approx. 65-70 remain in inventory at YE 2023, between 60% and 70% of those aircraft are delivered during 2024 and remaining are delivered in 1H25;

--BDS operating margins negative in 2023 and 2024, increasing towards breakeven in 2025;

--Generally, all cash in excess of around $10 billion to $12 billion will be directed towards debt repayment before YE 2025, with some exception in case of liquidity needs and seasonality in 2023;

--Pension contributions remain around $1 billion per year throughout the forecasted period;

--Working capital is an annual source of cash through 2025;

--R&D expense fluctuates around 4% of total sales throughout the forecasted period; capex remains around 2% of total sales;

--Fuselage and aft pressure bulkhead fixes result in a cash drag, spread between 2023 through 2024 as a result of inspections, increased work scope, operational disruption and modest conservatism for unforeseen future costs;

--Defense program cost overruns result in cash drag between 2023 and 2026;

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade:

--Continued progress towards operational normalization via reduced inventory and increased production;

--Demonstrated commitment to gross debt reduction leading to total debt to EBITDA leverage at 3.0x or lower;

--Sustained FCF margins at 3% or above.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade:

--Material negative developments with any of the company's major programs leading to delivery delays, order cancellations, large additional costs or inventory write-downs, which contribute to sustained FCF margins below 2% beyond 2023;

--Operational missteps and/or debt-funded acquisitions or share repurchases lead to sustained total debt to EBITDA leverage above 4.0x beyond 2024;

--Indications of materially higher business risk from regulatory challenges, fines, litigation, or reputation and brand damage.

Fitch could stabilize the outlook as a result of persistent operational delays which result in a delay of FCF generation and EBITDA leverage improvement inside BA's positive sensitivities.

Liquidity and Debt Structure

Fitch views BA's liquidity as sufficient and strong compared to capital intensive 'BBB' category companies. As of mid-2023 BA maintained total liquidity of greater than $23 billion, comprised of cash and equivalents in excess of $13 billion and full availability of its recently extended $10 billion unsecured revolver. Fitch believes the company will continue to hold greater than $10 billion of cash over the forecasted horizon and we do not expect BA to draw on its revolver.

We expect this will be adequate to cover any significant capital requirements, particularly as Fitch projects the company's FCF will improve towards $10 billion in 2025. The company's debt structure is predominantly comprised of senior unsecured notes, revolvers and CP availability. The company has several maturities due over the next 36 months, totaling more than $17 billion, which Fitch currently expects the company to repay using internally generated cash and cash on hand.

Issuer Profile

The Boeing Company (BA) is the world's largest aerospace & defense firm, and one of two major large commercial aircraft manufacturers, globally. The company operates in three principal segments: Boeing Defense, Space & Security; Boeing Commercial Aircraft; and Boeing Global Services.

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

ESG Considerations

The Boeing Company has an ESG relevance score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737 MAX challenges, which has had a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. Below average execution on the 737 MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs.

The highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3', unless otherwise disclosed in this section. A score of '3' means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores are not inputs in the rating process; they are an observation on the relevance and materiality of ESG factors in the rating decision. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores[https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores].

Document FITRA00020231003eja3000ul


Fitch Withdraws Boeing Capital Corporation's IDR
1816 words
28 September 2023
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2023 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-Chicago-28 September 2023: Fitch Ratings has withdrawn Boeing Capital Corporation's (BCC) 'BBB-' Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR). At the time of the withdrawal, the Rating Outlook was Stable.

Fitch has withdrawn BCC's ratings as the rated entity no longer exists and all of its outstanding senior unsecured debt has been paid in full. Accordingly, Fitch will no longer provide ratings or analytical coverage for BCC.

Key Rating Drivers

Prior to the withdrawal, BCC's ratings and Outlook reflected the linkage with that of its parent, The Boeing Company (BA), and the fact that BA has provided unconditional guarantees for the due and punctual payment and performance of all of BCC's outstanding publicly-issued debt. In addition to the guarantee, BCC's role arranging, structuring, and providing financing to support the sale of BA's products, the high level of management and operational integration between the two entities, BA's track record of support for BCC, and the fungibility of funding between the two entities further supported Fitch's view of BCC as a core subsidiary of BA.

Consistent with Fitch's 'Non-Bank Financial Institutions Rating Criteria', the ratings and Outlooks of core subsidiaries were equalized with those of its parent. BCC's unsecured debt rating were also equalized to the Long-Term IDR of the parent, reflecting the unconditional guarantee.

Key Rating Drivers are not applicable as the ratings were withdrawn.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Negative Rating Action/Downgrade

Rating Sensitivities are not applicable as the ratings were withdrawn.

Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Positive Rating Action/Upgrade

Rating Sensitivities are not applicable as the ratings were withdrawn.

Date of Relevant Committee

18 October 2022

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

ESG Considerations

The highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3', unless otherwise disclosed in this section. A score of '3' means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores are not inputs in the rating process; they are an observation on the relevance and materiality of ESG factors in the rating decision. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores[https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores].

Boeing Capital Corporation; Long Term Issuer Default Rating; Withdrawn; WD

Fitch receives fees from issuers, insurers, guarantors, other obligors, and underwriters for rating securities. Such fees generally vary from US$1,000 to US$750,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent) per issue. In certain cases, Fitch will rate all or a number of issues issued by a particular issuer, or insured or guaranteed by a particular insurer or guarantor, for a single annual fee. Such fees are expected to vary from US$10,000 to US$1,500,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent). The assignment, publication, or dissemination of a rating by Fitch shall not constitute a consent by Fitch to use its name as an expert in connection with any registration statement filed under the United States securities laws, the Financial Services and Markets Act of 2000 of the United Kingdom, or the securities laws of any particular jurisdiction. Due to the relative efficiency of electronic publishing and distribution, Fitch research may be available to electronic subscribers up to three days earlier than to print subscribers.

For Australia, New Zealand, Taiwan and South Korea only: Fitch Australia Pty Ltd holds an Australian financial services license (AFS license no. 337123) which authorizes it to provide credit ratings to wholesale clients only. Credit ratings information published by Fitch is not intended to be used by persons who are retail clients within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001

Fitch Ratings, Inc. is registered with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission as a Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organization (the ?NRSRO?). While certain of the NRSRO?s credit rating subsidiaries are listed on Item 3 of Form NRSRO and as such are authorized to issue credit ratings on behalf of the NRSRO (see

https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory]: https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory]

), other credit rating subsidiaries are not listed on Form NRSRO (the ?non-NRSROs?) and therefore credit ratings issued by those subsidiaries are not issued on behalf of the NRSRO. However, non-NRSRO personnel may participate in determining credit ratings issued by or on behalf of the NRSRO.

Fitch Solutions Group Limited

Document FITRA00020230928ej9s006el


Fitch Ratings: Strong Demand Supports EMEA Aerospace and Defence Growth
1859 words
21 September 2023
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2023 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-London-21 September 2023: A solid recovery in air traffic, expanded commercial airlines? fleet-modernisation programmes, as well as increased defence spending spurred by geopolitical events, support order growth in the EMEA aerospace and defence (A&D) sector, Fitch Ratings says.

The commercial aerospace recovery is helped by airlines? growing traffic, the need to modernise ageing fleets with more fuel-efficient units, and improving airline profitability. We expect deliveries in the sector to fully recover to pre-pandemic levels by end-2025. Within the sector, the narrow-body segment has been growing faster, although its growth in 2022 was slower than expected. Full recovery of the wide-body segment is likely to take until 2026.

Aircraft deliveries[https://e.infogram.com/f5cc8a1a-90a0-47e9-8f10-35037534b556?src=embed]

Our outlook for the A&D sector is ?Improving?. However, we now expect growth in aircraft deliveries by Airbus and Boeing in 2023 to be in low-teen percentages compared to our expectation of about 20% at the start of the year. Fitch forecasts Boeing to deliver slightly less than 600 aircraft in 2023, including 425-460 of the 737 MAX. We now expect a lower proportion of 737 MAX deliveries in 2023 to be from inventory following the Spirit Aerosystems fuselage issue that will require the rework of inventoried aircraft.

Aircraft order and backlog[https://e.infogram.com/a8bb591b-726e-4c8a-a6b8-6545046bccfc?src=embed]

We expect that production and delivery rates for European commercial aerospace companies will remain constrained by supply-chain disruptions until at least mid-2024. Such pressures have eased from their peak in 2021 but have persisted for longer than expected. Supply-chain bottlenecks have been registered in several parts of the aircraft value chain. Key pressure points relate to the shortage of parts such as engines, forgings and electrical components. Aircraft manufacturers and suppliers are also exposed to shortages of experienced engineers following job cuts during the pandemic.

A partial recall of some in-fleet GTF engines used primarily in the A320 family aircraft is the most recent setback in the commercial aerospace sector. This will likely affect the cash flow and liquidity of the programme?s minority European partners, MTU Aero Engines and GKN Holdings, although the full impact of the recall

is yet to be assessed: https://app.fitchconnect.com/search/research/article/PR_10246388[https://app.fitchconnect.com/search/research/article/PR_10246388].

Increased defence spending, triggered in Europe by geopolitical events, including Russia?s war in Ukraine, is likely to support revenue for the vast majority of European A&D manufacturers and service providers. Orders rose significantly in 1H23 and we expect them to continue growing for most companies in the coming years.

Still, some defence contractors will benefit sooner than others. Those companies that make munitions and armoured vehicles or provide related services, such as MBDA and BAE, have already seen an increase in projected volumes. Companies focusing on longer-cycle equipment, such as fighter jets and submarines, will likely see a more pronounced benefit only in the later part of this decade. This includes the Eurofighter consortium, thyssenkrupp and Thales.

Related research:

What Investors Want to Know: EMEA Aerospace & Defence ? August 2023: https://app.fitchconnect.com/search/research/article/RPT_10241309[https://app.fitchconnect.com/search/research/article/RPT_10241309]

In issuing and maintaining its ratings and in making other reports (including forecast information), Fitch relies on factual information it receives from issuers and underwriters and from other sources Fitch believes to be credible. Fitch conducts a reasonable investigation of the factual information relied upon by it in accordance with its ratings methodology, and obtains reasonable verification of that information from independent sources, to the extent such sources are available for a given security or in a given jurisdiction. The manner of Fitch's factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitch's ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed.

This opinion and reports made by Fitch are based on established criteria and methodologies that Fitch is continuously evaluating and updating. Therefore, ratings and reports are the collective work product of Fitch and no individual, or group of individuals, is solely responsible for a rating or a report. The rating does not address the risk of loss due to risks other than credit risk, unless such risk is specifically mentioned. Fitch is not engaged in the offer or sale of any security. The individuals are named for contact purposes only. A report providing a Fitch rating is neither a prospectus nor a substitute for the information assembled, verified and presented to investors by the issuer and its agents in connection with the sale of the securities. Ratings may be changed or withdrawn at any time for any reason in the sole discretion of Fitch. Fitch does not provide investment advice of any sort. Ratings are not a recommendation to buy, sell, or hold any security. Ratings do not comment on the adequacy of market price, the suitability of any security for a particular investor, or the tax-exempt nature or taxability of payments made in respect to any security. Fitch Affirms Boeing's IDR at 'BBB-'; Outlook Stable
4465 words
19 October 2022
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2022 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-19 October 2022: Fitch Ratings has affirmed The Boeing Company's (BA) Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) and senior unsecured debt at 'BBB-' and Short-Term IDR and CP rating at 'F3'. Fitch has also affirmed the Long-Term IDR and senior unsecured ratings of Boeing Capital Corporation (BCC) at 'BBB-'. The Rating Outlook is Stable.

BA's ratings and outlook reflect the company's improving FCF and leverage, progress towards reducing inventory and overcoming operational challenges, high degree of technology, and substantial liquidity. Fitch's rating case forecasts positive FCF of about $5.5 billion in 2023 and $10 billion in 2024, with leverage metrics trending below 3.5x. The company also holds a strong, diversified, and strategic market position in both aerospace and defense end-markets, supported by a large order backlog and regulatory moat.

Concerns include elevated inventory levels and supply chain constraints which could influence timing of cash generation, production rate increases, and operational stabilization, as well as Boeing's large debt balance, which leaves its rating exposed to adverse business or economic conditions until debt is reduced. The agency also recognizes headwinds including the return of the 737 MAX to China.

Key Rating Drivers

Leverage Trending Below 3.5x: Fitch anticipates BA's leverage will continue to remain elevated for the rating level, around or above 3.5x, until YE 2024 as the company recovers from the worst downturn in aviation history and moves beyond several operational and regulatory challenges. However, metrics should improve thereafter as the company's operations continue to normalize towards run-rate levels, which should lead to greater cash generation, in tandem with the company's stated plan to use excess cash to pay down debt. Fitch projects the company could reduce debt by more than $20 billion by 2025 while still maintaining greater than $10 billion of available cash.

Positive FCF Forecasted: Fitch projects BA's FCF to gradually improve towards a level consistent with the high 'BBB' category over the next few years. Fitch forecasts BA will generate between $1 billion and $2 billion of FCF in 2022, between $5 billion and $7 billion in 2023, and low double-digit billions in 2024. The pace and magnitude of FCF increases will largely depend on balancing aircraft deliveries, inventory reduction, and production rate increases, while the health of the supply chain and demand by airline customers will heavily influence each of these factors. Fitch also believes BA's defense business could be a negative drag on cash flow over the next 12 months to 18 months as the company works through operational and growth challenges.

Deliveries Increasing: Fitch's rating case assumes large commercial aircraft (LCA) deliveries by BA will increase by more than 75% between 2021 and 2023, driven by strong narrowbody demand despite our expectation for a mild U.S. recession in 2023. Strong air traffic demand, particularly within the US, as well as higher OEM production rates, should help to extend BA's recovery in profitability, FCF generation and revenue growth. Fitch believes through-the-cycle demand will remain intact given the long-term planning of customers, as well as the resiliency of aircraft funding.

Supply Chain, Inventory Constrain Production: Fitch believes BA will temper increases to production rates until there is a high degree of confidence in the supply chain's ability to increase capacity. Fitch's current base case for BA incorporates production rates for the 737 MAX increasing to the high-30s per month beginning in early-2024 from current 31 per month, then again to the low-40s in late 2024. These higher levels assume minimal supply chain disruption and steady inventory reduction. Meanwhile, Fitch projects the 787 will be produced at a low-single digit rate through the end of 2023 before raising to mid-single digits in 2024.

Supply Chain Challenges Remain: Supply chain health, specifically related to current high-pressure points of labor, engines and spares, engine parts, semiconductors, and raw materials, will remain a key watch item as Boeing and Airbus ramp up production rates beyond 2022. Fitch believes the majority of companies have been prudently restocking inventory that was drawn down during the pandemic and we consider risk of near-term disruption to be minimal. However, prolonged supply chain constraints could lead to higher costs and a slower ramp-up of future production which could limit financial performance upside from current levels and BA's to generate significant FCF and delever.

Inventory Reduction Ongoing: Fitch believes BA's ability to reduce the number of aircraft in inventory will be a key factor determining whether the company will be able to meet or exceed the agency's production and cash flow forecasts. Fitch expects BA will modestly reduce inventory in the final months of 2022, leaving balances of more than 250 737 MAX aircraft and more than 90 787s at the end of the year. We forecast the rate of reduction will likely hinge on a combination of the health and appetite of airline customers, and pace of production rate increases.

China Unlikely a Near-term Impact: Fitch believes an agreement with China to recertify the 737 MAX is possible over the next three months to six months. However, we do not expect an agreement will have a meaningful effect on the company's financial performance and delivery numbers until "Zero Covid" policies are loosened, which Fitch does not anticipate until mid-2023 or later. Geopolitical and trade tensions and global economic conditions are also key factors that could inhibit progress towards delivery resumption in the region.

LCA Competitive Position Weakened: Boeing still shares a valuable duopoly with Airbus, but its competitive position has weakened in the past three years. The MAX grounding allowed Airbus to solidify its leadership in the narrowbody market. Boeing also stopped development of the New Midmarket Airplane. Boeing's termination of the proposed Embraer joint venture gave Airbus an edge at the smaller end of the narrowbody market with the A220 family.

MAX -7 and -10 Certification Uncertain: BA's 737 MAX-7 and MAX-10 variants must be certified before YE 2022 in order to avoid the need for either significant re-design and alterations of the aircraft or an extension of the certification process by U.S. Congress.

Fitch expects BA will likely reach alternate arrangements, particularly with the largest customers for the variants, if certification or extensions are not awarded; however, it is possible that some orders for could be in jeopardy of cancellation if an agreement is not reached. Fitch assesses a moderate likelihood that certification of the -7 variant is possible by the end of 2022, though the -10 will likely require a Congressional extension.

Positive Defense Environment, but Program Challenges: Fitch considers the overall environment for defense contracts to be positive. Spending on defense is expected to increase both within the U.S. and internationally over the next several years.

Fitch views BA's defense business to be a positive factor for the credit due to the high degree of diversification by both contract and program that the segment adds; however, the company has experienced operational challenges on a few large contracts which may contribute to a drag on free cash flow over at least into 2023. Specifically, the KC-46 and T-7A programs, among others, have taken substantial charges during 2022 and future cost overruns are possible.

Boeing Capital:

The affirmation of BCC's ratings and Outlook reflect the linkage with that of its parent, BA, and the fact that BA has provided unconditional guarantees for the due and punctual payment and performance of all of BCC's outstanding publicly-issued debt. In addition to the guarantee, BCC's role arranging, structuring, and providing financing to support the sale of BA's products, the high level of management and operational integration between the two entities, BA's track record of support for BCC, and the fungibility of funding between the two entities further support Fitch's view of BCC as a core subsidiary of BA.

Consistent with Fitch's 'Non-Bank Financial Institutions Rating Criteria', the ratings and Outlooks of core subsidiaries are equalized with those of its parent. BCC's unsecured debt rating is also equalized to the Long-Term IDR of the parent, reflecting the unconditional guarantee.

BCC has historically exhibited sound operating performance, stable asset quality, and a sufficient liquidity profile, although its standalone credit risk profile would likely be lower than 'BBB-' given the cyclicality and residual value risk associated with the aircraft leasing business, the credit risk profile and concentration of BCC's lessees and its elevated leverage levels relative to standalone aircraft lessors.

BCC's operating income declined in 2022 due to lower net gains on the disposal or re-lease of assets and higher provision expenses. Operating performance is expected to remain pressured in the near-term resulting from portfolio run-off, slow paying customers and modest impairments.

Consistent with Fitch's 'Non-Bank Financial Institutions Rating Criteria', the ratings and Outlooks of core subsidiaries are equalized with those of its parent. BCC's unsecured debt rating is also equalized to the Long-Term IDR of the parent, reflecting the unconditional guarantee.

Boeing's ratings have been materially impacted in part by self-inflicted operational challenges and international regulators' response related to 737 MAX and 787 production, maintenance, and training since 2019. Delays in MAX return to service, which was exacerbated by the pandemic and broad aviation downturn, and 787 production caused a meaningful drag on FCF and subsequent build-up in inventory, which must be unwound. Fitch believes the company will be able to navigate these changes as the broader industry recovers, which could result in the ESG factor of '4' for Management Strategy being revised to a '3'.

Derivation Summary

Boeing is rated two notches below its most immediate peer, Airbus SE (BBB+/F1/Stable). This is largely the result of Boeing's execution challenges in the past several years, which have combined to weaken Boeing's quantitative rating factors compared with Airbus'. Cash flow generation is one of the key differentiators between Airbus and Boeing. In the past, Boeing consistently achieved significantly better FCF and funds from operations due to program execution and lower investment needs despite higher dividend payments. However, the 737 MAX grounding and 787 disruption severely affected Boeing's cash flow, and caused debt to rise significantly versus Airbus's.

Boeing's business profile has also been modestly stronger than Airbus's because of a more diverse revenue mix between commercial and defense, in addition to services. Airbus currently has a stronger balance sheet, though BA plans to use all excess cash to repay debt. Airbus generally operates with a higher net cash position than Boeing. Foreign exchange exposure is also a key differentiator between Boeing and Airbus, with the former having little exposure and the latter has significant exposure, although Airbus has taken modest actions to address this.

Key Assumptions

--Mild recession in mid-2023 results in BA taking a tempered approach to increasing production rates for the 737 MAX and 787, though demand for the aircraft remains relatively stable due to airlines' long-term fleet planning;

--MAX production rate continues at 31 per month until increasing to high 30s per month beginning in early-2024 and low-40s in mid-to-late 2024; 787 aircraft remains in the low single digit range in 2023, but increases to the mid-single digits in 2024;

--Between 80 and 100 737 MAX aircraft sold out of inventory per year in 2023 and 2024; between 35 and 50 787 aircraft sold out of inventory during the same period;

--Defense segment margins remain low through 2023 due to cost overruns at key programs;

--Marginally positive FCF in 2022, improving to high single digit billions in 2023 and low double-digit billions in 2024;

--COVID restrictions remain relatively strict in China through mid-2023 and 737 MAX deliveries don't resume until at least 2H23;

--Supply chain constraints remain relatively unchanged until at least early-to-mid 2023 before gradually improving; Modest drag on working capital in 2023 due to timing of payments and supply chain inefficiency;

--Company maintains at least $10 billion cash balance plus full revolver availability over the forecasted period;

--All cash in excess of $10 billion to $12 billion will be used to repay debt through 2025.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

BA:

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade:

--Sustained total debt to EBITDA leverage at 3.0x or lower;

--Sustained FCF margins at 3% or above;

--Continued progress towards operational normalization via reduced inventory and increased production.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade:

--Material negative developments with any of the company's major programs leading to delivery delays, order cancellations, large additional costs or inventory write-downs, which contribute to sustained FCF margins below 2% beyond 2023;

--Operational missteps and/or debt-funded acquisitions or share repurchases lead to sustained total debt to EBITDA leverage above 4.0x beyond 2024;

--Indications of materially higher business risk from regulatory challenges, fines, litigation, or reputation and brand damage;

--Material provision of customer financing by BCC.

BCC:

BCC's ratings and Outlook are linked to those of its parent.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade would be limited to Fitch's view of BA's credit profile. Fitch cannot envisage a scenario where the captive would be rated higher than its parent.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade could be driven by a downgrade of BA's ratings or the early termination of the parent guarantee prior to the repayment of BCC's outstanding publicly issued debt.

The unsecured debt rating is primarily sensitive to changes in the Long-Term IDR of the parent, and would be expected to move in tandem.

Best/Worst Case Rating Scenario

International scale credit ratings of Financial Institutions and Covered Bond issuers have a best-case rating upgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a positive direction) of three notches over a three-year rating horizon; and a worst-case rating downgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a negative direction) of four notches over three years. The complete span of best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings for all rating categories ranges from 'AAA' to 'D'. Best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings are based on historical performance. For more information about the methodology used to determine sector-specific best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579]

International scale credit ratings of Non-Financial Corporate issuers have a best-case rating upgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a positive direction) of three notches over a three-year rating horizon; and a worst-case rating downgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a negative direction) of four notches over three years. The complete span of best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings for all rating categories ranges from 'AAA' to 'D'. Best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings are based on historical performance. For more information about the methodology used to determine sector-specific best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579].

Liquidity and Debt Structure

Fitch views BA's liquidity as sufficient and strong compared to many other 'BBB-' rated companies. As of mid-2022 BA maintained total liquidity of greater than $25 billion, comprised of a cash balance in excess of $13 billion and full revolver availability of $12 billion. Fitch believes the company will continue to hold greater than $10 billion of cash over the forecasted horizon and we do not expect BA to draw on its revolver.

We expect this will be adequate to cover any significant capital requirements, particularly as Fitch projects the company will turn FCF positive during 2022. The company's debt structure is predominantly comprised of senior unsecured notes, revolvers and CP availability. The company has several maturities due over the next 36 months, totaling just under $15 billion, which Fitch expects the company to repay using internally generated cash and cash on hand.

Issuer Profile

The Boeing Company (BA) is the world's largest aerospace & defense firm, founded in Seattle, WA in 1916. The company operates in four principal segments: Boeing Defense, Space & Security; Boeing Commercial Aircraft; Boeing Global Services; and Boeing Capital Corporation.

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

ESG Considerations

BA has an ESG relevance score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737 MAX challenges, which has had a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. Below average execution on the 737 MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs and potential reputational damage.

Unless otherwise disclosed in this section, the highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3'. This means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit www.fitchratings.com/esg[http://www.fitchratings.com/esg].

; Short Term Issuer Default Rating; Affirmed; F3

)

ADDITIONAL DISCLOSURES
