In issuing and maintaining its ratings and in making other reports (including forecast information), Fitch relies on factual information it receives from issuers and underwriters and from other sources Fitch believes to be credible. Fitch conducts a reasonable investigation of the factual information relied upon by it in accordance with its ratings methodology, and obtains reasonable verification of that information from independent sources, to the extent such sources are available for a given security or in a given jurisdiction. The manner of Fitchs factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitchs ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed.

Document FITRA00020221019eiaj001md


Fitch Ratings: Boeing's Positive Rating Momentum Hinges on Operational Execution
1692 words
26 January 2022
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2022 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-26 January 2022: Fitch Ratings believes The Boeing Company (Boeing; BA) could achieve positive rating momentum during 2H22 if it executes on certain operational objectives to de-risk the company's credit profile. In particular, the agency heavily weights BA's ability to meet 737MAX delivery targets during 2022, as well as the timing of 787 deliveries resuming. Fitch is also monitoring the pace of orders, production rate increases, inventory levels, and the company's continued positive FCF execution and commitment to further pay down its debt balance. Fitch currently rates Boeing 'BBB-' with a Stable Outlook.

Fitch would consider Boeing delivering more than 450 737MAXs during the year to be a key step towards positive ratings momentum. Meeting or exceeding this target would likely put the company on pace to reduce inventory levels by more than 70-100 during the year, given the company's current production rate of 26 per month, and plan to increase to 31 per month early in 2022. Fitch considers the recent directive issued by the Civil Aviation Administration of China to be a favorable development, which could help BA meet its delivery goals.

In addition, the agency views the resumption of 787 aircraft deliveries as a necessary achievement, as it would remove a material headwind against FCF generation. Production of the aircraft is currently paused, and execution on the logistical challenges to deliver current inventory and resume production is an important watch item. Future customer concessions or charges related to 787 delivery delays are possible; however, Fitch expects the impact on cash flow will be manageable once the aircraft are again cleared for delivery.

Fitch's base case forecasts a return in delivery momentum on the 737MAX and 787 in the first half of the year, facilitating positive FCF in the $3 billion to $6 billion range for the full-year 2022. The company also has maturing and callable debt of roughly $5 billion in each 2022 and 2023, which provides a path for gross debt reduction. Fitch views management's willingness to allocate capital towards debt reduction as relatively strong given the alignment of debt and equity stakeholders' near-term priorities.

Risks to the company's positive rating momentum include the vulnerability of the aviation market recovery, order cancellations, unforeseen and costly testing and rework requirements related to 787 deliveries resuming during 2022, operational disruptions, and supply chain issues. Another risk is the potential for Boeing to deviate from its stated financial policy, but Fitch views this as less likely.

Contact:

Nicholas Varone

Director, Corporates

+1-212-908-0349

Fitch Ratings, Inc.

33 Whitehall Street

New York, NY 10004

Document FITRA00020220126ei1q003pd


Fitch Revises Boeing's Outlook to Stable; Affirms 'BBB-'/'F3' Ratings
5541 words
22 October 2021
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2021 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-22 October 2021: Fitch Ratings has affirmed The Boeing Company's (BA) Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) and senior unsecured debt at 'BBB-' and Short-Term IDR at 'F3'. Fitch has also affirmed the Long-Term IDR and senior unsecured ratings of Boeing Capital Corporation (BCC) at 'BBB-'. The Rating Outlook has been revised to Stable from Negative.

The Outlook revision reflects developments over the past year in coronavirus vaccines, airline traffic recovery and the 737 MAX. These developments have narrowed the uncertainty in Fitch's forecasts. Combined with Boeing's liquidity position, they have also reduced the likelihood of a downgrade. Additionally, they also offset 787 delivery delays and a slow MAX delivery ramp-up, which are contributing to 2021 financial performance below some of Fitch's expectations. Going forward, Fitch believes that Boeing is past its peak debt level and mostly through the cash burn trough.

Factors supporting the ratings include Boeing's strategic positions, diversification, technology, liquidity, access to the debt and equity markets, and a large order backlog. The relative stability of the defense business also supports the ratings. Substantial cost reductions should help mitigate pressures on Boeing's financial position.

Concerns include Boeing's large debt balance, which leaves its rating exposed to adverse business or economic conditions until debt is reduced.

Key Rating Drivers

737 MAX Recertification

In the past year, the 737 MAX program's credit risks have lessened, supporting the Outlook revision. Since the first recertification in November 2020, flying has been allowed in more than 175 countries and the number of passenger flights has exceeded 125,000. Boeing has delivered approximately 200 MAX aircraft, and customers have placed about 650 gross orders. Fitch estimates the program's current order backlog covers 5-6 years of deliveries, and the backlog is up slightly from year-end 2020. Boeing and the US Department of Justice reached a 737 MAX settlement in early 2021, with financial terms lower than Fitch's expectations. Boeing also continued to pay down its MAX concessions and considerations to customers.

Notwithstanding the progress, Fitch sees several ongoing 737 MAX disappointments. The pace of deliveries has been slower than Fitch expected, partly due to the delay in China's recertification, which Fitch now expects will take place in late 2021 or early 2022. Boeing's inventory reduction has also been slower than expected, and Fitch expects the inventory will be burned off during 2022 and possibly into 2023. Fitch believes there is a risk the production increase to 31/month could be delayed.

COVID-19 Pandemic: Early Stages of Airline Recovery

The previous Rating Outlook had incorporated the impact of the pandemic on the aviation sector, but the sector has made steady progress on a recovery, supporting the revision to Stable. Since Fitch downgraded Boeing in late October 2020, multiple vaccines have been approved for use, and the WHO reports that nearly 6.4 billion does have been administered as of early October. The vaccines have driven an initial recovery in airline traffic. Further recovery will be spurred by continued vaccine roll-out, the lifting of international travel restrictions and global GDP growth.

Fitch's base case for airline passenger traffic (domestic and international) assumes revenue passenger kilometers (RPKs) will not recover to 2019 levels before YE 2023, and for a full year until 2024, and Fitch expects the recovery will be uneven by type of travel and region. Fitch expects capacity (available seat kilometers, ASKs) to recover before RPKs.

The global airline industry still has years to go before returning to pre-pandemic levels. The damage to airline balance sheets will affect the industry for years, exposing it to the risks of another shock. Fitch assumes a disconnect for several years between the typical relationship between global GDP and traffic growth, with traffic lagging GDP due to travel hesitancy and restrictions, plus some additional impact from reduced business travel and ESG concerns.

787 Production Quality Issues and Delivery Delays

The 787 program delivery delays partly offset the benefits from the ongoing recoveries with the MAX and global airlines. These delays are related to quality issues at both Boeing and some suppliers, and they have persisted for more than a year. In the last twelve months, Boeing has delivered only 18 787's. This compares with Boeing's production rate of 14 per month at the beginning of 2020. The lack of deliveries has negatively affected Boeing's financial results in 2021.

Boeing has an inventory of approximately 100 787's, some of which require rework before delivery. Fitch believes Boeing is subject to some contractual penalties because of the delays, and there is also cancelation risk. Additionally, there is a growing risk of a reach-forward loss, although this non- cash charge would not likely affect ratings by itself. Fitch's forecasts assume deliveries resume in the fourth quarter, although a further delay into early 2022 would not likely affect ratings. Fitch estimates deliveries could be abnormally high in 2022, before dropping in 2023 and 2024.

Fitch believes the 787 situation is not as serious as the 737 MAX crisis. The 787 is not grounded, and it appears to be one of the most used widebody aircraft during the pandemic. Also, the quality issues do not appear to be safety-related. In addition, order cancelations have been modest, and there have been some new orders so far in 2021. Fitch's discussions with Boeing's 787 customers indicate the airlines still want the aircraft, although the depressed long-haul market eases near-term pressures for additional 787 capacity.

Restructuring and Cost Reductions

Boeing has reduced its cost base during the coronavirus downturn, and Fitch believes the cost reductions have started to affect Boeing's results, including 2021 cash flow. The reductions include several voluntary and involuntary layoff programs, real estate footprint reductions, and consolidation of 787 production to one location (North Charleston). So far, Boeing has taken severance charges covering 19,000 workers.

Commercial Airplane Competitive Position

Boeing still shares a valuable duopoly with Airbus, but its competitive position has weakened in the past 30 months. The MAX grounding allowed Airbus to solidify its leadership in the narrowbody market. Boeing also stopped development of the New Midmarket Airplane (NMA). Boeing's termination of the proposed Embraer JV gave Airbus an edge at the smaller end of the narrowbody market with the A220 family. Finally, Boeing reduced some R&D expenditures in response to financial pressures. On the favorable side, potential new rivals from China and Russia have also seen their new aircraft programs delayed by the pandemic.

Generally Supportive Defense Environment

Fitch considers the U.S. budget environment to be generally favorable for most defense contractors, despite near-term headwinds. It is possible that broad-based spending cuts take place over the next few years in response to substantial government stimulus spending. However, Fitch expects changes in spending on Procurement and Research, Development, Test, & Evaluation (RDTE) -- the two areas of the budget most relevant to defense contractors -- will be relatively neutral, varying greatly depending on program allocations.

The president's FY2022 budget request was up only modestly from the prior year's budget, and on an inflation-adjusted basis it would likely be down. Both houses in Congress have responded with higher spending plans. The President's budget request included funding for most of Boeing's programs, but not the F/A-18 and the P-8.

Boeing Capital

The affirmation of BCC's ratings and revision of the Rating Outlook to Stable from Negative reflect the linkage with that of its parent, BA, and the fact that BA has provided unconditional guarantees for the due and punctual payment and performance of all of BCC's outstanding publicly-issued debt. In addition to the guarantee, BCC's role arranging, structuring, and providing financing to support the sale of BA's products, the high level of management and operational integration between the two entities, BA's track record of support for BCC, and the fungibility of funding between the two entities further support Fitch's view of BCC as a core subsidiary of BA.

Consistent with Fitch's 'Non-Bank Financial Institutions Rating Criteria', the ratings and Rating Outlooks of core subsidiaries are equalized with those of its parent. BCC's unsecured debt rating is also equalized to the long-term IDR of the parent, reflecting the unconditional guarantee.

Derivation Summary

Boeing is rated two notches below its most immediate peer, Airbus SE (BBB+/F1/Stable). This is largely the result of Boeing's execution challenges in the past several years, which have combined to weaken Boeing's quantitative rating factors compared with Airbus'. Cash flow generation is one of the key differentiators between Airbus and Boeing. In the past, Boeing consistently achieved better FCF and funds from operations (FFO) due to program execution and lower investment needs despite higher dividend payments. However, the 737 MAX grounding has severely affected Boeing's cash flow, and caused debt to rise significantly versus Airbus's.

Boeing's business profile has also been modestly stronger than Airbus's because of a more diverse revenue mix between commercial and defense, in addition to services. Airbus currently has a stronger balance sheet and liquidity position. Airbus generally operates with a higher net cash position than Boeing, and this has been widened by the 737 MAX situation at Boeing. FX exposure is also a key differentiator between Boeing and Airbus, with the former having little exposure and the latter has significant exposure, although Airbus has taken actions to address this.

Compared to defense sector peer Lockheed Martin (A-/F1/Stable), Boeing is rated three notches lower due to a weaker financial profile that is only partly offset by better business diversification. Boeing is rated above Embraer (BB+/Negative) because of its superior competitive position and scale.

Key Assumptions

--737 MAX - China ungounds the MAX in late 2021, with a few deliveries to the country this year. A delay into the first quarter of 2022 would not affect the ratings or the Outlook. Boeing completes the delivery of inventoried aircraft from the grounding in late 2022 or early 2023. The 31/month production rate could be pushed back later in 2022;

--787 - deliveries resume in late 2021, with inventory worked down through 2022, and possibly into 2023. There will be a spike in deliveries in 2022, as Boeing meets the unmet demand from late 2020 and 2021;

--777 Programs - 777X enter service in late 2023 or the first half of 2024. Demand for the 777F remains solid;

--747 - The program finishes deliveries in 2022, and shuts down after more than 50 years;

--Global airline industry continues its recovery, reaching 2019 levels at the end of 2023. Short-haul traffic will recovery sooner, with long-haul later. Capacity will recover ahead of traffic, and the cargo aircraft market remains healthy. Business travel remains depressed for several years;

--Boeing's commercial deliveries grow through 2024, but they do not reach Boeing's delivery levels prior to the pandemic and the MAX grounding. Fitch expects the number of seats delivered by Boeing in 2024 will be down 10%-12% compared with 2018 deliveries. There is a mix shift toward narrowbody aircraft and away from widebody aircraft;

--The 'New Midmarket Airplane' development is not included in Fitch's forecast;

--The Defense and Space segment (BDS) grows modestly as the result of program wins over the past several years.

--Approximately 4,000 commercial airplanes (more than 100 seats) are retired or remain in long-term storage from 2020-2023, with around 25% of retirements being wide-body aircraft;

--FCF in 2021 is negative in the mid-single digits as a result of the delays in 787 deliveries and China's MAX recertification, along with the impact of Boeing's concessions to MAX customers. FCF should turn positive in 2022 in the mid-single digit range, as the company benefits from MAX and 787 inventory burn-off, partly offset by the margin impact of low production rates and MAX concessions;

--Boeing utilizes FCF and some excess liquidity to pay down debt, beginning in late 2021;

--No share repurchases or dividends through 2024, nor any equity issuance other than potential pension contributions or 401-K matching.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade:

--Sustained total debt to EBITDA leverage above 3.5x-4.0x and consolidated FFO-adjusted leverage above 3.5x-4.0x;

--Sustained FCF margins below 1%-2%;

--Material delays in resuming 787 deliveries beyond 1Q22, or worsening of the situation to include grounding of some or all of the 787 fleet;

--Indications of materially higher business risk from regulatory challenges, fines, litigation, or reputation and brand damage from the 737 MAX;

--Material negative developments with any of the company's other major programs leading to delivery delays, order cancellations, large additional costs or inventory write-downs;

--Large acquisitions or debt-funded share repurchases;

--Material provision of customer financing by BCC.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade:

--Sustained total debt to EBITDA leverage at 3.0x or lower and consolidated FFO-adjusted leverage at 3.0x or below;

--Sustained FCF margins at 3% or above;

--The company issues equity to accelerate debt reduction.

Boeing Capital:

BCC's ratings and Rating Outlook are linked to those of its parent.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade would be limited to Fitch's view of BA's credit profile. Fitch cannot envisage a scenario where the captive would be rated higher than its parent.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade could be driven by a downgrade of BA's ratings or the early termination of the parent guarantee prior to the repayment of BCC's outstanding publicly issued debt.

The unsecured debt rating is primarily sensitive to changes in the long-term IDR of the parent, and would be expected to move in tandem.

Best/Worst Case Rating Scenario

International scale credit ratings of Financial Institutions and Covered Bond issuers have a best-case rating upgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a positive direction) of three notches over a three-year rating horizon; and a worst-case rating downgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a negative direction) of four notches over three years. The complete span of best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings for all rating categories ranges from 'AAA' to 'D'. Best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings are based on historical performance. For more information about the methodology used to determine sector-specific best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579]

International scale credit ratings of Non-Financial Corporate issuers have a best-case rating upgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a positive direction) of three notches over a three-year rating horizon; and a worst-case rating downgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a negative direction) of four notches over three years. The complete span of best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings for all rating categories ranges from 'AAA' to 'D'. Best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings are based on historical performance. For more information about the methodology used to determine sector-specific best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579].

Liquidity and Debt Structure

Consolidated debt, as of June 30, 2021 was $63.6 billion (all attributable to BA except $1.5 billion attributable to BCC), of which $6.5 billion was classified as short-term. Most of the debt attributable to BCC consists of intercompany loans from BA to BCC. The company paid $1.15 billion of maturities with cash in the third quarter.

Boeing's debt rose nearly $50 billion during 2019 and 2020, demonstrating the company's access to the capital markets even in downturns. However, the company's debt load is now substantial, and high debt levels will remain a key credit consideration for several years despite Fitch's projections for steady debt reduction starting in late 2021.

The new debt was used to fund the company's cash burn and to build liquidity. Most of the new debt consisted of bonds with a mix of near-term maturities that would allow Boeing to reduce debt when the twin crises were over, but also some longer-term debt out as far as 2060. The company also issued a term loan to its bank group in early 2020 totaling $13.8 billion. The company issued $9.8 billion of bonds in early 2021, using the proceeds to repay part of the term loan. Fitch expects the remainder of the TL to be paid in late 2021 or prior to maturity in February 2022. Boeing has no commercial paper outstanding.

Fitch expects cash deployment will be almost exclusively focused on debt reduction for the next several years. The company has about $15 billion of maturing debt from 2022 to 2024, and it has some callable debt as well. Fitch estimates there is $20 billion-$21 billion of maturing and callable debt over the next three years, and Fitch estimates Boeing should have sufficient FCF and excess liquidity to pay down this debt while still maintaining higher liquidity that it has held in the past.

Leverage metrics (both EBITDA and FFO based) will remain high for the 'BBB-' rating (above 3.5x on a gross basis, or 2.0x-2.5x on a net basis) until sometime in 2024. Fitch believes Boeing will likely have the ability to pay down more debt, but available maturing and callable debt will limit its ability to do this absent a program to tender for additional debt issuances. Other quantitative credit metrics will be more in line with the current rating in 2023, or in a few cases in 2022. Qualitative credit factors are supportive of the current rating or higher.

With commercial business recovering, Boeing' liquidity supports the current IG rating. The company ended the second quarter with $36.1 billion of liquidity, consisting of $21.3 billion of cash and investments plus $14.8 billion of unused revolving credit facilities. Approximately $3.1 billion of the REV matures in October 2021, but Boeing has a term out option of one year. Fitch expects cash flow to turn positive in the next few quarters, leaving Boeing with a solid liquidity position. The substantial inventory of new aircraft accumulated in the past two years should be a cash and liquidity tailwind in the next 18 months.

Equity remains another source of financial flexibility for the company. Unlike many aviation companies in 2020, Boeing did not issue public equity to fund liquidity, although it did use stock to fund its 401-K match and to make a discretionary pension contribution. Fitch expects Boeing could issue equity to defend its credit ratings and liquidity position if there are further negative developments in its business, but Fitch has not included stock issuance in its base case forecasts.

Fitch does not expect Boeing to make material pension contributions in the next few years. Boeing made $4.0 billion of discretionary pension contributions in 2017, including a $3.5 billion contribution in the form of company shares. The company also made a discretionary contribution of $3.0 billion of BA stock to its pension fund in late 2020. These contributions should satisfy most required contributions for the next several years. Boeing's GAAP pension deficit at the end of 2020 was $13.7 billion, but the plan was more than 100% funded on an ERISA basis.

Fitch initially expected 2021 FCF would be break-even to modestly positive, but we now expect BA will burn $4 billion-$6 billion because of the delays in 787 deliveries and China's MAX recertification. Cash burn in the first half was $4.3 billion, but cash burn in the second quarter was only $0.7 billion.

Aside from the 787 and MAX impacts, Fitch believes 2021 underlying cash flow has been better-than-expected, mainly because of restructuring efforts and new aircraft orders. Fitch estimates fourth-quarter cash flow could be positive if 787 deliveries resume.

There are multiple moving parts to Boeing's cash flow in 2021 and through 2022. Headwinds include MAX concessions, inefficiencies at some of Boeing's aircraft facilities due to low production rates, rising inventory of undelivered 787's, higher interest expense, and some working capital investment to support to ramp up of MAX production in 2022. Tailwinds include the delivery of MAX and 787 planes out of inventory, restructuring benefits, and order deposits.

Fitch expects FCF will be positive in 2022 in the mid-single digits in our base case forecast. Fitch forecasts further improvements in FCF in 2023 and 2024, but not to levels seen prior to 2019.

BCC Treatment: In most cases where an industrial company has a captive finance subsidiary, Fitch deconsolidates the subsidiary and then evaluates the parent's financial statements treating the subsidiary as an equity investment. In the case of Boeing, Fitch does not follow this process, but instead looks at financial metrics primarily on a consolidated basis.

Fitch looks at Boeing and BCC on a consolidated basis for several reasons. BCC evolved into a less significant part of Boeing's financials as a result of the successful strategic shift to reduce BCC's emphasis on portfolio growth and increase focus on facilitating third-party financing for customers. BCC's primary strategic mission is not regular lending to Boeing's customers, but only occasionally financing aircraft, with approximately 99% of the company's deliveries typically financed by third parties.

The financial information Fitch has for BCC is not as detailed as is typically the case with industrial finance captives. In early 2013, Boeing fully guaranteed all of BCC's outstanding debt, which is also not typical of the industrial finance captives rated by Fitch. BCC stopped making separate SEC filings. In general, Fitch's approach of consolidating BCC's financial statements is a more conservative approach to the credit analysis of Boeing than if BCC were consolidated.

Issuer Profile

The Boeing Company (BA) is one of the world's largest aerospace & defense firms, founded in Seattle, WA in 1916. The company operates in four principal segments: Boeing Defense, Space & Security (BDS, 45% of 2020 sales); Boeing Commercial Airplanes (BCA, 28% of 2020 sales); Boeing Global Services (BGS, 27% of 2020 sales); and Boeing Capital Corporation (BCC, less than 1% of 2020 sales). In 2020, 51% of Boeing's revenues came from U.S. Government contracts (which include foreign military sales) and international customers accounted for approximately 37% of total revenues.

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

Public Ratings with Credit Linkage to other ratings

BCC's ratings and Rating Outlook are linked to those of its parent, BA.

ESG Considerations

The Boeing Company has an ESG Relevance Score of '4' for Management Strategy due to 737 MAX challenges, which has had a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. Below average execution on the 737 MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs and potential reputational damage.

Unless otherwise disclosed in this section, the highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3'. This means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit www.fitchratings.com/esg[http://www.fitchratings.com/esg].

; Short Term Issuer Default Rating; Affirmed; F3

Fitch conducts a reasonable investigation of the factual information relied upon by it in accordance with its ratings methodology, and obtains reasonable verification of that information from independent sources, to the extent such sources are available for a given security or in a given jurisdiction. The manner of Fitch's factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitch's ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed.

This opinion and reports made by Fitch are based on established criteria and methodologies that Fitch is continuously evaluating and updating. Therefore, ratings and reports are the collective work product of Fitch and no individual, or group of individuals, is solely responsible for a rating or a report. Ratings are not a recommendation to buy, sell, or hold any security. Such fees are expected to vary from US$10,000 to US$1,500,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent). Fitch Rates Boeing's Senior Notes 'BBB-'; Outlook Negative
4505 words
2 February 2021
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2021 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-02 February 2021: Fitch Ratings has assigned 'BBB-' ratings to The Boeing Company's (BA; BBB-/F3/Negative) proposed issuance of senior unsecured notes. The callable notes will be issued in multiple parts with maturities ranging from 2023 to 2026. Proceeds will be used to reduce borrowings outstanding under the company's term loan facility, which matures in February 2022. The transactions will not affect Boeing's gross debt balances.

Fitch lowered Boeing's credit rating to 'BBB-' from 'BBB' at the end of October 2020. The downgrade reflected a prolonged recovery from the pandemic compared with Fitch's prior expectations, continued pressures from the 737 MAX grounding and Fitch's estimate that Boeing will be challenged to return financial metrics to levels consistent with a mid 'BBB' rating by the end of 2022.

Developments have been mixed since the downgrade. Favorable developments include the 737 MAX's return to service in some key markets, orders for the 737 MAX and cargo aircraft, the approval and distribution of several COVID-19 vaccines, and Boeing's 737 MAX settlement with the U.S. Department of Justice. Negative developments include 787 production delays, deterioration of the 2021 cash flow outlook and the push-back of the date when the 777X will enter service.

Fitch continues to expect global airline traffic will not return to 2019 baseline levels until the end of 2023. Fitch's rating case assumes Boeing will deliver its inventory of more than 400 completed 737 MAX aircraft through 2021 and into 2022. While most qualitative rating factors support Boeing's investment-grade ratings, many of the company's quantitative rating factors will be inconsistent with the 'BBB' category for three years (2019-2021) and into 2022.

The Negative Rating Outlook incorporates ongoing uncertainty surrounding the impact of the pandemic on the aviation sector, continued pressure on production rates for some commercial aircraft models, the potential for inventory build of aircraft models in addition to the MAX and supply-chain risks. Other pandemic concerns driving the outlook include the continued impact on Boeing's commercial services business from lower airline traffic and retirement of older aircraft; the ramifications for global GDP, which is a key driver of air traffic trends; and the damage to airline balance sheets. The company's large total debt leaves it exposed to another shock to its business until the dual impact of the pandemic and MAX recedes and debt is reduced.

Factors supporting the ratings include the strategic positions of Boeing's businesses, diversification, technology, liquidity, access to the debt and equity markets, and a large order backlog. The relative stability of the company's defense and security business plus Boeing's strong position in cargo aircraft also support the ratings. Substantial cost reductions, including the consolidation of 787 assembly in South Carolina, should help mitigate some pressures on the company's financial position.

The ratings also incorporate expectations that Boeing has the potential to strengthen its credit profile via cash generation and debt reduction in the years after 737 MAX deliveries resume and after the coronavirus pandemic recedes. Overall, Boeing had a strong credit profile for its rating before the MAX grounding, and Fitch's ratings for the company incorporated the periodic stress periods that arise in the commercial aviation sector. However, the coronavirus is unmatched in its rapid impact on the aviation sector. Total company order backlog at the end of 2020 was $363 billion compared with $463 billion at the end of 2019, with the decline driven by low orders and cancellations.

Key Rating Drivers

Pandemic Impact on Commercial Aircraft

Fitch expects continued downward pressure on passenger airplane deliveries and production from Airbus SE, the Boeing Company, and other airplane manufacturers because of a slow recovery to pre-pandemic traffic levels, damaged airline financial profiles, travel restrictions and uncertainty about traveler behavior. Fitch estimates demand for aircraft deliveries will most likely be lower than that suggested by OEM production rates. However, in most scenarios downside production rate risk is lower than the magnitude of the already-announced cuts.

Fitch believes production will need to decline or airplane manufacturers will need to buildup aircraft inventory for market supply and demand to reach equilibrium. Either path will create cash flow challenges for the manufacturers. The analysis is highly sensitive to assumptions about traffic recovery and aircraft retirements. When growth returns, we assume it will be at a lower rate than pre-pandemic levels.

Fitch estimates approximately 4,700 passenger aircraft (those with more than 100 seats) will be produced in 2020 through 2023 based on announced production rates and possible rate increases. This compares with the top end of Fitch's delivery base case range of approximately 4,300 passenger aircraft, with downside risk based on a variety of factors. Fitch believes production is unlikely to return to pre-pandemic levels until 2025 or 2026.

Commercial Airplane Competitive Position

Boeing still shares a valuable duopoly with Airbus in large commercial aircraft, but its competitive position has weakened somewhat in the past 18 months. The MAX grounding allowed Airbus to consolidate its leadership in the narrow-body market, particularly the large end of the segment. Boeing also stopped development of the new midmarket airplane (NMA). Boeing's termination of the proposed Embraer JV gave Airbus an edge at the smaller end of the narrow-body market with the A220 family. Finally, Boeing reduced some R&D expenditures in response to financial pressures. On the favorable side for both Boeing and Airbus, potential new rivals from China and Russia have seen their new aircraft programs delayed by the pandemic.

Airline Traffic and Capacity

Fitch's base case for airline passenger traffic (domestic and international) assumes revenue passenger kilometers (RPKs) will not recover to 2019 levels before FYE23 and at FYE21 will still be 40% below 2019 levels. Underlying this forecast is the assumption that effective vaccines/treatments are available, but not at scale, through 2021, and there will be a continued collapse in travel until there is widespread vaccine/treatment availability.

Fitch's base case assumes domestic traffic recovers to 2019 levels around the middle of 2023, while international traffic returns to 2019 levels after 2023, perhaps the summer of 2024. Available information so far supports this assumption of domestic recovering first, including the data coming out of the important Chinese domestic market. Fitch expects capacity will recover before RPKs, and the agency believes load factors will remain lower than the record levels seen in 2019.

737 MAX Grounding

The U.S., the European Union and several countries have lifted the 737 MAX grounding since late November. Fitch expects the pace of re-certifications to pick up through the first quarter of 2021. China's recertification is a key watch item.

With the groundings lifted, passenger flights have resumed with six airlines, and the number of flights is approaching 3,000. Boeing has delivered more than 40 737 MAX aircraft since the grounding was lifted in the U.S. This will help the company's cash generation, but the program's full cash benefit is not likely to come until 2022. Boeing has also received several new 737 MAX orders, including from Ryanair and Alaska Air. The 737 MAX order backlog at the end of December was 3,987 planes, or 3,240 planes adjusted for accounting policies. Fitch estimates the adjusted backlog represents five to six years' worth of production at our delivery forecasts.

Logistical issues around the eventual ramp-up of production and deliveries remains a concern. Boeing faces complicated tasks of delivering more than 400 parked aircraft and ramping up production from currently low rates.

Cash generation by the MAX in at least the first year after the ungrounding will get a boost from deliveries of already-built aircraft. However, Boeing will also be bearing the expense of continued 737 production at low rates and the impact of concessions to customers. These offsetting factors will cause some uncertainty regarding cash generation.

BA has an ESG relevance score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737 MAX challenges, which has had a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. Below-average execution on the 737 MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs and potential reputational damage.

Derivation Summary

Boeing's most immediate peer is Airbus SE (BBB+/F1/Negative). Cash flow generation is one of the key differentiators between Airbus and Boeing. Boeing consistently achieved better free cash flow (FCF) and funds from operations (FFO) over the past decade, due to program execution and lower investment needs despite higher dividend payments. However, the 737 MAX grounding has severely affected Boeing's cash flow, and caused debt to rise significantly versus Airbus's.

Boeing's business profile has also been modestly stronger than Airbus's because of a more diverse revenue mix between commercial and defense. Airbus currently has a stronger balance sheet and liquidity position. Airbus generally operates with a higher net cash position than Boeing, and this has been widened by the 737 MAX situation at Boeing. FX exposure is also a key differentiator between Boeing and Airbus, with the former having little exposure and the latter has significant exposure, although Airbus has taken actions to address this.

Compared to defense sector peer Lockheed Martin (A-/Stable), Boeing is rated lower due to a weaker financial profile that is only partly offset by better business diversification. Boeing is rated above Embraer (BB+/Negative) because of its superior competitive position, scale and financial strength.

Key Assumptions

Fitch's Key Assumptions Within the Rating Case for the Issuer

--The 737 MAX groundings will continue to be lifted in phases by different regions through the remainder of 1Q21 and into 2Q21. Deliveries in various regions will resume shortly after the groundings are lifted;

--The inventory of MAX aircraft assembled but undelivered during the grounding will be delivered through 2021 and into 2022;

--Boeing delivers approximately 2,100 airplanes through 2023 (around 1,850 commercial, 280 cargo and military derivative), with risks mainly to the downside;

--Global airline traffic recovers to 2019 baseline levels at the end of 2023;

--Approximately 4,000 commercial airplanes (more than 100 seats) are retired or remain in long-term storage from 2020-2023, with around 25% of retirements wide-body aircraft;

--FCF is break-even or moderately negative for 2021, with the first half of the year showing the heaviest outflows;

--Debt is down modestly in 2021, then for several years Boeing uses its free cash flow to pay down debt;

--Share repurchases and dividends remain suspended through 2023;

--There is additional pressure on the production rates for the 787 and other wide-body models due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, but cargo aircraft demand partly offsets weak passenger 777 demand.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade:

--Extended coronavirus pandemic leads to more delivery deferrals, cancellations, and material production cuts of Boeing airplanes or material declines in revenues at Boeing Global Services (BGS), with 737 MAX program backlog falling to less than 3 years of deliveries;

--Coronavirus causes material disruptions to Boeing's operations, including extended shutdowns of key facilities;

--Material delays in resuming 737 MAX deliveries in a phased manner beyond 1Q21;

--Indications of materially higher business risk from regulatory challenges, fines, litigation, or reputation and brand damage from the 737 MAX;

--Material negative developments with any of the company's other major programs leading to delivery delays, order cancellations, large additional costs or inventory write-downs;

--Large acquisitions or debt-funded share repurchases;

--Material provision of customer financing by BCC;

--Sustained consolidated FFO-adjusted leverage above 3.5x;

--Sustained FCF margins below 1%-2%.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade:

--The Rating Outlook could be revised to Stable if Fitch gains confidence the severity and duration of the coronavirus pandemic will not further materially affect Boeing's credit profile;

--Positive rating actions could be considered if the company returns the 737 MAX program to a stable condition and begins to reduce debt taken on to fund inventory build related to the 737 MAX program;

--The company issues equity to pay down balance-sheet debt.

Best/Worst Case Rating Scenario

International scale credit ratings of Non-Financial Corporate issuers have a best-case rating upgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a positive direction) of three notches over a three-year rating horizon; and a worst-case rating downgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a negative direction) of four notches over three years. The complete span of best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings for all rating categories ranges from 'AAA' to 'D'. Best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings are based on historical performance. For more information about the methodology used to determine sector-specific best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579].

Liquidity and Debt Structure

Boeing's liquidity at the end of 2020 was approximately $35.1 billion, consisting of $25.6 billion of cash and investments plus $9.5 billion of revolving credit facility availability, offset by $1.7 billion of current maturities.

On Oct. 26, 2020, the company refinanced its 364-day revolver at $3.1 billion, down $100 million from the prior amount. This facility and its other revolving commitments total $9.5 billion, including a $3.2 billion three-year revolver and a $3.2 billion five-year revolver. The revolving commitments back a CP program of the same size.

Access to the public capital markets was favorable in 2020, easing risks about potential government support, secured debt issuance, and revolver draws. In early 2020, the company entered into a two-year delayed draw term loan (DDTL) with a group of banks to cover cash needs during 2020. The amount was $13.8 billion, and the company decided to draw down this unsecured facility early in response to the coronavirus pandemic. In April the company issued $25 billion of long-term unsecured bonds, and in the fourth quarter it issued $4.9 billion of unsecured bonds.

Consolidated debt, as of Dec. 31, 2020, was $63.6 billion ($62.0 billion attributable to Boeing, and $1.6 billion attributable to Boeing Capital), of which $1.7 billion was classified as short-term. Most of the debt attributable to Boeing Capital consists of intercompany loans from Boeing to Boeing Capital; the last significant amount of debt originally issued by BCC and subsequently guaranteed by Boeing matured in 2019.

Fitch expects significant debt reduction will not begin until 2022, although there are some positive scenarios that could lead to debt reduction in late 2021. Debt reduction will be the focus of FCF deployment for several years. The company could also reduce debt with excess liquidity, so the company's future liquidity policy will be an important item to watch.

Boeing can pay down its term loan at any time, but after that the company's debt maturity schedule will limit rapid debt reduction in the absence of liability management actions such as calling or tendering for bonds.

Boeing's cash generation typically contributes to its liquidity position. The company generated $9.6 billion of FCF in 2018, but FCF was substantially negative in 2019 ($8.9billion) and 2020 ($21 billion) due to the 737 MAX grounding and the pandemic. Fitch expects long-term annual free cash will be at least at 2018 levels, or greater than $9 billion per year. In 2021, FCF will be enhanced by the run-off of MAX inventories, but it will be offset by lower production and customer concessions. Fitch expects modest negative FCF, but the forecast is uncertain on both the downside and upside. Cash flow is likely to be negative in 1H21 before possibly turning positive in 2H21.

Fitch does not expect Boeing to make material pension contributions in the next few years. Boeing made $4 billion of discretionary pension contributions in 2017, including a $3.5 billion contribution in the form of company shares. The company made an additional discretionary contribution with $3 billion of Boeing stock in November of 2020. These contributions should satisfy most required contributions for the next several years. Boeing's GAAP pension deficit at the end of 2020 was $13.7 billion.

BCC Treatment: In most cases where an industrial company has a captive finance subsidiary Fitch deconsolidates the subsidiary and then evaluates the parent's financial statements treating the subsidiary as an equity investment. In the case of Boeing, Fitch does not follow this process but instead looks at financial metrics primarily on a consolidated basis. Fitch looks at Boeing and BCC on a consolidated basis for several reasons.

BCC evolved into a less significant part of Boeing's financials as a result of the successful strategic shift to reduce BCC's emphasis on portfolio growth and increase focus on facilitating third-party financing for customers. BCC's primary strategic mission is not regular lending to Boeing's customers, but only occasionally financing aircraft, with approximately 99% of the company's deliveries typically financed by third parties.

The financial information Fitch has for BCC is not as detailed as is typically the case with industrial finance captives. In early 2013, Boeing fully guaranteed all of BCC's outstanding debt, which is also not typical of the industrial finance captives rated by Fitch. BCC stopped making separate SEC filings. In general, Fitch's approach of consolidating BCC's financial statements is a more conservative approach to the credit analysis of Boeing than if BCC were de-consolidated.

Date of Relevant Committee

28 October 2020

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

ESG Considerations

Boeing has an ESG Relevance Score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737 MAX challenges, which has had a negative impact on the credit profile and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors.

Unless otherwise disclosed in this section, the highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3'. This means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit www.fitchratings.com/esg[http://www.fitchratings.com/esg].

The Boeing Company

The manner of Fitch's factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitch's ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed.

Fitch Solutions Group Limited

Document FITRA00020210202eh22000xd


Fitch Downgrades Boeing to 'BBB-'; Outlook Negative
5395 words
29 October 2020
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2020 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-29 October 2020: Fitch Ratings has downgraded The Boeing Company's Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) and senior unsecured debt to 'BBB-' from 'BBB'. Fitch has also downgraded the Long-Term IDR and senior unsecured ratings of Boeing Capital Corporation (BCC) to 'BBB-' from 'BBB'. The Rating Outlook is Negative.

Fitch has also assigned 'BBB-' ratings to Boeing's proposed issuance of senior unsecured notes. The notes will be issued in multiple parts with potential maturities ranging from 2023 to 2030. Proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, which Fitch expects will include paying down commercial paper balances and debt maturities in 2020 and 2021.

The downgrades reflect a prolonged recovery from the pandemic compared with Fitch's original expectations, continued pressures from the 737 MAX grounding, and Fitch's estimate that Boeing will be challenged to return financial metrics to levels consistent with a 'BBB' by the end of 2022.

Fitch now expects global airline traffic will not return to 2019 baseline levels until the end of 2023. Fitch's rating case assumes the 737 MAX will be re-certified in at least some key markets in November, but the delays in the certification process have lengthened the time frame over which Boeing will deliver its inventory of more than 450 completed aircraft, a process which will last into 2022. While most qualitative rating factors support Boeing's investment-grade ratings, many of the company's quantitative rating factors will be inconsistent with the 'BBB' category for three years (2019-2021) and into 2022.

The Negative Rating Outlook incorporates ongoing uncertainty surrounding the impact of the pandemic on the aviation sector, continued pressure on production rates for some commercial aircraft models, the potential for inventory build of aircraft models in addition to the MAX, and supply-chain risks. Other pandemic concerns driving the outlook include the continued impact on Boeing's commercial services business from lower airline traffic and retirement of older aircraft; the ramifications for global GDP, which is a key driver of air traffic trends; and the damage to airline balance sheets. The company's large total debt l leaves it exposed to another shock to its business until the dual impact of the pandemic and MAX recedes and debt is reduced.

Factors supporting the ratings include the strategic positions of Boeing's businesses, diversification, technology, liquidity, access to the capital markets, and a large order backlog. The relative stability of the company's defense and security business plus Boeing's strong position in cargo aircraft also support the ratings. Substantial cost reductions, including the consolidation of 787 assembly in South Carolina, should help mitigate some pressures on the company's financial position.

The ratings also incorporate expectations that Boeing has the potential to strengthen its credit profile via cash generation and debt reduction in the years after 737 MAX deliveries resume and after the coronavirus pandemic recedes. Overall, Boeing had a strong credit profile for its rating before the MAX grounding, and Fitch's ratings for the company incorporated the periodic stress periods that arise in the commercial aviation sector. However, the coronavirus is unmatched in its rapid impact on the aviation sector. Total company order backlog at the end of 1Q20 was $393 billion compared with $463 billion at the end of 2019, with the decline driven by low orders and cancellations.

Today's proposed debt issuance would enhance liquidity and help fund maturities through 2021. However, it also indicates that the company will not begin reducing debt from 2Q20 levels until 2022. Fitch had previously expected modest debt reduction to begin in late 2020 and in 2021. With today's proposed new issuance, Boeing will have issued more than $42 billion of gross debt in 2020. Fitch expects Boeing will end 2020 with more than $60 billion of gross debt and more than $25 billion of cash.

Key Rating Drivers

Pandemic Impact on Commercial Aircraft

Fitch expects continued downward pressure on passenger airplane deliveries and production from Airbus SE, the Boeing Company, and other airplane manufacturers because of a slow recovery to pre-pandemic traffic levels, damaged airline financial profiles, travel restrictions and uncertainty about traveler behavior. Fitch estimates demand for aircraft deliveries will most likely be lower than that suggested by OEM production rates. However, in most scenarios downside production rate risk is lower than the magnitude of the already-announced cuts.

Fitch believes production will need to decline or airplane manufacturers will need to build up aircraft inventory for market supply and demand to reach equilibrium. Either path will create cash flow challenges for the manufacturers. The analysis is highly sensitive to assumptions about traffic recovery and aircraft retirements. When growth returns, we assume it will be at a lower rate than pre-pandemic levels.

Fitch estimates more than 4,700 passenger aircraft (those with more than 100 seats) will be produced through 2023 based on announced production rates and possible rate increases. This compares with the top end of Fitch's delivery base case range of approximately 4,300 passenger aircraft, with downside risk based on a variety of factors. We believe production is unlikely to return to pre-pandemic levels until 2025 or 2026.

Commercial Airplane Competitive Position

Boeing still shares a valuable duopoly with Airbus in large commercial aircraft, but its competitive position has weakened somewhat in the past 18 months. The MAX grounding allowed Airbus to consolidate its leadership in the narrow-body market, particularly the large end of the segment. Boeing also stopped development of the new midmarket airplane (NMA). Boeing's termination of the proposed Embraer JV gave Airbus an edge at the smaller end of the narrow-body market with the A220 family. Finally, Boeing reduced some R&D expenditures in response to financial pressures. On the favorable side for both Boeing and Airbus, potential new rivals from China and Russia have seen their new aircraft programs delayed by the pandemic.

Airline Traffic and Capacity

Fitch's base case for airline passenger traffic (domestic and international) assumes revenue passenger kilometers (RPKs) will not recover to 2019 levels before FYE23 and at FYE21 will still be 30% below 2019 levels. Underlying this forecast is the assumption that an effective vaccine/treatment is available, but not at scale, through 2021, and there will be a continued collapse in travel until there is widespread vaccine/treatment availability.

Our base case assumes domestic traffic recovers to 2019 levels around the middle of 2023, while international traffic returns to 2019 levels after 2023, perhaps the summer of 2024. Available information so far supports this assumption of domestic recovering first, including the data coming out of the important Chinese domestic market. We expect capacity will recover before RPKs, and we believe load factors will remain lower than the record levels seen in 2019.

737 MAX Grounding

The U.S. and a few other countries are nearing the end of the re-certification process but Fitch does not expect a coordinated global ungrounding as countries are likely to lift the grounding in stages through the fourth quarter and into 2021. Coordination between the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and the E.U. Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) would be a positive, as they are the two main aircraft certification bodies in the industry.

In the US the last key part of the re-certification process was a report on proposed training. This was released for a period of public comment, which ends on November 2. Fitch expects several weeks of review by the FAA, then the grounding could be lifted shortly after. MAX deliveries should resume once the grounding is lifted in one or two key aviation markets, providing Boeing and aviation suppliers some relief. This will help the company's cash generation, but the program's full cash benefit is not likely to come until 2022.

Additional MAX order cancellations are anticipated, given the coronavirus pandemic's effect on the airline industry but we believe the backlog will remain sufficient to support our current delivery forecasts. There is some downside cushion with respect to MAX deliveries and Boeing's rating. For example, if the contractual backlog were to decline to approximately 3,000 aircraft, Fitch estimates this would still represent more than five or six years' worth of production at our delivery forecasts.

Logistical issues around the eventual ramp-up of production and deliveries may also exist. Boeing faces complicated tasks of delivering more than 450 parked aircraft and ramping up production from currently low rates.

Cash generation by the MAX in at least the first year after the ungrounding will get a boost from deliveries of already-built aircraft. However, Boeing will also be bearing the expense of continued 737 production at low rates. These two offsetting factors will cause some uncertainty regarding cash generation. Uncertainty will also remain due to potential fines and ongoing investigations related to the crashes and whether Boeing accelerates future narrow-body development plans to address Airbus's narrow-body lead.

Boeing Capital

The downgrade of BCC's ratings and the Negative Rating Outlook reflect the linkage with that of its parent, Boeing, and the fact that Boeing has provided unconditional guarantees for the due and punctual payment and performance of all of BCC's outstanding publicly-issued debt. In addition to the guarantee, BCC's role arranging, structuring, and providing financing to support the sale of Boeing's products, the high level of management and operational integration between the two entities, Boeing's track record of support for BCC, and the fungibility of funding between the two entities further support Fitch's view of BCC as a core subsidiary of Boeing. Consistent with Fitch's 'Non-Bank Financial Institutions Rating Criteria', the ratings of core subsidiaries are equalized with those of its parent.

BCC has historically exhibited sound operating performance, stable asset quality, and a sufficient liquidity profile, although its standalone credit risk profile would likely be lower than 'BBB-' given the cyclicality and residual value risk associated with the aircraft leasing business, the credit risk profile and concentration of BCC's lessors and its elevated leverage relative to standalone aircraft lessors'.

BCC's operating income declined in 2020 due to the adverse impact of the coronavirus pandemic on airline customers. Operating performance is expected to remain under pressure in the near-term from the potential for additional asset impairments, reduced finance lease income and an increase in the allowance for losses.

BA has an ESG relevance score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737 MAX challenges, which has had a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. Below-average execution on the 737 MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs and potential reputational damage.

Derivation Summary

Boeing's most immediate peer is Airbus SE (A-/F1/Negative). Cash flow generation is one of the key differentiators between Airbus and Boeing. Boeing consistently achieved better free cash flow (FCF) and funds from operations (FFO) over the past decade, due to better program execution and lower investment needs despite higher dividend payments. However, the 737 MAX grounding has severely affected Boeing's cash flow, and caused debt to rise significantly versus Airbus's. Boeing's business profile has also been modestly stronger than Airbus's because of a more diverse revenue mix between commercial and defense. Airbus currently has a stronger balance sheet and liquidity position. Airbus generally operates with a higher net cash position than Boeing, and this has been widened by the 737 MAX situation at Boeing. FX exposure is also a key differentiator between Boeing and Airbus, with the former having little exposure and the latter has significant exposure, although Airbus has taken actions to address this.

Compared to defense sector peer Lockheed Martin (A-/Stable), Boeing is rated lower due to a weaker financial profile that is only partly offset by better business diversification. Boeing is rated above Rolls-Royce (BB+/Negative) due mainly to better product diversification and strategic position. Boeing is rated above Embraer (BB+/Negative) because of its superior competitive position, scale, and financial strength.

Key Assumptions

Fitch's Key Assumptions Within Our Rating Case for the Issuer

--The 737 MAX groundings will be lifted in phases by different regions through the remainder of 4Q20 and into 2021. Deliveries in various regions will resume shortly after the groundings are lifted;

--The inventory of MAX aircraft assembled but undelivered during the grounding will be delivered through late 2020 and into 2022;

--Boeing delivers approximately 2,100 airplanes through 2023 (around 1,850 commercial, 280 cargo and military derivative), with risks mainly to the downside;

--Global airline traffic recovers to 2019 baseline levels at the end of 2023;

-- Approximately 4,000 commercial airplanes (more than 100 seats) are retired or remain in long-term storage from 2020-2023, with around 25% of retirement wide-body aircraft;

-- FCF is break-even or modestly positive for 2021, but negative through at least the second quarter;

--Debt rises in 2020, then for several years Boeing pays down debt and reduces much of its commercial paper (CP) balance;

--Share repurchases and dividends remain suspended through 2023;

-- Additional cuts to the 787 and other wide-body models are possible due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, but cargo aircraft demand partly offsets weak passenger 777 demand; and

--The 777X enters service in 2022.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Boeing:

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade:

--Extended coronavirus pandemic leads to more delivery deferrals, cancellations, and material production cuts of Boeing airplanes or material declines in revenues at Boeing Global Services (BGS), with 737 MAX program backlog falling to less than 3 years of deliveries;

--Coronavirus causes material disruptions to Boeing's operations, including extended shutdowns of key facilities;

--Material delays in resuming 737 MAX deliveries in a phased manner beyond 1Q21;

--Indications of materially higher business risk from regulatory challenges, fines, litigation, or reputation and brand damage from the 737 MAX;

--Material negative developments with any of the company's other major programs leading to delivery delays, order cancellations, large additional costs or inventory write-downs;

--Large acquisitions or debt-funded share repurchases;

--Material provision of customer financing by BCC;

--Sustained consolidated FFO-adjusted leverage above 3.5x; and

--Sustained FCF margins below 1%-2%.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade:

--The Rating Outlook could be revised to Stable if Fitch gains confidence the severity and duration of the coronavirus pandemic will not further materially affect Boeing's credit profile;

--Positive rating actions could be considered if the company returns the 737 MAX program to a stable condition and begins to reduce debt taken on to fund inventory build related to the 737 MAX program; and

--The company issues equity to pay down balance-sheet debt.

BCC:

BCC's ratings and Rating Outlook are linked to those of its parent.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/upgrade would be limited to Fitch's view of Boeing's credit profile. Fitch cannot envisage a scenario where the captive would be rated higher than its parent.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade could be driven by a downgrade of Boeing's ratings or the early termination of the parent guarantee prior to the repayment of BCC's outstanding publicly issued debt.

Best/Worst Case Rating Scenario

International scale credit ratings of Financial Institutions and Covered Bond issuers have a best-case rating upgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a positive direction) of three notches over a three-year rating horizon; and a worst-case rating downgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a negative direction) of four notches over three years. The complete span of best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings for all rating categories ranges from 'AAA' to 'D'. Best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings are based on historical performance. For more information about the methodology used to determine sector-specific best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings, visit [https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579]]

International scale credit ratings of Non-Financial Corporate issuers have a best-case rating upgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a positive direction) of three notches over a three-year rating horizon; and a worst-case rating downgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a negative direction) of four notches over three years. The complete span of best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings for all rating categories ranges from 'AAA' to 'D'. Best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings are based on historical performance. For more information about the methodology used to determine sector-specific best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579].

Liquidity and Debt Structure

Boeing's liquidity at the end of September 2020 was approximately $36.7 billion, consisting of $27.1 billion of cash and investments plus $9.6 billion of revolving credit facility availability, offset by $3.6 billion of outstanding CP and current maturities.

On Oct. 26, 2020, the company refinanced its 364-day revolver at $3.1 billion, down $100 million from the prior amount. This facility and its other revolving commitments total $9.5 billion, including a $3.2 billion three-year revolver and a $3.2 billion five-year revolver. The revolving commitments back the CP program of the same size.

Access to the public capital markets has been favorable so far in 2020, easing risks about potential government support, secured debt issuance, and revolver draws. In early 2020, the company entered into a two-year delayed draw term loan (DDTL) with a group of banks to cover cash needs during 2020. The amount was $13.8 billion, and the company decided to draw down this unsecured facility early in response to the coronavirus pandemic. In April the company issued $25 billion of long-term unsecured bonds.

Consolidated debt, as of Dec. 31, 2019, was $27.3 billion ($25.3 billion attributable to Boeing, and $2 billion attributable to BCC), of which $7.3 billion was classified as short-term, including $6.1 billion of CP. Consolidated debt, as of September 30, 2020, was $61 billion ($59.1 billion attributable to Boeing, and $1.9 billion attributable to BCC). Most of the debt attributable to BCC consists of intercompany loans from Boeing to BCC; the last significant amount of debt originally issued by BCC and subsequently guaranteed by Boeing matured in 2019.

Fitch expects significant debt reduction will not begin until 2022, although there are some positive scenarios that could lead to debt reduction in late 2021. Debt reduction will be the focus of FCF deployment for several years. The company could also reduce debt with excess liquidity, so the company's future liquidity policy will be an important item to watch. Boeing can pay down the DDTL at any time, but after that the company's debt maturity schedule will limit rapid debt reduction in the absence of liability management actions.

Boeing's cash generation typically contributes to its liquidity position. The company generated $9.6 billion of FCF in 2018, but 2019 FCF was substantially negative ($8.9 billion) due to working capital build- up related to the 737 MAX. Fitch expects long-term annual free cash will be at least at 2018 levels, or greater than $9 billion per year, but Fitch expects FCF in 2020 will again be significantly negative, approaching ($20 billion), as the company recovers from the MAX grounding. In 2021, FCF will be enhanced by the run-off of MAX inventories; Fitch expects modest positive FCF, but the forecast is uncertain on both the downside and upside. Cash flow is likely to be negative in 1H21 before turning positive in 2H21.

Fitch does not expect Boeing to make material pension contributions in the next few years. Boeing made $4 billion of discretionary pension contributions in 2017, including a $3.5 billion contribution in the form of company shares. The company announced an additional $3 billion of Boeing stock will be issued to the pension fund in November. These contributions should satisfy most required contributions for the next several years. Boeing's GAAP pension deficit at the end of 2019 was $15.9 billion.

BCC Treatment: In most cases where an industrial company has a captive finance subsidiary Fitch deconsolidates the subsidiary and then evaluates the parent's financial statements treating the subsidiary as an equity investment. In the case of Boeing, we do not follow this process but instead look at financial metrics primarily on a consolidated basis. Fitch looks at Boeing and BCC on a consolidated basis for several reasons. BCC evolved into a less significant part of Boeing's financials as a result of the successful strategic shift to reduce BCC's emphasis on portfolio growth and increase focus on facilitating third-party financing for customers. BCC's primary strategic mission is not regular lending to Boeing's customers, but only occasionally financing aircraft, with approximately 99% of the company's deliveries typically financed by third parties.

The financial information Fitch has for BCC is not as detailed as is typically the case with industrial finance captives. In early 2013, Boeing fully guaranteed all of BCC's outstanding debt, which is also not typical of the industrial finance captives rated by Fitch. BCC stopped making separate SEC filings. In general, Fitch's approach of consolidating BCC's financial statements is a more conservative approach to the credit analysis of Boeing than if BCC were consolidated.

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

Public Ratings with Credit Linkage to other ratings

BCC's ratings and Rating Outlook are linked to those of its parent Boeing.

ESG Considerations

Boeing has an ESG Relevance Score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737 MAX challenges, which has had a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors.

Unless otherwise disclosed in this section, the highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3'. This means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit www.fitchratings.com/esg[http://www.fitchratings.com/esg].
