Fitch conducts a reasonable investigation of the factual information relied upon by it in accordance with its ratings methodology, and obtains reasonable verification of that information from independent sources, to the extent such sources are available for a given security or in a given jurisdiction. The manner of Fitch's factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitch's ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed.

Fitch Ratings: Reductions at Boeing Plant not Expected to Impact Snohomish PUD (WA) Credit Quality
1662 words
2 October 2020
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2020 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-02 October 2020: Reports that The Boeing Company is expected to move production of the 787 Dreamliner from the Everett Factory in Snohomish County, WA to South Carolina is not expected to affect the credit quality of Snohomish County PUD #1 (WA) rated 'AA-'/Stable, according to Fitch Ratings. This includes the roughly $85 million in series 2020 refunding bonds that priced on Sept. 22.

Fitch's rating, published Sept. 15, considered the then expected reduction of Boeing's electric load of roughly 10% through 2025, due to pandemic related impacts on the aviation industry. Revenue from Boeing made up just under 4% of the utility's total $686 million operating revenue in fiscal 2019. Fitch's forward look factored in the expectation for Boeing revenues to decline from $24 million in fiscal 2019 to roughly $22 million going forward, given the delay of the production of the new 777X jet for multiple years, and the expected reduced production of current planes like the 787. Fitch anticipates that moving the production of the 787 jet (the most active production line at the Everett Factory) to South Carolina in the coming years will likely further reduce Boeing's electric load and negatively impact the local economy.

While Fitch is not able to estimate the timing or size of the decline in revenue and jobs at this time, the agency's analysis notes the district's substantial flexibility in meeting potential load declines while maintaining its very strong financial profile. The district's ability to independently adjust retail electric rates, modify purchased power from its contract with Bonneville, and potentially draw down some portion of its significant cash reserves provide financial flexibility.

The district's very strong financial profile provides some headroom at the current rating. The district's leverage ratio of 5.2x in fiscal 2019, measured by debt and fixed obligations in relation to funds available for debt service, supports the current rating. Incorporated in the rating analysis is a stress case scenario that contemplates a roughly $50 million shock to revenue from the coronavirus pandemic among other potential impacts. Leverage increases to roughly 7.0x in the stress case and remains adequate for the rating. Days cash on hand was 160 days in fiscal 2019. For further details please see Fitch's press release published on Sept. 15, 2020 at www.fitchratings.com[http://www.fitchratings.com].

Contact:

Parker Montgomery

Associate Director

+1-212-908-0356

Fitch Ratings, Inc.

300 West 57th Street

New York, NY 10019

Jeb Spengler

Director

+1415-732-5615

Media Relations: Sandro Scenga, New York, Tel: +1 212 908 0278, Email: sandro.scenga@thefitchgroup.com

Fitch Rtgs: Boeing 737 MAX Return and Backlog Risks Remain
1815 words
16 September 2020
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2020 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Related Fitch Ratings Content:

Boeing 737 MAX Return and Backlog Risks Remain (A Snapshot of Key Issues and Expectations): https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10136219[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10136219]

Fitch Ratings-Chicago/New York-16 September 2020: Aviation regulators and Boeing have made steady progress on the recertification of the 737 MAX. However, a number of regulatory uncertainties could further delay the return to service (RTS) of the aircraft and the risk of continued order cancellations or deferrals by airlines and lessors due to coronavirus-related travel restrictions also remains, says Fitch Ratings. Downside cushion with respect to MAX deliveries and Boeings rating currently exists but regulatory and backlog uncertainties indicate risks are weighted to the downside.

Sources of potential recertification delays include timing of the US Federal Aviation Administrations (FAA) public comment evaluation and the Joint Operations Evaluation Board recommendations and Flight Standardization Board (FSB) report public comment period. In addition to other FAA reports and events that are part of the ungrounding process, uncertainty also remains regarding additional requirements by international aviation regulators and whether there will be a separate certification for the 737 MAX 200 variant of the MAX 8. The US Congressional report on the 737 MAX released today is not expected to materially affect the timing of RTS.

We do not expect a coordinated global ungrounding but there could be coordination among a few countries. Coordination between the FAA and the EU Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) would be a positive, as they are the two main aircraft certification bodies in the industry. Once the grounding is lifted in one or two key aviation markets, such as the US and EU, MAX deliveries should resume. Additional order cancellations are anticipated, given the pandemics effect on the industry, but the backlog should remain sufficient to support our current delivery forecasts.

Boeing Deliveries Fitch Forecasts-CNTs[https://e.infogram.com/ffe31837-60cc-48e0-95d4-a490705862dd?src=embed]

We estimate total 737 MAX program deliveries for the 20192023 period will be at least 1,700 aircraft lower than expected at the beginning of 2019. This is a reduction of approximately 50% compared with Fitchs previous expectations, due to the grounding and the pandemics effect on the global airline industry.

Delivery ranges are driven by the coronavirus uncertain evolution, the timing of the FAAs ungrounding and the timing of the ungrounding in other regions. Visibility into 2021 and 2022 deliveries are further muddied by the lack of the typical signaling from production rates. Additionally, it is not clear at this time how the MAX settlements between Boeing and its customers will affect deliveries.

Regulatory and cancellation risks could cause deliveries to be at the bottom of, or even below, these ranges. The timing of the ungrounding will be important, as delays would pressure deliveries before the Northern Hemisphere summer of 2021, causing some airlines to defer additional deliveries. We expect it will take at least 18 months for Boeing to clear its existing 737 MAX inventory of more than 450 aircraft.

For more information see Fitchs special report

Boeing 737 MAX Return and Backlog Risks Remain (A Snapshot of Key Issues and Expectations)

at www.fitchratings.com[http://www.fitchratings.com].

Contacts:

Craig Fraser

Managing Director, US Corporates

+1 212 908-0310

Fitch Ratings, Inc.

33 Whitehall St.

New York, NY 10004

Carla Norfleet Taylor, CFA

Senior Director, Fitch Wire

+1 312 368-3195

Media Relations: Elizabeth Fogerty, New York, Tel: +1 212 908 0526, Email: elizabeth.fogerty@thefitchgroup.com

The above article originally appeared as a post on the Fitch Wire credit market commentary page. The original article can be accessed at www.fitchratings.com[http://www.fitchratings.com]. All opinions expressed are those of Fitch Ratings.

DIRECTORS AND SHAREHOLDERS RELEVANT INTERESTS ARE AVAILABLE AT https://WWW.FITCHRATINGS.COM/SITE/REGULATORY[https://WWW.FITCHRATINGS.COM/SITE/REGULATORY]. FITCH MAY HAVE PROVIDED ANOTHER PERMISSIBLE SERVICE TO THE RATED ENTITY OR ITS RELATED THIRD PARTIES. DETAILS OF THIS SERVICE FOR RATINGS FOR WHICH THE LEAD ANALYST IS BASED IN AN EU-REGISTERED ENTITY CAN BE FOUND ON THE ENTITY SUMMARY PAGE FOR THIS ISSUER ON THE FITCH WEBSITE.

Reproduction or retransmission in whole or in part is prohibited except by permission. All rights reserved. In issuing and maintaining its ratings and in making other reports (including forecast information), Fitch relies on factual information it receives from issuers and underwriters and from other sources Fitch believes to be credible. Fitch conducts a reasonable investigation of the factual information relied upon by it in accordance with its ratings methodology, and obtains reasonable verification of that information from independent sources, to the extent such sources are available for a given security or in a given jurisdiction. The manner of Fitch's factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitch's ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed.The information in this report is provided "as is" without any representation or warranty of any kind, and Fitch does not represent or warrant that the report or any of its contents will meet any of the requirements of a recipient of the report. A Fitch rating is an opinion as to the creditworthiness of a security. This opinion and reports made by Fitch are based on established criteria and methodologies that Fitch is continuously evaluating and updating. Therefore, ratings and reports are the collective work product of Fitch and no individual, or group of individuals, is solely responsible for a rating or a report. The rating does not address the risk of loss due to risks other than credit risk, unless such risk is specifically mentioned. Fitch is not engaged in the offer or sale of any security. All Fitch reports have shared authorship. Individuals identified in a Fitch report were involved in, but are not solely responsible for, the opinions stated therein. The individuals are named for contact purposes only. A report providing a Fitch rating is neither a prospectus nor a substitute for the information assembled, verified and presented to investors by the issuer and its agents in connection with the sale of the securities. Ratings may be changed or withdrawn at any time for any reason in the sole discretion of Fitch. Fitch does not provide investment advice of any sort. Ratings are not a recommendation to buy, sell, or hold any security. Ratings do not comment on the adequacy of market price, the suitability of any security for a particular investor, or the tax-exempt nature or taxability of payments made in respect to any security. Fitch receives fees from issuers, insurers, guarantors, other obligors, and underwriters for rating securities. Such fees generally vary from US$1,000 to US$750,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent) per issue. In certain cases, Fitch will rate all or a number of issues issued by a particular issuer, or insured or guaranteed by a particular insurer or guarantor, for a single annual fee. Such fees are expected to vary from US$10,000 to US$1,500,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent). While certain of the NRSRO's credit rating subsidiaries are listed on Item 3 of Form NRSRO and as such are authorized to issue credit ratings on behalf of the NRSRO (see https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/regulatory]), other credit rating subsidiaries are not listed on Form NRSRO (the "non-NRSROs") and therefore credit ratings issued by those subsidiaries are not issued on behalf of the NRSRO. Fitch Ratings Previews Seven Key Topics for Boeing and Airbus Second Quarter Earnings
2104 words
28 July 2020
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2020 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-28 July 2020: Fitch Ratings expects the earnings reports this week from The Boeing Company (BBB/Negative) and Airbus S.E. (A-/Negative) to be some of the most important in many years. Here are some top issues and questions Fitch's aerospace analysts have ahead of the earnings releases, filings, and in discussions with management teams as we look into the second half and 2021.

Liquidity and Cash Burn - Liquidity is a credit positive at both companies, but these resources will be eroded the longer the coronavirus pandemic downturn continues. Fitch will be looking for indications of the magnitude of cash used for items such as inventory build, restructuring costs, supplier support, and, for Boeing, 737 Max concessions. Fitch expects substantial cash use, with more than $11 billion likely burned in the first half at both companies. Fitch expects this will continue into the early part of 2021. Fitch forecasts liquidity from various sources will be in the $30 billion-$40 billion range at both companies at quarter-end. A key question is when the two OEMs will be at break-even cash flow levels. Fitch believes this is likely to happen in the second half of 2021, aided by an expected partial recovery in the airline sector and inventory unwind.

Commercial Aircraft Deliveries vs. Production Rates - Both OEMs are currently building more planes than they are delivering, which can rapidly drain cash, as Boeing experienced in the extreme during 2019 with the 737MAX grounding. This is being done partly to support the OEMs' vast supply chains but also to maintain their own core operating capabilities. Fitch expects working capital outflows as production exceeds deliveries for the second half and at least part of 2021 at both OEM's for twin-aisle models and for Airbus with its single-aisle planes. The opposite should be the case for Boeing single-aisles in 2021 assuming the 737 MAX returns to service, although there will likely be some offsetting WC build as Boeing readies higher production.

Restructuring Progress - We will be looking at how rapidly the companies cut costs in the past quarter and what the expected pace is going forward. We expect restructuring charges in the quarter, with the magnitude a key indicator of how expensive the restructuring will be. Both companies have previewed their restructuring plans, and we will watch for whether they comment on the visibility of the long-term structural shrinkage of the sector and need to announce expanded headcount reductions in their commercial businesses. This is an important topic, as the companies need to balance cost reductions versus preserving the long-term capabilities that are key sources of credit ratings strength.

Aircraft Finance Market and Potential Customer Financing - Aircraft financing will be a key factor in the eventual recovery in deliveries to airlines. Both Boeing and Airbus have been key financing facilitators, and they have valuable insights into the aircraft debt markets. We will be interested in their views on the capacity of aircraft lessors to provide financing, as airlines will be less able to increase debt in the next few years. Also, what are their views on the export-credit agencies, capital markets, and commercial banks? It would be a downside risk to cash flow forecasts if the OEMs used their own balance sheets to finance customer deliveries. In what cases would the OEMs consider providing customer financing? Fitch's current expectation is that this would only occur for key customers and on a short-term basis.

Other Business Lines - Non-commercial aircraft businesses provide some diversification for Boeing and Airbus, but the outlook is mixed. We are watching how defense budgets hold up in the face of higher government budget deficits and debt. Information about new program wins such as Boeing's F-15EX is also important. Do the companies believe demand for cargo aircraft is sustainable? How are their helicopter programs being affected by the downturn in the oil sector? How badly are the commercial services offerings being hurt?

Airline Markets by Region - Fitch believes that differences will begin to emerge among airline industry regions as the pandemic progresses. Are the OEMs seeing different levels of demand by region in this global industry? Could some regions emerge from the pandemic sooner, providing some support to aircraft deliveries? This is already becoming evident in parts of Asia, as capacity is ramping up again, but does this translate into willingness to take deliveries?

737Max - The coronavirus pandemic has overtaken the MAX as the key credit issue at Boeing, but the airplane is still a key concern. Aviation regulators will decide when the plane can carry passengers, but the pandemic will determine the pace of deliveries, which is the key to Boeing unlocking the 11-digit MAX inventory on its balance sheet. We don't expect many detailed comments about the FAA certification process, but we will be interested in any logistical updates for return-to-service, concessions paid in the quarter and whether estimated total concessions will be affected by recent order cancelations.

Contact:

Craig D. Fraser

Managing Director

+1-212-908-0310

Fitch Ratings, Inc.

33 Whitehall Street

New York, NY 10004

Director

Additional information is available on www.fitchratings.com[http://www.fitchratings.com]

Document FITRA00020200728eg7s001b9


Fitch Rates Boeing's Senior Notes 'BBB'
4882 words
30 April 2020
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2020 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-New York-30 April 2020: LEAD PARAGRAPH

Fitch Ratings has assigned 'BBB' ratings to The Boeing Company's (BA; BBB/Negative/F2) proposed issuance of senior unsecured notes. The notes will be issued in multiple parts with maturities ranging from 2022 to 2060. Proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, which Fitch expects will include paying down commercial paper balances and debt maturities.

On March 24, Fitch downgraded BA's long-term ratings and the long-term ratings for Boeing Capital Corporation (BCC) to 'BBB' from 'A-' and removed the ratings from Rating Watch Negative. The actions reflected the rapid escalation of the coronavirus pandemic and the effect it is having on Boeing's aviation markets and operations. The Rating Outlook is Negative.

Fitch's rating case includes expectations for a significant global economic downturn with a gradual recovery into 2021 and 2022. This scenario will dramatically affect airline traffic and financial results, driving requests for delivery deferrals and lower maintenance expenditures. Fitch does not expect global aviation markets to return to 2019 levels until 2022, and in some cases 2023. Under this scenario, BA's financial metrics will be very weak for the current rating in 2020, but the company has sufficient liquidity, including today's bond issuance, to withstand the downturn. Fitch expects Boeing will be able to rebuild its credit metrics, already weakened by the 737 MAX grounding, to levels consistent with a 'BBB' category rating by the end of 2021 or early 2022.

The Negative Rating Outlook is driven by the risk of a more extended coronavirus pandemic, the ongoing risks related to the timing of the return-to-commercial service (RTCS) of the 737 MAX, and the pace of the 737 MAX delivery ramp up after the grounding is lifted. In the case of a second wave of infections or a prolonged coronavirus impact, including extended shut-downs of Boeing's key facilities or material delays on the 737 MAX RTCS, Fitch's expects Boeing could need access to additional capital, which could further pressure BA's credit profile.

Factors related to coronavirus, including the duration and severity of the pandemic, will remain key concerns for BA's ratings. These factors include the continued impact on Boeing's commercial services business from lower airline traffic; the potential for increased requests for commercial airplane delivery deferrals; the ramifications for global GDP, which is a key driver of air traffic trends; and the direct impact on Boeing's operations, particularly in the Seattle area. Another key concern is whether the coronavirus prolongs the 737 MAX grounding.

The ratings are supported by Boeing's competitive positions in its main businesses. In addition, the ratings incorporate expectations that BA has the potential to strengthen its credit profile via cash generation and debt reduction in the years after 737 MAX deliveries resume and after the coronavirus pandemic recedes. Overall, BA had a strong credit profile for its rating before the MAX grounding, and Fitch's ratings for the company incorporated the periodic stress periods that arise in the commercial aviation sector. However, the coronavirus is unmatched in its rapid impact on the aviation sector. Fitch's forecasts include conservatism for potentially higher cost related to the 737 MAX situation. Fitch believes the lack of material 737 MAX cancelations since the grounding illustrates the aviation industry's continued support for the aircraft, which also supports the rating. Total company order backlog at the end of the first quarter of 2020 was $439 billion compared to $463 billion at the end of 2019.

Boeing's debt nearly doubled in 2019 to around $27.0 billion, and debt rose to $38.9 billion at the end of the first quarter after Boeing drew down its $13.8 billion delayed draw term loan. Debt will continue to rise in with today's debt issuance. Fitch expects year-end 2020 debt could be approximately $45 billion after the company reduces commercial paper balances and meets debt maturities. If ending debt is higher than $45 billion, Fitch expects it would be offset by higher cash balances. Fitch expects Boeing will prioritize debt pay down starting in 2021.

Key Rating Drivers

Coronavirus Pandemic:

Coronavirus risks for Boeing are both global and local. From a global perspective, Fitch has several virus related concerns related to Boeing's financial performance. First, lower air traffic will hurt results at Boeing Global Services (BGS) due to lower aftermarket services and parts; Fitch estimates BGS could see revenues down mid-teens in 2020. The pandemic has also spurred airline delivery deferral requests, and aircraft deliveries will be lower than previously expected in both 2020 and 2021. This was a key driver of Fitch's forecast revisions and the rating downgrade in March. Fitch believes wide-body demand has taken the biggest hit, but the situation will also lead to a slower 737 MAX production ramp up.

Locally, coronavirus will affect Boeing's operations, particularly in the Seattle area, which the virus has hit harder than many other regions in the U.S. Approximately 45% of Boeing' employees are in Washington State. The company's facilities in the region were closed for about one month, but recently reopened. A negative scenario, in Fitch's view, would be if Boeing's key facilities nation-wide had to be shut again for several months.

Commercial Aircraft Deliveries:

Fitch expects aircraft deliveries will be lower than previously expected in both 2020 and 2021, which was a key driver of the rating downgrade in March. The new production rates that Boeing announced on Wednesday are in line with Fitch's forecasts from the March rating downgrade. Wide-body demand has taken the biggest hit, but the situation will also lead to a slower MAX production ramp up. Fitch believes there are risks of additional production cuts, which is incorporated in the Negative Outlook.

Fitch's forecasts are informed by the firm's credit view of the global airline industry, as well as insights from Fitch's aircraft leasing and aircraft ABS teams. Fitch's global airline ratings incorporate scenarios where revenues fall 75% to 100% in the second quarter of 2020 before beginning a slow recovery in the second half. Delivery deferrals are key elements of most airlines' near-term plans to address the severe liquidity pressures caused by the pandemic. Fitch believes some of the deferrals will be into the second half of 2020, but some will flow into 2021. After the recovery begins, airlines will have higher debt levels and lower liquidity than pre-pandemic, which will drive additional delivery deferrals in 2021 and 2022.

The wide-body aircraft market will be most affected given the severe impact on long-haul routes. Deliveries in 2021 will fall at least one-third, and could be down 50% from recent peak production levels. Cargo aircraft could see less pressure than passenger jets, at least initially. Overbooking will relieve some of the delivery pressure on the 737 MAX, but Fitch expects the production ramp up will slow versus prior expectations.

Other risks to the delivery outlook include supply chain disruptions and the aircraft finance market. Fitch has included no material customer financing from Boeing in its forecasts, but it would be negative for Boeing's credit profile if the company needs to meet some of its financing commitments due to disruption in the capital markets. Fitch expects the U.S. Export-Import Bank will ease some of the pressure in the market and could see a significant amount of activity in the next two years.

737 MAX Grounding:

A key rating concern continues to be regulatory risk and uncertainty regarding the timing and global sequencing of the 737 MAX' RTCS. Boeing continues to expect expects the ungrounding will begin in mid-2020. Fitch believes the pandemic increases the risk that this date could be pushed back. The MAX will likely be a concern throughout the aviation credit sector through 2021 as the airline industry catches up on delayed MAX deliveries. The MAX situation reduced much of Boeing's financial cushion in the 'A' category, leaving the company more exposed to other unforeseen events or industry developments, such as the coronavirus.

The logistical challenge of returning the planes to service and catching up on deliveries is also a concern, particularly considering the risk of supplier challenges with an extended 737 MAX production suspension. BA's substantial debt build-up over the past 12 months is another concern. There is also uncertainty over the ultimate amount of concessions BA will make to airlines, although there is a chance that negotiations regarding virus-related deferrals could lead to lower concessions. The MAX situation is also likely to increase business risk from fines, litigation, weakened competitive position, or reputation damage. Fitch expects there will be a lingering operating margin impact for several years even after the MAX returns to commercial service.

Fitch views the MAX situation as partly an issue of timing unless substantial orders are cancelled. However, key uncertainties remain in addition to the unclear timing on RTCS. These include pilot training requirements, public perception of the MAX, MAX valuations, aircraft finance impact and lawsuits/investigations. There is also uncertainty surrounding the phasing of RTCS throughout the world. It is also clear that the role of regulators in the airplane certification process will change.

Embraer Joint Venture Termination

On April 25, Boeing terminated the agreement to establish several joint ventures with Embraer (ERJ/BB+/Negative). Fitch believes this illustrates how the coronavirus has changed the aerospace sector's priorities. The termination will benefit BA's liquidity, as it will not spend $4.2 billion to help establish the proposed JV. It also will not consolidate $3.5 billion of related debt. The termination also frees up management time and resources to address the key challenges at hand, namely the coronavirus and the MAX. Some strategic questions arise, such as whether the termination opens the door for other aspiring aerospace players to link up with ERJ. Fitch expects litigation is likely. Termination does not preclude future tie ups between the two companies.

Potential Capital Needs and Potential Government Support:

BA's decision to suspend its dividend was a form of self-help that will reduce cash outflows by approximately $9 billion over the next two years. However, in the scenario of a prolonged coronavirus impact or a second wave of infections, Boeing could need access to additional capital to bridge liquidity until the economy recovers or MAX deliveries resume. Additional debt beyond current expectations could pressure the 'BBB' ratings unless the debt is used to build liquidity.

Fitch has general concerns regarding continued comments about the possibility of government support, but broad government support for Boeing is not incorporated into Fitch's analysis. Fitch believes Boeing and its suppliers would require government support in the scenario of an extended pandemic combined with significant disruption of the public capital markets. However, various Federal Reserve programs lessen some concerns. Support for airlines worldwide by various governments indirectly supports the aerospace sector.

ESG: BA has an ESG relevance score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737 MAX challenges, which has had a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. Below average execution on the 737 MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs and potential reputational damage.

Derivation Summary

Boeing's most immediate peer is Airbus SE (A-/F1/Positive). Several key credit factors differentiate the two companies' ratings. Cash flow generation is one of the key differentiators between Airbus and Boeing. Boeing consistently achieved better FCF and FFO over the past decade, due to better program execution and lower investment needs despite higher dividend payments. However, the 737 MAX grounding has severely affected Boeing's cash flow, and caused debt to rise significantly versus Airbus. Boeing's business profile has also been modestly stronger than Airbus' because of a more diverse revenue mix between commercial and defense. Airbus currently has a stronger balance sheet and liquidity position. Airbus generally operates with a higher net cash position than Boeing, and this has been widened by the 737 MAX situation at Boeing. FX exposure is a key differentiator between Boeing and Airbus, with the former having little exposure and the latter have significant exposure, although Airbus has taken actions to lessen the situation.

Key Assumptions

Fitch's Key Assumptions Within the Rating Case for the Issuer

--The 737 MAX groundings will be lifted in phases by different regions through 3Q20. Deliveries in various regions will resume in 2020 shortly after the groundings are lifted;

--Total MAX inventory build will exceed $15 billion;

--The 737 MAX program order backlog does not suffer material cancelations;

--BA moves the 737 production rate up at a slower than previously expected rate due to the impact of the coronavirus on the airline industry;

--The inventory of MAX aircraft assembled but undelivered during the grounding will be delivered in 2020 and 2021;

--Margins are negatively affected by MAX-related costs in 2019 through 2021, but remain consistent with the rating in 2021, with EBIT margin approximately 10%;

--Concessions and other considerations for 737 MAX customers affected by the grounding will rise from the $8.8 billion amount already estimated and recognized by Boeing;

--Debt rises in 2020, then for several years Boeing pays down debt;

--Share repurchases remain suspended through the forecast period;

--The dividend suspension remains in effect through 2021 and part of 2022;

--The 777X enters service in 2021.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Factors that could lead, individually or collectively, lead to negative rating action/downgrade:

--Extended coronavirus pandemic leads to more delivery deferrals of Boeing airplanes or material declines in revenues at BGS;

--The coronavirus causes material disruptions to Boeing's operations, including extended shut-downs of key facilities;

--Substantial order cancellations and related material cost increases for the 737 MAX program;

--Material delays in resuming 737 MAX deliveries in a phased manner beyond the mid-year 2020 time frame;

--Indications of materially higher business risk from regulatory challenges, fines, litigation, or reputation and brand damage from the 737 MAX situation;

--Material negative developments with any of the company's other major programs leading to delivery delays, order cancellations, large additional costs or inventory write-downs;

--Large acquisitions, particularly combined with a sector downturn, or debt-funded share repurchases;

--Sustained consolidated FFO-adjusted leverage above 3.0x to 3.5x;

--Sustained FCF margins below 3%.

Factors that could, individually or collectively, lead to positive rating action/downgrade:

--The Rating Outlook could be revised to Stable if Fitch gains confidence the severity and duration of the coronavirus pandemic will not materially affect Boeing's credit profile;

--Positive rating actions could be considered if the company returns the 737 MAX program to a stable condition and begins to reduce debt taken on to fund inventory build related to the 737 MAX program.

Best/Worst Case Rating Scenario

International scale credit ratings of Non-Financial Corporate issuers have a best-case rating upgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a positive direction) of three notches over a three-year rating horizon; and a worst-case rating downgrade scenario (defined as the 99th percentile of rating transitions, measured in a negative direction) of four notches over three years. The complete span of best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings for all rating categories ranges from 'AAA' to 'D'. Best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings are based on historical performance. For more information about the methodology used to determine sector-specific best- and worst-case scenario credit ratings, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579].

Liquidity and Debt Structure

Boeing's liquidity at the end of March 2020 was approximately $20 billion, consisting of $15.5 billion of cash and investments plus $9.6 billion of revolving credit facility availability, offset by $5.2 billion of short-term debt. Liquidity will initially be enhanced by today's debt issuance. The termination of the Embraer joint venture will help the liquidity outlook during 2020, as Boeing will no longer make the $4.2 billion payment to fund the transaction.

On Oct. 30, 2019, the company refinanced and increased its revolving commitments to $9.6 billion, including a $3.2 billion 364-day revolver, a $3.2 billion three-year revolver, and a $3.2 billion five-year revolver. The revolving commitments back the CP program of the same size.

In early 2020, the company entered into a two-year Delayed Draw Term Loan with a group of banks to cover cash needs during 2020. The amount was $13.8 billion. The company decided to draw down the facility early in response to the coronavirus pandemic.

Consolidated debt, as of Dec. 31, 2019, was $27.3 billion ($25.3 billion attributable to BA, and $2.0 billion attributable to BCC), of which $7.3 billion was classified as short-term, including $6.1 billion of CP. Consolidated debt, as of March 31, 2020, was $38.9 billion ($36.9 billion attributable to BA, and $2 billion attributable to BCC), of which $5.2 billion was classified as short-term. Most of the debt attributable to BCC consists of intercompany loans from BA to BCC.

Boeing's cash generation typically contributes to its liquidity position. The company generated $9.6 billion of FCF in 2018, but 2019 FCF was substantially negative ($8.9 billion) due to working capital build up related to the 737MAX. Fitch expects long term annual FCF will be at least at 2018 levels, or greater than $9 billion per year, but Fitch expects FCF in 2020 will again be significantly negative as the company recovers from the MAX grounding. In 2021, FCF will be enhanced by the run-off of MAX inventories.

Fitch does not expect Boeing to make material pension contributions in the next few years. Boeing made $4.0 billion of discretionary pension contributions in 2017, including a $3.5 billion contribution in the form of company shares. This satisfied most required contributions for the next several years. Boeing's GAAP pension deficit at the end of 2019 was $15.9 billion.

BCC Treatment: In most cases where an industrial company has a captive finance subsidiary Fitch deconsolidates the subsidiary and then evaluates the parent's financial statements treating the subsidiary as an equity investment. In the case of Boeing, Fitch does not follow this process, but instead look at financial metrics primarily on a consolidated basis. Fitch looks at Boeing and BCC on a consolidated basis for several reasons. BCC evolved into a less significant part of Boeing's financials as a result of the successful strategic shift to reduce BCC's emphasis on portfolio growth and increase focus on facilitating third-party financing for customers. BCC's primary strategic mission is not regular lending to Boeing's customers, but only occasionally financing aircraft, with approximately 99% of the company's deliveries typically financed by third parties.

The financial information Fitch has for BCC is not as detailed as is typically the case with industrial finance captives. In early 2013, Boeing fully guaranteed all of BCC's outstanding debt, which is also not typical of the industrial finance captives rated by Fitch. BCC stopped making separate SEC filings. In general, Fitch's approach of consolidating BCC's financial statements is a more conservative approach to the credit analysis of Boeing than if BCC were consolidated.

Date of Relevant Committee

24 March 2020

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

Public Ratings with Credit Linkage to other ratings

BCC's ratings are linked to those of its parent, The Boeing Company.

ESG Considerations

BA has an ESG relevance score of '4' for Management and Strategy due to 737 MAX challenges, which has had a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. Below average execution on the 737 MAX strategy has contributed to higher costs and potential reputational damage.

Except for the matters discussed above, the highest level of ESG credit relevance, if present, is a score of 3 - ESG issues are credit neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity(ies), either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity(ies). For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit www.fitchratings.com/esg[http://www.fitchratings.com/esg].

Fitch conducts a reasonable investigation of the factual information relied upon by it in accordance with its ratings methodology, and obtains reasonable verification of that information from independent sources, to the extent such sources are available for a given security or in a given jurisdiction. The manner of Fitch's factual investigation and the scope of the third-party verification it obtains will vary depending on the nature of the rated security and its issuer, the requirements and practices in the jurisdiction in which the rated security is offered and sold and/or the issuer is located, the availability and nature of relevant public information, access to the management of the issuer and its advisers, the availability of pre-existing third-party verifications such as audit reports, agreed-upon procedures letters, appraisals, actuarial reports, engineering reports, legal opinions and other reports provided by third parties, the availability of independent and competent third- party verification sources with respect to the particular security or in the particular jurisdiction of the issuer, and a variety of other factors. Users of Fitch's ratings and reports should understand that neither an enhanced factual investigation nor any third-party verification can ensure that all of the information Fitch relies on in connection with a rating or a report will be accurate and complete. Ultimately, the issuer and its advisers are responsible for the accuracy of the information they provide to Fitch and to the market in offering documents and other reports. In issuing its ratings and its reports, Fitch must rely on the work of experts, including independent auditors with respect to financial statements and attorneys with respect to legal and tax matters. Further, ratings and forecasts of financial and other information are inherently forward-looking and embody assumptions and predictions about future events that by their nature cannot be verified as facts. As a result, despite any verification of current facts, ratings and forecasts can be affected by future events or conditions that were not anticipated at the time a rating or forecast was issued or affirmed.

A Fitch rating is an opinion as to the creditworthiness of a security. This opinion and reports made by Fitch are based on established criteria and methodologies that Fitch is continuously evaluating and updating. Therefore, ratings and reports are the collective work product of Fitch and no individual, or group of individuals, is solely responsible for a rating or a report. The individuals are named for contact purposes only. Ratings may be changed or withdrawn at any time for any reason in the sole discretion of Fitch. Fitch does not provide investment advice of any sort. Ratings are not a recommendation to buy, sell, or hold any security. Ratings do not comment on the adequacy of market price, the suitability of any security for a particular investor, or the tax-exempt nature or taxability of payments made in respect to any security. Such fees generally vary from US$1,000 to US$750,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent) per issue. Such fees are expected to vary from US$10,000 to US$1,500,000 (or the applicable currency equivalent). Fitch Rebaixa IDRs da Embraer Para 'BB+'; Perspectiva Revisada Para Negativa
3877 words
29 April 2020
Fitch Rating / Non Rating Action Commentary
FITRA
English
Copyright 2020 by Fitch Ratings Inc., Fitch Ratings Ltd. and its subsidiaries.

Fitch Ratings-Chicago-29 April 2020: A Fitch Ratings rebaixou os IDRs (Issuer Default Ratings - Ratings de Inadimplncia do Emissor) de Longo Prazo em Moedas Estrangeira e Local da Embraer S.A. (Embraer) para 'BB+' (BB mais), de 'BBB-' (BBB menos), e afirmou o Rating Nacional de Longo Prazo da empresa em 'AAA(bra)', atribuindo Perspectiva Estvel classificao. A Observao Negativa foi removida e a agncia atribuiu Perspectiva Negativa aos IDRs. O rating das notas sem garantias reais da Embraer foi removido da Observao Positiva e rebaixado para 'BB+' (BB mais), de 'BBB-' (BBB menos). O rating das notas estava em Observao Positiva, aguardando a criao de uma joint venture comercial com a The Boeing Company (Boeing, IDRs 'BBB'/Perspectiva Negativa).

As aes de rating refletem os fortes obstculos enfrentados pelo setor de aviao comercial, devido pandemia do coronavrus, que vem resultando em alto volume de adiamentos nas entregas de aeronaves, menores investimentos em manuteno e forte concorrncia no mercado de jatos comerciais e executivos. A Fitch acredita que este cenrio levar deteriorao da gerao de fluxo de caixa livre (FCF) e dos indicadores de crdito da Embraer no perodo de 2020 a 2022. O cancelamento do acordo com a Boeing impe desafios adicionais posio competitiva da Embraer de mdio a longo prazos, embora abra a possibilidade de acordos com outras empresas de aviao. A Embraer reportou, em 2019, USD121 milhes em custos de ciso relacionados joint venture proposta. O cenrio-base da Fitch no inclui qualquer reembolso, diante da discusso em andamento entre as partes e da incerteza sobre o momento desta potencial entrada de caixa.

A Perspectiva Negativa dos IDRs reflete as elevadas incertezas em torno do setor de aviao e o risco de continuidade das medidas de distanciamento social entre a segunda metade de 2020 e o incio de 2021. A capacidade da Embraer de ajustar rapidamente suas operaes e sua estrutura de custos ser essencial para minimizar a elevada queima de caixa, projetada pela Fitch em cerca de USD1 bilho. A ausncia de grandes amortizaes de dvida durante 2020 e 2021 e a forte posio de liquidez, aliadas ao acesso aos mercados de crdito no Brasil e no exterior, so pontos fortes para o rating da Embraer. O cenrio-base da agncia estima que a alavancagem lquida da empresa ficar em cerca de 11,0 vezes e 4,0 vezes em 2020 e 2021, respectivamente.

Os ratings da Embraer refletem suas posies competitivas nos mercados de jatos comerciais e executivos, seu robusto backlog (carteira de pedidos firmes), de USD16,8 bilhes, que abrange vrios anos de vendas, e programas no segmento de defesa do Brasil. O forte perfil de liquidez da companhia (principalmente fora do pas) e suas elevadas receitas de exportao, combinadas com o fluxo de caixa operacional no exterior, sustentam ainda mais os ratings 'BB+' (BB mais), que esto acima do Teto-pas do Brasil, 'BB'. As preocupaes com o crdito incluem novos programas de desenvolvimento de aeronaves em andamento, incluindo a transio para a aeronave E2, o impacto nos pedidos e nos backlogs a longo prazo, a concorrncia acirrada nos mercados de jatos comerciais e executivos, novos participantes no mercado de jatos comerciais e as baixas margens operacionais da companhia em vrios segmentos de negcios.

PRINCIPAIS FUNDAMENTOS DO RATING

Presso Elevada: No cenrio atual, com o aumento do nmero de adiamentos de entregas de aeronaves, a Fitch acredita que haver reduo de 50% no volume de entregas de aeronaves comerciais em 2020 e alguma recuperao em 2021. Em termos de entregas de jatos executivos, a queda deve ser menor, em torno de 15% a 20%, tendo em vista a diferente dinmica de negcios. A agncia estima que a Embraer enfrentar desafios adicionais para impulsionar os pedidos da nova aeronave E2. O backlog da companhia totalizava 338 aeronaves no final do quarto trimestre de 2019, frente a 435 avies h dois anos. Na viso da Fitch, a carteira de pedidos sustentar a produo da Embraer nos prximos anos, apesar de ser impactada por fatores como concentrao e qualidade. A agncia observa que a aeronave E175-E2 , atualmente, muito pesada para atender s clusulas de escopo existentes no mercado dos Estados Unidos. Estas clusulas devem ser renegociadas para que a aeronave seja vivel, ou os pedidos precisaro ser convertidos para E1.

Baixo Risco Relacionado ao Brasil: Aproximadamente 90% da receita da Embraer so gerados por exportaes ou operaes comerciais no exterior. No entanto, o ambiente econmico e poltico do Brasil representa preocupao, uma vez que a maior parte da base de ativos operacionais da companhia est domiciliada no pas. O Brasil est listado como parte relacionada nos registros da Embraer Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC, Comisso de Ttulos e Cmbio dos EUA), devido golden share que o governo brasileiro detm na empresa, alm de sua participao como acionista direto (aproximadamente 5% da Embraer), por meio de uma empresa controlada pelo governo.

Atualmente, a Fitch no considera o Teto-pas do Brasil um fator de limitao dos ratings da Embraer, tendo em vista a robusta posio de caixa da empresa fora do Brasil, bem como seu forte foco nas exportaes e no crescimento dos negcios no exterior. Com base nestes fatores, de acordo com a metodologia da agncia, a Embraer poderia ser classificada at trs graus acima do Teto-pas brasileiro.

Margem de EBIT Pressionada: O desempenho operacional da Embraer foi mais fraco do que o esperado no ano passado e deve apresentar tendncia ligeiramente negativa em 2020. A empresa vem enfrentando presses em suas margens operacionais, enquanto desenvolve vrios novos programas. A reduo do volume de entregas na aviao comercial e o mix menos favorvel afetaram a diluio do custo fixo da Embraer em 2019. Em um cenrio de adiamento significativo nas entregas de aeronaves, as margens operacionais sero ainda mais pressionadas. Em 2020, a Fitch estima que a margem de EBIT da companhia ficar negativa, em torno de 1%, e apresentar recuperao em 2021 e 2022, aumentando para 4,6% e 5,8%, respectivamente.

FCF Negativo: A fraca gerao de fluxo de caixa operacional e os investimentos em curso devem levar a Embraer a queimar cerca de USD1 bilho em caixa em 2020, segundo estimativas da Fitch. De acordo com o cenrio-base da agncia, o fluxo de caixa das operaes (CFFO) da companhia dever ficar negativo em mais de USD500 milhes em 2020, pressionado pela reduo nas entregas de aeronaves e pelas necessidades de capital de giro. Os investimentos operacionais esto estimados em cerca de USD400 milhes. Em 2021, a expectativa de que o FCF atinja o ponto de equilbrio, em torno de USD71 milhes, aps investimentos de USD450 milhes.

Alta Alavancagem: A Fitch estima que a alavancagem lquida da Embraer (dvida lquida/EBITDA) aumentar para 11,0 vezes em 2020 e se reduzir para 4,2 vezes em 2021 e para 3,8 vezes em 2022, em comparao com 2,0 vezes em 2018 e com a mdia de 1,0 vez no perodo de 2015 a 2017.

SENSIBILIDADE DOS RATINGS

Fatores que podem, individual ou coletivamente, levar a uma ao de rating positiva/elevao:

-- A Perspectiva dos IDRs da Embraer pode ser revisada para Estvel se o desempenho da companhia em 2020 e em meados de 2021 levar a ndices de alavancagem lquida em torno de 3,5 vezes em 2021;

-- A elevao dos IDRs para grau de investimento depender do retorno de ndices de alavancagem lquida abaixo de 2,5 vezes, em bases sustentveis, alm da manuteno de forte posio de liquidez, sem grandes riscos de refinanciamento a mdio prazo.

Fatores que podem, individual ou coletivamente, levar a uma ao de rating negativa/rebaixamento:

-- Cancelamentos substanciais de pedidos nos programas E1 e E2 e no segmento de jatos executivos;

-- Atrasos significativos e aumentos de custos nos programas E2, KC-390 ou outros;

-- Impossibilidade de reduzir custos e de reportar gerao de FCF acima do esperado;

-- Manuteno de alavancagem lquida consistentemente acima de 3,5 vezes at o fim de 2021;

-- Quedas substanciais na liquidez, sem redues proporcionais de dvida;

-- Rebaixamento, em vrios graus, no rating soberano do Brasil, juntamente com um rebaixamento semelhante no Teto-pas.

Melhores e Piores Cenrios de Rating

Os ratings de crdito em escala internacional de Empresas No Financeiras tm o melhor cenrio de elevao (definido como o 99 percentil de transies de ratings, medido em uma direo positiva) de trs graus ao longo de um horizonte de rating de trs anos; e o pior cenrio de rebaixamento (definido como o 99 percentil de transies de ratings, medido em uma direo negativa) de quatro graus ao longo de trs anos. A faixa completa de melhores e piores cenrios de ratings de crdito para todas as categorias de rating varia de 'AAA' a 'D'. Os melhores e piores cenrios de ratings de crdito se baseiam no histrico de desempenho. Informaes adicionais sobre a metodologia utilizada para determinar os melhores e piores cenrios de rating especficos do setor esto disponveis em https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579[https://www.fitchratings.com/site/re/10111579]

PRINCIPAIS PREMISSAS

-- Manuteno dos principais programas de desenvolvimento, E190-E2 e KC-390, dentro do cronograma e do oramento;

-- Reduo das entregas de aeronaves comerciais da Embraer para cerca de 50% em 2020 e 20% em 2021 (em comparao com 2019) e estabilizao ou aumento deste percentual em 2022;

-- Reduo de entregas no mercado de jatos executivos de 20% em 2020 e de 15% em 2021 (em comparao com 2019), seguindo uma tendncia mais resiliente para este segmento;

-- Expectativa de margem de EBIT negativa em 2020 (cerca de 1,3%), com ligeira recuperao em 2021 e 2022;

-- FCF negativo em USD1 bilho em 2020;

-- Investimentos em torno de USD400 milhes em 2020 e 2021;

-- Expectativa de captao de cerca de USD1 bilho em novas dvidas de longo prazo para financiar a gerao de FCF negativo em 2020, a custos financeiros atrativos;

-- Manuteno de forte liquidez ao longo do perodo projetado.

RESUMO DA ANLISE

A Embraer uma das lderes do mercado de jatos comerciais com menos de 150 assentos. Suas aeronaves so conhecidas pela engenharia, pela semelhana entre os modelos e pelo design interno. A carteira da empresa apresentava 338 pedidos firmes em 31 de dezembro de 2019, incluindo jatos da nova famlia E2. A carteira total de pedidos, que abrange contratos de todos os segmentos, totalizava USD16,8 bilhes no mesmo perodo. A posio competitiva da Embraer mais fraca que a de seus principais pares globais, sobretudo a Boeing e a Airbus , baseada em escala e fora financeira, parcialmente compensada por sua boa posio no segmento de jatos comerciais com menos de 150 assentos, bem como por seu perfil financeiro administrvel.

A alavancagem, as margens e a liquidez da Embraer so melhores que as da Bombardier Inc. (IDRs 'CCC'), mas esta ltima apresenta maior diversificao de negcios. A Bombardier Inc. tambm opera nos segmentos de jatos executivos e defesa. A maioria das operaes da Embraer est no Brasil, embora a companhia esteja deslocando grande parte de sua linha de montagem de jatos executivos para os EUA. A metodologia da Fitch de atribuio de ratings acima do Teto-pas foi aplicada a esta anlise.

Referncias para Fontes Altamente Relevantes Citadas entre os Principais Fundamentos dos Ratings

As principais fontes de informao utilizadas na anlise esto descritas nas Metodologias Aplicadas listadas abaixo.

LIQUIDEZ E ESTRUTURA DA DVIDA

Forte Liquidez: No entender da Fitch, a flexibilidade financeira da Embraer relativamente conservadora, considerando sua posio de liquidez, que fundamental para sustentar os ratings. A empresa tem uma poltica de manter forte liquidez, o que a Fitch considera adequado, tendo em vista as despesas com programas peridicos de desenvolvimento e a natureza do setor areo comercial. A agncia acredita que a Embraer permanecer disciplinada no que diz respeito liquidez e manter sua abordagem proativa na gesto de passivos, para evitar a exposio a riscos de refinanciamento. A companhia no possui linhas de crdito rotativo, o que no incomum para emissores corporativos latino-americanos.

Em 31 de dezembro de 2019, a Embraer tinha dvida de USD3,4 bilhes, incluindo uma posio lquida de USD271 milhes em dvidas no mbito de uma Sociedade de Propsito Especfico (SPE) e USD282 milhes em garantias de financiamentos de venda (depsitos em garantia). O caixa total e os investimentos no final do perodo eram de USD2,7 bilhes -- montante suficiente para cobrir a amortizao da dvida at, pelo menos, 2023. A maior parte da dvida da Embraer vence aps este perodo. Em 31 de dezembro de 2019, aproximadamente 86% do caixa, equivalentes e investimentos financeiros da empresa estavam denominados em dlares.

CONSIDERAES DE ESG

Salvo disposio em contrrio divulgada nesta seo, o score mais alto de relevncia de crdito ESG 3. As questes de ESG so neutras ou tm impacto mnimo no crdito da Embraer, seja devido sua natureza, ou forma como esto sendo administradas pela empresa. Para mais informaes sobre os Scores de Relevncia de ESG da Fitch, acesse www.fitchratings.com/esg[http://www.fitchratings.com/esg].

INFORMAES REGULATRIAS:

A presente publicao um relatrio de classificao de risco de crdito, para fins de atendimento ao artigo 16 da Instruo CVM n 521/12.

As informaes utilizadas nesta anlise so provenientes da Embraer S.A.

A Fitch adota todas as medidas necessrias para que as informaes utilizadas na classificao de risco de crdito sejam suficientes e provenientes de fontes confiveis, incluindo, quando apropriado, fontes de terceiros. No entanto, a Fitch no realiza servios de auditoria e no pode realizar, em todos os casos, verificao ou confirmao independente das informaes recebidas.

Histrico dos Ratings:

Embraer S.A.

Data na qual a classificao em escala nacional foi emitida pela primeira vez: 4 de abril de 2016.

Data na qual a classificao em escala nacional foi atualizada pela ltima vez: 17 de dezembro de 2019.

A classificao de risco foi comunicada entidade avaliada ou a partes a ela relacionadas, e o rating atribudo no foi alterado em virtude desta comunicao.

Os ratings atribudos pela Fitch so revisados, pelo menos, anualmente.

A Fitch publica a lista de conflitos de interesse reais e potenciais no Anexo X do Formulrio de Referncia, disponvel em www.fitchratings.com/brasil[http://www.fitchratings.com/brasil]

Para informaes sobre possveis alteraes na classificao de risco de crdito veja o item: Sensibilidade dos Ratings.

Informaes adicionais esto disponveis em 'www.fitchratings.com[http://www.fitchratings.com]' e em 'www.fitchratings.com/site/brasil[http://www.fitchratings.com/site/brasil]'.

Este relatrio foi publicado originalmente, em ingls, em 28 de abril de 2020.

A Fitch Ratings foi paga para determinar cada rating de crdito listado neste relatrio de classificao de risco de crdito pelo devedor ou emissor classificado, por uma parte relacionada que no seja o devedor ou o emissor classificado, pelo patrocinador (sponsor), subscritor (underwriter), ou o depositante do instrumento, ttulo ou valor mobilirio que est sendo avaliado.

-- Metodologia de Ratings Corporativos (27 de maro de 2020).
